Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to file a formal complaint against XXXX for unlawfully denying my application for credit in violation of federal laws, specifically : The Equal Credit Opportunity Act ( ECOA ), 15 U.S.C. 1691 The Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), 15 U.S.C. 1602 and 1611 The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, 12 U.S.C. 1431 Issue On XX/XX/24, I applied for credit with XXXX and was subsequently denied without an adequate or legally valid explanation. XXXX decision to deny my credit application appears to be in direct violation of the ECOA, which prohibits creditors from discriminating against any applicant on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, or receipt of public assistance ( 15 U.S.C. 1691 ).

Additionally, the ECOA and its implementing regulation, 12 C.F.R. 1002.9, require creditors to provide a specific reason for a denial of credit in a timely manner. XXXX either failed to provide an explanation or provided an insufficient explanation that does not comply with these legal standards. 

Furthermore, under the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1602 ), XXXX is obligated to disclose credit terms transparently and in good faith. Denying credit without valid reasoning undermines my rights under this statute and suggests non-compliance with 15 U.S.C. 1611, which prohibits creditors from knowingly failing to provide accurate disclosures or following legal obligations.

Legal Basis 15 U.S.C. 1691 ( ECOA ) : This provision prohibits discrimination and mandates clear, timely communication of reasons for credit denial.

12 C.F.R. 1002.9 : Requires creditors to issue a written statement detailing specific reasons for denying credit or informing the applicant of their right to request this information within 60 days.

15 U.S.C. 1602 & 1611 ( TILA ) : These provisions ensure that lending practices are conducted transparently and that any denial is justifiable and communicated effectively.

12 U.S.C. 1431 : This section governs federal oversight of lending practices and ensures that financial institutions operate in compliance with public and consumer protection laws. 
Harm Caused The denial of credit has caused significant harm to me, including : Inability to meet my financial needs and goals due to lack of access to credit. 
Adverse effects on my creditworthiness and potential opportunities for future credit. 
Emotional distress and financial hardship as a result of being denied without proper justification.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear TransUnion, I am writing to address a concerning discrepancy in my credit report. I was dismayed to find that an item that had previously been removed by two other credit reporting agencies has been re-verified by your agency. This has raised serious concerns for me, as the other agencies concluded that the item was unverified and subsequently deleted it from my credit report. 

It is important to note that these items in question are a result of identity theft, which has caused significant distress and harm to my mental, emotional, and physical well-being. I find it deeply troubling that despite the clear evidence of fraudulent activity associated with this debt, your agency has chosen to not adhere to the regulations that mandate the validation of such debts. 

I must emphasize that the inaccuracies in my credit report are not only detrimental to my financial standing but also tarnish my reputation and creditworthiness. I urge you to promptly rectify this issue and ensure that the erroneous item is removed from my credit report in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. 

I kindly request that you conduct a thorough investigation into this matter and provide me with a detailed explanation as to why the item has been re-verified despite the lack of validation from other reporting agencies. It is imperative that this issue be resolved expeditiously to prevent further harm to my credit profile. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and expect a swift resolution to restore the accuracy of my credit report. Please feel free to contact me at your earliest convenience to discuss this further. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX, XXXX and XXXX do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, XXXX and XXXX ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to formally file a complaint against Equifax and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX for violations of federal laws, specifically under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), codified at 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), codified at 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. 

Issue : The account in question, a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX installment account, has been reported on my credit file by Equifax as " charged off '' but simultaneously reflects an outstanding balance of {$9600.00}. This reporting practice is in clear violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which mandates that consumer reporting agencies ensure maximum possible accuracy in the information contained within a consumer report. 

A charge-off designates the account as a loss for the creditor, written off for profit-and-loss purposes, and no longer considered collectable. However, it is inconsistent and misleading to maintain both a " charge-off '' status and an outstanding balance simultaneously. The reported status creates an inaccurate and unfair representation of my financial position.

Additionally, pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), furnishers of information ( in this case, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) have a duty to provide accurate information to credit reporting agencies. By reporting a balance on a charged-off account, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX has violated this statutory requirement.

Moreover, under 15 U.S.C. 1601, th
e Truth in Lending Act requires accurate disclosure of terms and obligations in credit arrangements. This misreporting may also lead to violations of TILA by failing to clearly delineate the status and financial obligations of the account.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Experian for Fraudulent and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally file a complaint against Experian for what I believe to be fraudulent, discriminatory, and unethical credit reporting practices that harm consumers, particularly minority groups. 
Recently, I observed that my XXXX XXXX dropped by over XXXX points, despite no changes to my credit report, no new accounts being added, and no inquiries being made. Upon reviewing my report, I found no explanation for this significant decrease. This sudden drop appears arbitrary and unsubstantiated. When I contacted Experian for clarification, their representatives were unable to provide a valid explanation for the change. 
This raises serious concerns about XXXX compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which mandates that consumer credit reports must be accurate and that consumers are entitled to a clear explanation of changes in their credit scores. By failing to provide transparency and accuracy, Experian is engaging in practices that I believe are fraudulent and harmful to consumers. 
Moreover, I have reason to believe that XXXX practices disproportionately XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX, particularly XXXX and XXXX individuals, who are often unfairly targeted or penalized in credit reporting. This type of discriminatory treatment violates not only consumer protection laws but also anti-discrimination laws. 

XXXX negligence and potential bias in reporting are unacceptable. These practices are damaging to consumers financial well-being and trust in the credit reporting system. I request the CFPB to : XXXX. Investigate Experian for fraudulent and discriminatory credit reporting practices. 

XXXX. Mandate that Experian provide a detailed explanation of XXXX XXXX changes to consumers. 

XXXX. Ensure accountability by requiring compensation for affected consumers, including myself, for the harm caused by inaccurate reporting. 

XXXX. Enforce stronger oversight and penalties on Experian for repeated violations of consumer protection laws. 



XXXX actions not only harm individual consumers but also erode the integrity of the financial system. I urge the CFPB to take swift and decisive action to address these issues. 



Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your response

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XXXX XXXX, XXXX, an account with **Credence Resource Management** ( original creditor : XXXX XXXX XXXX ) was reported on my credit file with a balance of ** $ XXXX. However, I have identified multiple inaccuracies in the reporting of this account across XXXX and XXXX including : XXXX XXXX  did not report this account, despite the obligation to ensure consistent and accurate reporting across all credit bureaus. 
- Inconsistent dates, such as the " Date Last Active, '' which is reported as XXXX XXXX, XXXX by XXXX but XXXX XXXX, XXXX by XXXX. 
- Incorrect payment status, claiming " Seriously past due '' despite no clear validation of the debt. 

I attempted to address this issue by reviewing my records and contacting the reporting bureaus. On ** [ Insert Date You Took Action ] **, I submitted disputes to the credit bureaus and requested debt validation from Credence Resource Management under the **Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) **. 

-- - # # # **Actions Taken** - Submitted a **dispute letter** to XXXX and XXXX, highlighting the discrepancies.

- Sent a **debt validation request** to Credence Resource Management , requesting documentation proving the debt 's validity and accuracy. 
- Attached an affidavit, asserting my rights under the **Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) **, to ensure the information 's correction Mark Paid as agreed or ok Legal Consequences of Non-Compliance Failure to comply with this lawful demand may result in legal action, including but not limited to : Filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX CFPB ), Federal Trade Commission XXXX FTC XXXX, and XXXX  Department of Attorney General. 

Seeking damages under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and other applicable laws. 

Legal Basis for My Dispute 15 U.S.C. 1681a ( 2 ) : Reports limited to transactions or experiences between the consumer and the reporting entity must be removed if included unlawfully.

15 U.S.C. 1681e : Reporting entities must ensure the maximum possible accuracy of credit report information. The inclusion of incorrect data demonstrates non-compliance.

15 U.S.C. 1681i : Reinvestigate disputed information within 10 days.

Notify the furnisher and verify the accuracy of disputed information.

Correct or delete unverifiable or inaccurate information.

15 U.S.C. 1692g : Validation of debts requires documented evidence of debt accuracy and my liability.

15 U.S.C. 1611 : Criminal penalties, including fines of up to {$5000.00} or imprisonment for up to one year, apply to knowingly providing false information.

Product: Mortgage
Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue with the loan closing
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have reached out to Atlantic Bay Mortgage Group via a Non-Negotiable Notice of Debt Validation Request as a Private Communication between the Parties and Constitute Due Process In Administrative Procedure, to provide validation information and confirm whether it still owns the loan ( XXXX & Loan ID XXXX ). Following XXXX5 U.S. Code ss 1692 and under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, all collection efforts regarding this account are to be suspended until this matter has been settled. ( documentation of said Notices will be provided as attachments ). I additionally asked Atlantic Bay, to provide me with detailed documentation as to whether it had securitized this loan in the Non-Negotiable Notice of Debt Validation Request.

One of Atlantic Bay 's communications was " Since your mortgage loan with Atlantic Bay was sold to a third party on XX/XX/XXXX, Atlantic Bay would not be the party to send this form '' /request.

Another of Atlantic Bay 's subsequent letters sent me a letter on XX/XX/XXXX, stating it had sold my loan in XX/XX/XXXX to XXXX XXXX. 
I have asked the mortgage company to provide documentation about the sale of that loan transaction. 
XXXXntic Bay has repeatedly sent misguided information with the intent to delay, deny, and confuse us the consumers from obtaining the true and accurate information of the Loan it says it provided.

Throughout this whole process that has been a 12-month journey Atlantic Bay has continued to provide inaccurate information on the loan, it has not provided us the name, address, and contact person of the entity it says purchased my loan, nor has it ceased collection efforts to include setting a date for a DEED Of Trust Sale ( XX/XX/XXXX ) after it clearly stated in its letters dated XXXX and XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX that it had sold the mortgage. 
The Mortgage and DEED are documents that require assignments and court filings if they are transferred, reassignment, or subsequent change of ownership.

Atlantic Bay has not provided any of the required notices to me the consumer of this kind of transaction concerning my mortgage and deed.

Atlantic Bay does not possess the standing in my opinion to take a lawful action of foreclosure or Deed of trust sale if it does not hold/own both the Mortgage and the Deed.

Some of the requests in this Administrative Procedure with Atlantic Bay were to consider Rescission and start over since it had failed to provide clear and concise relevant information in this contract. Since Atlantic Bay failed in its responsibility to provide relevant disclosure concerning the Securitization, Sale, and Trading of my financial assets ( NOTE and DEED ) without my knowledge then Rescission is necessary and being claimed by me. 
I sent Atlantic Bay at least two Non Negotiable Notices of Rescission on XX/XX/XXXX and again on XX/XX/XXXX. I subsequently received a letter from XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, informing me that they were retained by Atlantic Bay to respond to my NOTICE of Right of Rescission dated XX/XX/XXXX and received by Atlantic Bay. Telling me that my right to rescind expired on XX/XX/XXXX, without further addressing the disputes associated with my claim. I responded by sharing with the Law Firm, a letter that I received from Atlantic Bay, Noticing that it had received my request for Rescission well in advance of the XX/XX/XXXX date my alleged right to rescind has expired. 
Case law states that UNTIL the required disclosures have been provided to the consumer then the clock on the consumer 's right of RESCISSION does not start. Additionally, I will provide a XXXX XXXX to obtain information on the Securitization, Sale, possible Funding, and active trading of a XXXX  Number created during the Mortgage Back Securitization and offers associated with the loan in question with Atlantic Bay.

Atlantic Bay has delayed, provided misinformation, and failed to provide the full disclosure that it is required to provide while lamenting they have been overloaded with requests that take up their valuable time after responding to my requests they label as bothersome and without merit.

The attachments and Atlantic Bay 's acknowledgment of the sale of the Mortgage, the securitization of the loan, and the sale of the deed of trust together reveal that Atlantic Bay lacks standing to take any action on me except to return the deed and Note to me free and clear with prejudice.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Account number XXXX Subject : Formal Dispute Regarding Negative Item and Violation of Federal Laws To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute an inaccurate and unlawful negative item listed on my credit report. I believe this entry is not only incorrect but also reflects a violation of several federal consumer protection laws. Below, I outline the violations and request immediate action to investigate and rectify this matter.

1. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1635 ( Right of Rescission ) : Under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), I am entitled to specific disclosures and protections regarding financial obligations. This law provides a right to rescind certain transactions within a specific timeframe. The negative item on my report does not reflect that this right was properly honored or communicated.

2. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( Validation of Debts ) : As per the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I have the right to request validation of any alleged debt. Despite my requests for verification, I have not received adequate proof that the negative item on my report is valid or accurate. This failure constitutes a violation of federal law.

3. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( Communication Practices ) : The FDCPA also regulates the manner and timing of communications regarding debt. Any communication about the disputed item must comply with the prescribed standards, including restrictions on contacting me without consent or at inappropriate times. I believe these standards have not been adhered to.

4. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( Compliance with Accurate Reporting ) : The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) mandates that credit bureaus maintain strict procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of information reported. The presence of this negative item, which I have reason to believe is inaccurate or unverifiable, indicates a failure on your part to comply with these obligations.

Requested Resolution : 1. I demand an immediate investigation into this matter and the removal of the disputed negative item from my credit report.

2. Please provide me with the purchase agreement verifying the accuracy and legality of the information in question, as required by federal law.

3. Confirm in writing that the disputed item has been removed or corrected within 30 days of receiving this letter.

Failure to address this matter adequately and in compliance with federal laws may result in further action, including filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and pursuing legal remedies. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this serious matter. Please acknowledge receipt of this letter and keep me informed of your actions regarding this dispute. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Statement on Supervisory and Enforcement Practices Regarding the Fair Credit Reporting Act and Regulation V in Light of the CARES Act The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection ( Bureau ) recognizes the serious impact the COVID-19 pandemic is having on the financial well-being of many consumers and on the operations of many supervised entities, including actors in the consumer reporting system, and the challenges of this unique and rapidly evolving situation. Last Friday, on XX/XX/XXXX, the XXXX signed the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act ( \ '' CARES Ad\ ' ), which provides critical emergency assistance to consumers and businesses affected by COVID-19 and includes provisions addressing consumer reporting requirements.

Consumer report information is critical to consumers and industry in determining who obtains credit, insurance, and housing, and at what price, and who obtains employment in many cases. Consumer reporting has enormous reach, as evidenced by the over XXXX XXXX consumers in the United States who have credit files and trade lines furnished by over XXXX providers. The continued operation of the consumer reporting system will play a critical role in the functioning of the consumer financial services market, promoting fair and efficient access to credit and benefiting consumers and creditors alike. The Bureau understands that the current crisis impacts the financial well-being of consumers and poses operational challenges for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers, accommodation, the furnisher report the credit obligation or account as current; or ( Il ) if the credit obligation or account was delinquent before the maintain the delinquent status during the period in which the accommodation is in effect; and ( bb ) if the consumer brings the credit obligation or account current during the period described in item ( aa ), report the credit obligation or account as current\ '' ). In addition, section XXXX of the CARES Act addresses the furnishing of certain student loans for which payments are suspended. Rendering them unable to investigate consumer reporting disputes within the timeframes the FCRA requires. Furnishers include a wide variety of businesses that vary in size and sophistication and can range from small retailers to very large financial services firms, each of which will face unique challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In evaluating compliance with the FCRA as a result of the pandemic, the Bureau will consider a consumer reporting agencies or furnisher\ 's individual circumstances and does not intend to cite in an examination or bring an enforcement action against a consumer reporting agency or furnisher making good faith efforts to investigate disputes as quickly as possible, even if dispute investigations take longer than the statutory timeframe. The Bureau reminds furnishers and consumer reporting agencies that they may take advantage of statutory and regulatory provisions that eliminate the obligation to investigate disputes submitted by credit repair organizations and disputes they reasonably determine to be frivolous or irrelevant. 
The Bureau will consider the significant current constraints on furnisher and consumer reporting agency time, information, and other resources in assessing if such a determination is reasonable. 
Regulatory Requirements This Policy Statement is a non-binding general statement of policy articulating considerations relevant to the Bureau\ 's exercise of its supervisory and enforcement authorities. It is therefore exempt from the notice and comment rule making requirements under the Administrative Procedure Act pursuant to 5 USC 553 ( b ). Because no notice of proposed rule making is required, the Regulatory Flexibility Act does not require an initial or final regulatory flexibility analysis. See 5 USC 603 ( a ), 604 ( a ). The Bureau has determined that this Policy Statement does not impose any new or revise any existing record keeping, reporting, or disclosure requirements on covered entities or members of the public that would be collections of information requiring XXXX approval under the Paperwork Reduction Act, XXXX XXXX XXXX.

All furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies must comply with all applicable regulations. Information about applicable regulations currently in effect can be found at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureaus website, www.consumerfinance.gov/learnmore NOTICE TO FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION : OBLIGATIONS OF FURNISHERS UNDER THE FCRA A list of tile sections of tile FCRA cross-referenced to the.U.S Code is at the end of this document.The federal Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C 1681-1681y, imposes responsibilities on all persons who furnish information to consumer reporting agencies ( CRAs ). These responsibilities are found in Section 623 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C 1681s-2. State law may impose additional requirements on furnishers. All furnishers of information to CRAs should become familiar with the applicable laws and may want to consult with their counsel to ensure that they are in compliance. The text of the FCRA is available at the website of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) : www.consumerfinance.gov/learnmore Section 623 imposes the following duties upon furnishers : Accuracy Guidelines results to all CRAs to which the furnisher provided the information that compile and maintain files on a nationwide basis. Section 623 ( a ) ( 4 ).

Duty to Report Dates of Delinquencies If a furnisher reports information concerning a delinquent account placed for collection, charged to profit or loss, or subject to any similar action, the furnisher must, within 90 days after reporting the information, provide the CRA with the month and the year of the commencement of the delinquency that immediately preceded the action, so that the agency will know how long to keep the information in the consumers file. Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ).

Any person, such as a debt collector, that has acquired or is responsible for collecting delinquent accounts and that reports information to CRAs may comply with the requirements of Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( until there is a consumer dispute ) by reporting the slime delinquency date previously reported by the creditor. If the creditor did not report this date, they may comply with the FCRA by establishing reasonable procedures to obtain and report delinquency dates, or, if a delinquency date can not be reasonably obtained, by following reasonable procedures to ensure that the date reported precedes the date when the account was placed for collection charged to profit or loss, or subjected to any similar action. Section Duties of Financial Institutions When Reporting Negative Information Financial institutions that furnish information to \ '' XXXX '' consumer reporting agencies, as defined in Section 603 ( p ), must notify consumers in writing if they may furnish or have furnished negative information to a CRA . The Bureau is therefore issuing this policy statement ( Policy Statement ) to highlight furnishers\ ' responsibilities under the CARES Act and inform consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of the Bureau\ 's flexible supervisory and enforcement approach during this pandemic regarding compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Regulation V. The Bureau intends to consider the circumstances that entities face as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and entities\ ' good faith efforts to comply with their statutory and regulatory obligations as soon as possible. The Bureau believes that this flexibility will help furnishers and consumer reporting agencies to manage the challenges the current crisis poses. It also will enable consumers, as well as lenders, insurers, employers and other consumer report users, to maintain confidence in the consumer reporting system.

Below are examples of the flexibility the Bureau intends to provide in the consumer reporting system.

Furnishing Consumer Information Impacted by COVID-19 : The Bureau reiterates its prior guidance encouraging financial institutions to work constructively with borrowers and other customers affected by COVID-19 to meet their financial needs. While companies generally are not legally obligated to furnish information to consumer reporting agencies, the Bureau encourages them to continue furnishing information despite the current crisis. Furnishers\ ' providing accurate information to consumer reporting agencies produces substantial benefits for consumers, users of consumer reports, and the economy as a whole.

The CARES Act, a section of which amends the FCRA, generally requires furnishers to report as current certain credit obligations for which furnishers make payment accommodations to consumers affected by COVID 19 who have sought such accommodations from their lendersl .The Bureau expects furnishers to comply with the CARES Act and will work with furnishers as needed to help them do so.

Many furnishers are or will be offering consumers affected by COVID-19 various forms of payment flexibility, including allowing consumers to defer or skip payments, as required by the CARES Act or voluntarily. Such payment accommodations will avoid the reporting of delinquencies resulting from the effects of COVID-19. The Bureau supports furnishers\ ' voluntary efforts to provide payment relief, and it does not intend to cite in examinations or take enforcement actions against those who furnish information to consumer reporting agencies that accurately reflects the payment relief measures they are employing.

Disputes : The FCRA generally requires that consumer reporting agencies and furnishers investigate disputes within 30 days of receipt of the consumer\ 's dispute. The 30-day period may be extended to 45 days if the consumer provides additional information that is relevant to the investigation during the 30-day period.

The Bureau is aware that some consumer reporting agencies and furnishers may face significant operational disruptions that pose challenges for them in investigating consumer disputes. . Section 623 ( e ) .The FCRA requires furnishers to comply with federal guidelines and regulations dealing with the accuracy of information provided to CRAs by furnishers. Federal regulations and guidelines are available at www.consumerfinance.gov/learnmore General Prohibition on Reporting Inaccurate Information The FCRA prohibits information furnishers from providing information to a CRA that they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate. However, the furnisher is not subject to this general prohibition if it clearly and conspicuously specifies an address to which consumers may write to notify the furnisher that certain information is inaccurate. Sections Duty to Correct and Update Information If at any time a person who regularly and in the ordinary course of business furnishes information to one or more CRAs determines that the information provided is not complete or accurate, the furnisher must promptly provide complete and accurate information to the CRA. In addition, the furnisher must notify all CRAs that received the information of any corrections, and must thereafter report only the complete and accurate information. Section Duties After Notice of Dispute from Consumer If a consumer notifies a furnisher, at an address specified for the furnisher for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate, and the information is, in fact, inaccurate, the furnisher must thereafter report the correct information to CRAs. Section 623 ( a ) ( I ) ( B ).

If a consumer notifies a furnisher that the consumer disputes the completeness or accuracy of any information reported by the furnisher, the furnisher may not subsequently report that information to a CRA without providing notice of the dispute. Section 623 ( a ) ( 3 ).

623 ( a ) (? Furnishers must comply with federal regulations that identify when an information furnisher must investigate a dispute made directly to the furnisher by a consumer. Under these regulations, furnishers must complete an investigation within 30 days ( or 45 days, if the consumer later provides relevant additional information ) unless the dispute is frivolous or irrelevant or comes from a \ '' credit repair organization.\ '' Section 623 ( a ) (?. Federal regulations are available at www.consumerfinance.gov/learnmore.Section Duties After Notice of Dispute from Consumer Reporting Agency If a CRA notifies a furnisher that a consumer disputes the completeness or accuracy of information provided by the furnisher, the furnisher has a duty to follow certain procedures. The furnisher must : Conduct an investigation and review all relevant information provided by the CRA, including information given to the CRA by the consumer. Sections 623 ( b ) ( I ) ( A ) and Report the results to the CRA that referred the dispute and, if the investigation establishes that the information was in fact, incomplete or inaccurate, report the All furnishers must have in place reasonable procedures to respond to notifications from CRAS that information furnished is the result of identity theft, and to prevent refurnishing the information in the future. A furnisher may not furnish Information that a consumer has identified as resulting from identity theft unless the furnisher subsequently knows or is informed by the consumer that the information is correct. Section 623 ( a ) ( 6 ). If a furnisher learns that it has furnished inaccurate information due to identity theft, it must notify each CRA of the correct information and must thereafter report only complete and accurate information. Section 623 ( a ) ( 2 ). When any furnisher of information is notified pursuant to the procedures set forth in Section 605B that a debt has resulted from identity theft, the furnisher many not sell, transfer, or place for collection the debt except in certain limited circumstances. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, AL XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX Experian XXXX XXXX Assistance XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX To Whom it XXXX Concern : I am writing to address concerns regarding the accuracy and compliance of information on my credit report, as mandated by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681I ) and industry-standard reporting guidelines such as the XXXX XXXX XXXX Points of Compliance. 
It has come to my attention that certain information reported on my credit file XXXX be inaccurate, inconsistent, or unverifiable. Under the FCRA and XXXX XXXX standards, creditors are obligated to provide accurate and complete information to credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) in a timely manner. 
I want to emphasize the importance of adhering to the prescribed reporting requisites and standards. Even if the information reported is factually correct, it must be reported precisely according to the mandated format, such as XXXX XXXX data field formatting. Any deviations from these standards XXXX render the reported information deficient and non-compliant. 
Therefore, I am exercising my rights as a consumer to demand the removal of any inaccuracies and deficiencies from my credit report. I request a thorough investigation into the sources of these accounts to ensure that creditors have fully complied with industry reporting standards, including XXXX XXXX requirements. 
It is crucial to ascertain that all alleged reporting data furnishers can accurately provide my complete file information to all major credit reporting agencies, including XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. 
Furthermore, I want to highlight the significance of the FCRA 's provision regarding the accuracy of consumer reports ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). Consumer reporting agencies are required to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of information contained in consumer reports.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
This complaint addresses serious and egregious violations of federal law committed by XXXX, XXXX, Experian ( the Credit Reporting Agencies or CRAs ), and XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX regarding their mishandling and unlawful reporting of my personal data, privacy breaches, and fraudulent classification of charged-off debts. Their actions not only infringe upon my statutory rights but also cause significant harm to my financial well-being and reputation.

Failure to Honor Opt-Out Rights Under FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802 ) Under 15 U.S.C. 6802, consumers have the right to opt out of the sharing of non-public personal information ( NPI ). I am formally opting out of any prior or assumed authorizationswritten, verbal, implied, or otherwisegranted to the CRAs or XXXX And XXXX XXXX to use or share my data. Despite this clear directive, these entities have willfully disregarded my right to privacy by continuing to disseminate my XXXX without consent. 


XXXX. Violations of the Privacy Act of XXXX The Privacy Act of XXXX mandates that entities handling personal information must notify individuals of its use and provide them with a meaningful opportunity to restrict or control its dissemination. 

Violation : XXXX, XXXX, Experian, along with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX failed to notify me of how my personal information was being shared with third parties and denied me the ability to opt out of these unauthorized disclosures. 
Impact : This lack of transparency infringes upon my fundamental rights to control the use of my personal data.

3. Illegal Reporting of Charged-Off Debts as Income ( 15 U.S.C. 6801 ) Charged-off debts reported to the IRS via a 1099-C are reclassified as income under federal tax law. Income, however, is not permissible for inclusion on a consumer credit report under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). XXXX, XXXX, Experian, and [ Bank Names ] are knowingly violating federal law by falsely reporting charged-off debts as derogatory items instead of removing them as required. 

Violation : The continued reporting of charged-off debts as derogatory trade lines violates 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ), which governs the permissible content of consumer reports. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX the court confirmed that debts reported inaccurately or without proper validation are unlawful under the FCRA. This precedent underscores that creditors and CRAs must remove such items promptly. 
Impact : This misclassification harms my creditworthiness and exposes me to undue financial hardship and damage. 



4.Negligence and Gross Misconduct by Each Bank and CRA Each of the following entities has engaged in illegal reporting and privacy violations : XXXX AND XXXX : Refused to validate a charged-off debt and continued reporting it despite being reclassified as income. 



XXXX, XXXX, and Experian : Complicit in reporting unvalidated, inaccurate, and impermissible information, including charged-off debts and transaction histories without my authorization. 



The actions of XXXX, XXXX, Experian, and XXXX and XXXX XXXX violate the following federal statutes and case law precedents : Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 15 U.S.C. 16811681x. 
Privacy Act of XXXX : Public Law 93-579. 
Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) : 15 U.S.C. 68016809. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) : Addressing unlawful debt reporting practices. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) : Highlighting the illegality of misleading credit reports.

According to 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, not one credit reporting agency shouldn't be reporting any inaccurate information anyways due to neglect use considering that I was in breach. I need help now so I can proceed to buy my family a house.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to declare that I am a victim of identity theft. A fraudulent account was illegally opened in my name without my knowledge or consent. Specifically, I have no recollection of applying for or authorizing the account with XXXX XXXX, and I am unfamiliar with its origin. This unauthorized activity has caused harm to my credit and financial reputation. 

I have taken immediate action by filing a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and I have enclosed my Identity Theft Report as evidence of this crime. Additionally, I have contacted the credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) to request validation of the debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). However, the information I requested has not been provided, which further confirms the lack of legitimacy surrounding this account. 

The fraudulent activity violates my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which ensures the accuracy of information reported to consumer reporting agencies, and the Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act, which makes the unauthorized use of my personal information a federal crime. 

I am requesting the immediate investigation and removal of this account from my records and credit reports to prevent further harm. Identity theft has impacted my ability to secure credit and maintain my financial well-being. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and your cooperation in helping me resolve this issue. Please contact me if you require additional documentation or information. 

Please find attached a copy of my id, a copy of my social security card, a copy of my most recent utility bill, a copy of the FTC complaint, and a copy of the validation of dept letter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX dispute This complaint is in regard to the account related to XXXX XXXX XXXX that is being reported to XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX needs prior consent from either the court or the consumer before communication with the collection of any debt to a credit reporting agency. 
Notice, it is a fact, I the consumer did not give prior consent to communication to the debt collector, { XXXX XXXX XXXX } and the consumer alleges there was no prior consent from a court giving permission to contact I, the consumer in collection of any debts owed to XXXX XXXX XXXX and thus this communication by XXXX XXXX XXXX is a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692c ( a ) without a court order brought forth. I did not consent to XXXX XXXX XXXX communicating with me any obligations to pay a debt through any mediums which includes communication with the credit reporting agencies to report the alleged debt. Furthermore 15 U.S.Code 1692a ( 6 ) 1692a ( 6 ) - a debt collector is defined as anyone in the business of collecting a debt. Therefore by definition XXXX XXXX XXXX is debt collector. 

Notice, it is a fact, that, I, agent for principal ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) am aware that XXXX XXXX XXXX is a debt collector by the legal definition. Pursuant to 15 U.S.Code 1692 ( a ) ( 6 ), a debt collector is any person who uses instrumentality of interstate commerce, such as the mails, in any business which the principal purpose is the collection of any debts, or who regularly collects or attempts to collect, directly or indirectly, debts owed or due or asserted to be owed or due another Furthermore this law U.S.Code 1692d states A Debt collector may not engage in any conduct ( no restriction ) which will harass, oppress or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Oppressing a right would be conduct not allowed from 1692d. Credit is the right granted and protected by federal law. If any debt collection caused a denial of credit this allows for damages. I have been denied credit on multiple occasions and denied housing because of this negative account on XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report. This is an actual damage as this tremendously harmed my ability to operate in commerce and purchase household goods and shelter for I the consumer and my family. 

Notice, it is a fact, I the affiant is aware, credit is a right granted to me as a creditor under the Truth in Lending Act and { XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX } does not have the right to oppress or abuse any part of my character which would restrict or prohibit my right to extend credit. XXXX XXXX XXXX has oppressed my right to extend credit which is a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692d.

Furthermore this law 15 U.S.Code 1692e ( 8 ) states the actions performed by XXXX XXXX XXXX was illegal- Communicating with any person false credit information including failure to communicate the debt is being disputed has not been verified. As well as there being no contract that exists bewteen the I the consumer and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX says I the consumer would pay XXXX XXXX XXXX the alleged debt this was false and misleading reporting. 

Notice, it is a fact, affiant is aware and has proof in this complaint of false and inaccurate credit information reported and it is a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692e ( 8 ). XXXX XXXX XXXX reported a debt collections account to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX report. I the affiant have disputed this debt this information can not keep reporting while the dispute is still not resolved as well as failing to communicate with the credit reporting agencies that the debt is being disputed and has not been verified by I, the consumer. Consumer complaint narrative:
Credit Report Dispute In a recent submission, I inadvertently attached incorrect documents to my dispute filings. I apologize for this oversight and wish to clarify that the issues and accounts I am disputing remain unchanged. I am submitting this revised dispute to provide the correct documentation for your review. 

Investigation of Inaccurate Credit Report Items is in Violation Under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) ( b ) Accuracy of report To Whom It May Concern, I recently conducted a review of my credit report and found several items that have caused me significant distress. These items appear to be unverifiable, inaccurate, and questionable. Your agency has failed to ensure the accuracy of the information as required under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of Reports. This statute mandates that consumer reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information they report. 

Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of Inaccurate or Unverifiable Information, you are required to promptly delete or modify any information found to be inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable during a reinvestigation. If you are unable to provide me with verifiable proof of the accuracy of the disputed items within 15 days of your investigation, these accounts and the related information must be removed from my credit report. 

Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I do not recognize any of the alleged creditors or debt collectors. I have never entered into a valid contract with any of these entities, nor have I engaged in any transactions with them. As such, these accounts are fraudulent and may be the result of identity theft or other illegal activities. Attempting to enforce these fraudulent accounts is unlawful. I request that you expedite your investigation to prevent further harm, losses, or damages that I may suffer as a victim of identity theft. 

Moreover, under the Fair Credit Billing Act, my right to privacy has been violated, and this breach infringes upon my rights as outlined in The Privacy Act of 1974. Removing the inaccurate and fraudulent information from my credit report will help restore my privacy and prevent further violations.

Consumer complaint narrative:
EXPERIAN XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, TX XXXX To Whom It May Concern, Going over my credit report, I have found it has many errors. It has come to my attention that you are reporting what I believe to be inaccurate data, which I dispute, and this letter is an appeal for your assistance. As a national reporting agency, you are governed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( " FCRA '' ), which protects consumers from inaccurate, outdated, or invalidated information reporting of their credit file. The FCRA states that it's the Credit Bureau 's responsibility to ensure that all information contained within consumer credit files is accurate and free from errors.

According to federal law, you are required to comply with the requirements imposed under the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., including but not limited to : follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information in the consumer report, as required by 15 U.S.C. $ 1681e ( b ) ; 2 ) comply with the investigation requirements ; 3 ) should not provide consumer credit file to companies without determining that these companies had a permissible purpose to obtain consumer credit file pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681b ; 4 ) provide consumer credit file pursuant to 15 U.S.C. $ 1681g ; 5 ) et seq.

Accordingly, I request your company to provide verifiable documentary proof ( e.g., original consumer contract or similar proof bearing my wet ink signature on it ) you have on file of accounts/items listed below. Under the FCRA, if you do not provide documented and verifiable proof, you must remove all unverified, invalid, derogatory information from my consumer disclosure report. For your convenience, I am sending you a list of the items you need to verify them. These listed accounts are neither my debts nor my authorized inquiries. Please correct this by the removal of these items from my credit report. See. Exhibit A. Upon completion of your investigation, please send a detailed description of the procedures used to determine the accuracy of the account ( s ) I am disputing, as well as the name and contact information of the agent conducting the said investigation in case further communication is necessary. I know that your company will need some sort of verification to prove my identity. My information is clearly shown below : Accounts that need to be removed XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  {$1600.00} XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX {$2200.00} - XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

15 USC 1681b ( c ) - Furnishing reports in connection with credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer : ( 3 ) Information regarding inquiries : Except as provided in section 1681g ( a ) ( 5 ) of this title, a consumer reporting agency shall not furnish to any person a record of inquiries in connection with a credit or insurance transaction that is not initiated by a consumer. 
The following inquiries, which are a result of identity theft and were not initiated by me, must be deleted immediately : XXXX : XXXX XX/XX/XXXX My identity has been stolen, and I am placing you on formal notice. 
Aggravated Identity Theft pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1028A : ( 1 ) In general : Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 2 years. 
15 USC 1681b - Permissible purposes of consumer reports : ( a ) IN GENERAL : Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report only under the following circumstances : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates.

15 USC 1681- Fair Credit Reporting Act : ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reports : ( 4 ) There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 
List of Fraudulent Accounts : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Pursuant to 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 - Block of information resulting from identity theft : A consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information resulting from alleged identity theft, not later than XXXX business days after the date of receipt by such agency of : ( XXXX ) Appropriate proof of the identity of the consumer ; ( XXXX ) A copy of an identity theft report ; ( XXXX ) The identification of such information by the consumer ; and ( XXXX ) A statement by the consumer that the information is not related to any transaction by the consumer. 
Enclosed are all relevant documents pursuant to the above section of the law. I demand that all the aforementioned fraudulent accounts be deleted immediately. Additionally, I demand an updated copy of my consumer file reflecting these changes, as stated by 15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports.

15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports : In any case in which a consumer reporting agency includes a fraud alert in the file of a consumer pursuant to this subsection, the consumer reporting agency shall : ( A ) Disclose to the consumer that they may request a free copy of their file pursuant to section 1681j ( d ) of this title. 
Be advised that I will CC : The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection ( CFPB ) The Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Attorney General 's Office in your state and mine Thank you, XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Copy of ID Utility bill showing proof of address Copy of Social Security Card FTC Identity Theft Report

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information on my credit report regarding an account reported by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate, complete, and verifiable reporting. Below are the specific issues with this account : 1. Late Payments Reported on a Closed, Paid Account : Despite the account being marked as Closed with a {$0.00} balance and Current payment status, the payment history includes multiple 30-day late marks. If the account is paid and closed, late payments should not persist unless accurate and verifiable. 
2. Inconsistent Comments Across Bureaus : XXXX : Closed. 
Experian : Subscriber reports dispute resolved - consumer disagrees. 
XXXX : Closed or paid account/zero balance XXXX. 
These comments are inconsistent and may mislead lenders about the resolution of disputes. 
XXXX. Failure to Properly Update or Resolve Disputes : Dispute-related comments remain on the account, even though it has been resolved and paid. This suggests a failure to update the status, violating the FCRAs accuracy standards. 
4. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : Minor discrepancies in dates, such as the Date Last Active and Last Reported dates, differ slightly among the bureaus. While this might seem minor, it reflects a lack of synchronization.

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit bureaus are required to ensure the information they report is accurate and consistent. The inconsistencies in comments, late payments, and reporting dates violate this requirement. 
2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If disputes have been filed and inaccuracies persist, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate and correct the errors properly. 
3. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor ( XXXX XXXX ) may have furnished inaccurate or misleading information regarding payment history and dispute resolution. 
4. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : If the late payments are outdated or unverifiable, they should not appear on the report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX  XXXX bankruptcy : Bankruptcy - Reference Number - XXXX Subject : Dispute of Bankruptcy Reporting Under the FCRA To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to dispute the inaccurate reporting of a bankruptcy on my credit report. Upon confirmation with the bankruptcy court, I have verified that the court does not report credit information to any credit reporting agencies, including XXXX, XXXX, and Experian. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 USC 1681e ( b ), credit reporting agencies are required to maintain reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information contained in consumer reports. Reporting a bankruptcy as originating from the court without direct verification from the source violates this requirement.

Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681i, I have the right to dispute any inaccurate or unverifiable information on my credit report. Since the bankruptcy court does not furnish such information to credit reporting agencies, its inclusion on my credit report is unsubstantiated and must be removed.

Actions Requested : Conduct an Investigation : Investigate the source of the bankruptcy information reported on my credit report. If the reporting can not be verified directly by the source ( the bankruptcy court ), it must be removed.

Provide Written Confirmation : Notify me in writing of the results of your investigation and provide an updated copy of my credit report reflecting the removal of the inaccurate bankruptcy entry.

Ensure Compliance : Verify that all procedures are in compliance with the FCRA to prevent similar inaccuracies in the future.

Enclosed are supporting documents, including confirmation from the bankruptcy court that they do not furnish credit reporting data, and a copy of my credit report highlighting the disputed bankruptcy entry.

I expect a response within the 30 days required under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ). Failure to comply with these legal obligations will leave me no choice but to report this matter to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and my state Attorney Generals office.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Credit Reporting and Request for 1099-C Documentation To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to dispute the accuracy of an account listed on my credit report. This letter is being sent under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 USC 1681s-2, which requires that furnishers of credit information report only accurate and verifiable information. 

The account in question is as follows : 1. Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Date Listed : XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX. Account Name : XXXX XXXX Date Listed : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX. Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX  Date Listed : XX/XX/XXXX This account is reporting a balance despite the fact that such reporting may violate consumer law and IRS regulations concerning the discharge of indebtedness. 

According to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, the issuance of a 1099-C form is evidence of an identifiable event of debt cancellation under IRS regulations . Specifically, Identifiable Event Code 7 states that a discharge of indebtedness occurs due to a decision by the creditor to discontinue collection activity and cancel the debt as part of a defined policy. 

If a 1099-C form has been issued for this account, it signifies that the debt has been canceled. Reporting a balance for a canceled debt is not only inaccurate but also misleading under the FCRA. This inaccurate reporting is damaging my credit and must be addressed immediately. 

Demands : Verification of the Account Balance : Provide evidence showing that the balance being reported is accurate and collectible. 

Provision of the 1099-C Form : If a 1099-C form has been issued for this debt, provide a copy of the document as proof of the identifiable event. 

Immediate Deletion of the Account : If the debt has been discharged under Identifiable Event Code 7 or can not be verified, this negative information must be promptly deleted from my credit report to comply with the FCRA. 

Under the FCRA, I expect your investigation to be conducted within 30 days of receipt of this letter. If you are unable to verify the accuracy of the information or provide the requested documentation, you are required to remove this account from my credit report. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your resolution and a written confirmation of the results. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX, XXXX, and Experian are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' XXXX XXXX is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' XXXX XXXX the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX, XXXX, and Experian do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, XXXX, and Experian, XXXX XXXX whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' XXXX XXXX Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX, XXXX, and Experian are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute several unauthorized hard inquiries appearing on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), credit inquiries XXXX only be made with my explicit consent or when otherwise permitted by law. I have reviewed my credit report and found the following inquiries that I did not authorize. picture have been unloaded Under Section 604 of the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), a consumer reporting agency XXXX only provide a credit report for permissible purposes, such as a legitimate credit transaction that the consumer initiated. These inquiries were not authorized by me, and I am requesting their immediate removal as they violate this provision. 

XXXX. Section 607 ( b ) : Maximum Possible Accuracy Credit bureaus must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information included in a consumer report. This applies to all types of data, including inquiries.

2. Section 611 : Dispute Process Consumers have the right to dispute any inaccurate or incomplete information in their credit report, including unauthorized or incorrect credit inquiries. Credit bureaus must investigate disputes within 30 days and delete or correct any unverifiable or inaccurate information.

3. Section 604 : Permissible Purpose Inquiries must have a legitimate purpose and be authorized by the consumer or permissible under the law ( e.g., for a credit application, insurance underwriting, or employment ). If inquiries appear on your credit report without authorization, they violate this section. 
XXXX. Section 609 : Disclosure to Consumers Credit bureaus must provide consumers with a list of all entities that accessed their credit file, including inquiries. Consumers can request details on why their credit report was accessed and by whom.

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Sub-issue: Debt was result of identity theft
Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Complaint Regarding Fraudulent Account, FCRA Violations, and Unauthorized Legal Actions by XXXX XXXX  To Whom It May Concern at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against XXXX XXXX  concerning a fraudulent account opened in my name, improper reporting practices, violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), and unauthorized legal actions taken against me. 

Background and Timeline of Events : 1. Initial Identity Theft Incident ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : - While attempting to purchase a vehicle, I noticed a significant drop in my credit score. 
- Upon reviewing my credit reports, I discovered several unauthorized accounts opened without my knowledge or consent. 
- I promptly filed an identity theft report with the XXXX Police Department ( Report Number : XXXX ) and submitted a detailed complaint to the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ). 

2. Implementation of Fraud Alerts ( XXXX ) : - To protect my credit, I requested and successfully placed a 7-year fraud alert with all three major credit bureaus : XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. 
- These alerts were intended to prevent any new unauthorized accounts from being opened in my name without stringent verification processes. 

3. Unauthorized XXXX XXXX  Account ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : - Despite the active fraud alerts, a fraudulent account was opened with XXXX XXXX  under my name, accruing unauthorized charges totaling {$7400.00}. 
- XXXX XXXX  records indicate acknowledgment of this account being fraudulent, yet no effective measures were taken to resolve the issue on their end. 

4. Improper Charge-Off Reporting : - My Experian credit report shows that XXXX XXXX  charged off the fraudulent account. 
- According to IRS guidelines, a creditor who charges off a debt is required to issue a Form 1099-C ( Cancellation of Debt ) to the debtor. I have never received such a form from XXXX XXXX. 
- Furthermore, XXXX XXXX continues to report this charged-off account negatively on my credit reports, which is adversely affecting my credit score and financial reputation. 

5. Unauthorized Collection and Legal Actions : - Contrary to the acknowledgment of the fraudulent nature of the account, XXXX XXXX  initiated collection efforts against me. 
- A lawsuit was filed in an attempt to collect the alleged debt, resulting in a default judgment due to my unawareness of the legal proceedings. 
- These actions have caused significant stress, financial strain, and have unjustly held me responsible for a debt I did not incur. 

Violations Noted : - Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Violations : - Failure to accurately report information and correct known errors in my credit file. 
- Continued reporting of a fraudulent account despite evidence and acknowledgment of identity theft. 
- Negligence in conducting a reasonable investigation upon notification of the dispute. 

- IRS Reporting Violations : - Failure to issue a Form 1099-C upon charging off the alleged debt, as required by IRS regulations . 

Impact on Me : - Financial Hardship : - Denial of credit opportunities and higher interest rates due to damaged credit. 
- Unwarranted legal fees and costs associated with defending myself against the wrongful lawsuit. 

- Emotional Distress : - Significant stress and XXXX  resulting from continuous collection attempts and legal actions for a debt I did not incur. 

- Reputational Damage : - Harm to my credit reputation, which affects both personal and professional opportunities. 

Steps I Have Taken to Resolve the Issue : - Provided copies of the police report and FTC identity theft report to XXXX XXXX. 
- Notified XXXX XXXX  of the fraud alerts placed on my credit files. 
- Disputed the fraudulent account with all three credit bureaus, attaching all supporting documentation. 
- Attempted to communicate with XXXX XXXX  's fraud department to resolve the issue amicably. 


Conclusion : The actions of XXXX XXXX have caused undue hardship and are in direct violation of federal laws designed to protect consumers. I kindly request the CFPB 's assistance in resolving this matter promptly to prevent further damage to my financial well-being. 

Attachments : - Copy of the XXXX Police Department Identity Theft Report. 
- FTC Identity Theft Affidavit. 
- Correspondence with XXXX XXXX  acknowledging the fraudulent account. 
- Copies of credit reports showing the erroneous entries and charge-off. 

Thank you for your time and consideration. I am available to provide any additional information or documentation required to facilitate this investigation. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

I dispute these claims and demand that any negative information be removed from the reports immediately. The claims that this information in my report is negative, untrue, incorrect, incomplete, untimely, and not verifiable are unsubstantiated. I have yet to be provided physical verifiable proof that the claims of negativity within my report are true. After reviewing my report, there are several deviations from mandatory reporting standards therefore the data in my report can not be accurate and complete! With that said, I refute your allegations and challenge you to provide proof that you have the right to report this incomplete negative information about me. Document that you have complied with the reporting requirements, and report without any deviations. If you have not complied with the requirements or there are any negative aspects below that have been challenged, you must remove them from my report. Per 15 U.S.C 1681e, 15U.S. code 1666b Timing of payments.

Whenever a consume reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. According to 12 CFR Part 1022 ( Regulation V ) requires furnishers to : Furnish information concerning accounts or other relationships with a consumer that has integrity. Furnish information about accounts or other relationships with a consumer that is accurate. 
C - Conduct reasonable investigations of consumer disputes According to CRRG, in order to make a lawful report, you must follow the Metro 2 compliance standards.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Name : [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] Address : [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX MI ] Phone Number : [ XXXX ] Email Address : [ XXXX ] Company Name ( XXXX, XXXX, Experian ) : Company Name : [ XXXX ] Account Number : [ Credit Acceptance ] Date of Incident : [ Different dates not accurate ] Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Credit Reporting and Violation of Consumer Rights Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Details of Complaint : Dear CFPB, I am submitting a complaint against [ Credit Reporting Agency or Creditor Name ] for violating several provisions under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ).

Specifically, I believe the following violations have occurred regarding my credit report : Inaccurate Reporting of Account Status - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) The reporting of my account status across different credit reporting agencies is inconsistent and inaccurate. For example, [ Name of Credit Reporting Agency ] lists the account as [ describe the status, such as " Voluntary Repossession '' or " Foreclosure '' ], while other agencies, such as [ list other agencies ], report different statuses, including [ list conflicting status reports ]. 
This inconsistency has led to confusion regarding the actual status of my account and has negatively impacted my credit score.

Failure to Report Accurate Payment History - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) The payment history reported on my credit report is inaccurate. [ Name of Credit Reporting Agency ] reports months as " FC '' ( Foreclosure ) when the account was not in foreclosure during those months. This is incorrect, and the payment history is inconsistent with my actual payments. 
I request an immediate correction of this reporting, as it violates the FCRA 's requirement for maximum accuracy. 
Failure to Update the Balance After Repossession or Voluntary Surrender - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 2 ) ) My credit report continues to show an inaccurate balance of [ {$4700.00} ] after a repossession or voluntary surrender. I believe the balance should reflect the current status after the vehicle was sold, and any remaining deficiency balance should be accurately reported. 
Failure to update this information is a violation of the FCRA, which requires creditors to report accurate information regarding the balance of the account. 
Failure to Investigate Disputed Information - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ) I have disputed the inaccurate information in my credit report with [ XXXX, XXXX, experian ] on [ XX/XX/2024 ], but no investigation or resolution has occurred. Under the FCRA, the agency is required to investigate and correct any inaccuracies within a timely manner. This failure to respond is a violation of my rights under the FCRA. 
Inadequate Debt Validation Information - Violation of FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) I have not received the proper validation of the debt from the creditor or collection agency. I have requested specific details regarding the balance, payment history, and original contract, but have not received a satisfactory response. 
Under the FDCPA, I am entitled to request and receive debt validation within 30 days of receiving a collection notice, which has not occurred. 
I expect a response to this complaint within [ 30 days ], in accordance with the regulations under the FCRA and FDCPA. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] [ XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, MI ] [ XXXX ]

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX, Tn XXXX Experian XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX Subject : Request for Verification and Copy of 1099-C for Charged-Off Account Dear Experian, I am writing to formally dispute the reporting of a charge-off account listed on my credit report. The account information is as follows : Creditor Name : XXXXXXXX XXXX Account XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/year> I request that you verify this debt in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and provide me with all supporting documentation, including a copy of IRS Form 1099-C, if applicable. If the debt has been forgiven or written off by the creditor, as indicated by the charge-off status, the creditor is required to issue a 1099-C for the amount canceled. 

Please note that failure to verify or provide the requested documentation within 30 days may result in my request to have this item removed from my credit report. 

I have attached a copy of my drivers license/state ID to verify my identity. Additionally, I have enclosed a copy of my credit report highlighting the disputed account.
