Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this formal complaint regarding the unlawful and improper practices of XXXX, XXXX, and Experian ( collectively referred to as the " Credit Reporting Agencies '' or " CRAs '' ) related to the illegal reporting of my transaction history. Below, I detail the specific issues and violations of federal law : I am formally opting out of any and all authorizations I may have givenwhether written, verbal, unwritten, or impliedfor the CRAs to share reporting of my transaction history Under 15 U.S.C. 6801, financial institutions and their agents are bound by an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy and confidentiality of consumers ' non-public personal information. Reporting transaction history without explicit consent violates this statute. 

Violation : XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX have engaged in the unauthorized reporting of my transaction history, which is illegal without my consent. 

Impact : This unauthorized action directly undermines the Congressional mandate for safeguarding consumer privacy, as outlined in the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act and its supporting provisions under the FCRA Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 15 U.S.C. 6801 Unlawful Reporting of Charged-Off Debt as Income Under federal law, charged-off debts are considered income for tax purposes when reported to the IRS via a 1099-C form. However, income is not a permissible category for reporting on consumer credit reports under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The FCRA and related case law establish that consumer credit reports must only contain accurate and permissible information directly related to creditworthiness, not income classifications. 

Violation : XXXX, XXXX, and Experian are unlawfully reporting charged-off debts as derogatory trade lines on my credit report despite their reclassification as " income '' under IRS regulations XXXX This constitutes a clear violation of the FCRA because income, especially income derived from forgiven debt, is not authorized for inclusion in consumer credit reporting. 

Supporting Legal Precedents : XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( a ) : Restricts the type of information that can appear on a consumer report. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  : Emphasized that misleading information on credit reports can violate the FCRA. 
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  : Highlighted the importance of accurate classification of debt in credit reporting. 
Impact : The misreporting of charged-off debt as a derogatory item when it should be classified as income causes severe harm to my credit profile and undermines my creditworthiness. Additionally, it subjects me to undue financial and reputational harm by inaccurately portraying my financial behavior.

Consumer complaint narrative:
The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. 
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX Bankruptcy Ref : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX has violated my rights. 

I looked at my Experian credit report on XX/XX/year> and noticed some things are incomplete and not accurate. And according to the fair credit reporting act Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ). And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer. and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are suppose to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Name : XXXX XXXX Email : XXXX Phone : XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/2023 Original Balance : {$7200.00} Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX CA XXXX XXXX : Request for 1099-C Form for Charged-Off Debt Dear, CFPB This letter serves as my **fifth request** for the deletion and removal of a charged-off account with Excite Alliance. Despite four prior attempts to obtain a **1099-C form** related to the cancellation of the debt associated with this account, I have yet to receive any response or acknowledgment from your office. This lack of action is a direct violation of both my rights under federal tax law and consumer protection laws related to credit reporting. As stipulated by Internal Revenue Code ( IRC ) 6050P, XXXX XXXX is legally required to issue a 1099-C form when a debt of {$600.00} or more is canceled. The failure to issue this form constitutes a violation of federal law, as you are obligated to report cancelled debts to both the IRS and the consumer. This issue has gone unresolved for far too long. To also add, this account has multiple inaccuracies thats reporting false information across all 3 bureaus. Furthermore, under the **Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 1681**, all information reported to credit bureaus must be accurate and complete. The ongoing reporting of this charged-off account is not only incorrect but also misleading. As per the FCRA, if an account is charged off or forgiven, and if the debt is cancelled, the report must reflect this cancellation, and the account should be removed from my credit report or marked as paid or settled with a zero balance. The continued reporting of this account as an open, charged-off balance, without issuing the required 1099-C, is an inaccurate representation of my financial obligations and violates my rights under the FCRA. As a consumer, I am entitled to accurate reporting and full transparency regarding any debt that has been forgiven or settled. By failing to issue a **1099-C form** and continuing to report a charged-off account, Excite Alliance is infringing upon my rights under the **Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) **, which protects consumers from misleading and unfair practices by debt collectors and creditors. I request the immediate removal of this charged-off account from my credit report and the deletion of all associated negative entries that do not reflect the true status of the debt. This includes removing any record of the account that reflects it as charged off or in default if the debt has been forgiven or settled. Please delete and remove all this account. 

Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/2023 Original Balance : {$7200.00} If this matter is not resolved within 15 days, I will be forced to pursue further action, which may include : 1. Filing a formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) for failure to comply with **credit reporting laws 2. Reporting this noncompliance to the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and the Internal Revenue Service ( IRS ) for failure to issue the required **1099-C form.

3. Seeking legal recourse for any violations under the Fair Credit Reporting Act and other applicable laws. 

Attached will also be the previous letters send out to this creditor. I expect written confirmation of these actions within 15 days from the date of this letter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding a violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) by Experian and XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  ). My repeated disputes about the accuracy and verifiability of a charge-off account reported on my Experian credit report have not been resolved, and neither party has provided sufficient evidence or documentation to validate the information. 

Details of the Disputed Account Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Reported Status : Charge-Off Open Date : XX/XX/year> Current Status : {$0.00} Balance Summary of the Issue Failure to Provide Verification I first disputed this account with Experian and Upstart because the reported information is inaccurate and unverifiable. 

Despite my repeated written requests, XXXX has failed to provide any substantial proof or documentation to verify the account 's accuracy. 
Violation of the FCRA Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) are required to investigate disputes within 30 days. The information must be deleted from the consumers credit report if it can not be verified.

As per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), any information that can not be verified must be promptly deleted. XXXX has not provided verifiable proof of this account, rendering it unverifiable and requiring its removal. 

Experian has failed to fulfill its obligation to delete the inaccurate information, and XXXX has failed to provide the necessary documentation to validate the account. 

I have attached the following documents to support my complaint : Copies of my dispute letters to Experian and XXXX. 

Notes from my correspondence regarding the lack of response and verifiability. 
A copy of my credit report showing the inaccurate charge-off for account XXXX. 

I believe my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681i, have been violated. Experian has failed to fulfill its legal obligations to : Investigate my dispute within the required 30-day period. 

Obtain verification of the disputed charge-off account from the data furnisher ( XXXX ). 
Delete the charge-off account from my credit report when it was determined that the data furnisher could not verify the accuracy of the account. 

As per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), any information that can not be verified must be promptly deleted from my credit report. XXXX has not provided verifiable proof of this account, demonstrating that it is unverifiable and must be removed from my credit report immediately. 

In light of the failure of both Experian and XXXX to provide verifiable proof of the disputed account, I respectfully request that the CFPB : Investigate this matter thoroughly and ensure compliance with federal laws governing credit reporting and debt validation. 

Direct Experian to immediately delete the disputed charge-off account ( XXXX ) from my credit report due to its inaccurate and unverifiable nature. 

Enforce any applicable penalties against XXXX and/or Experian for their failure to comply with the FCRA. 

This situation has caused undue stress and damaged my credit score and financial well-being. I trust the CFPB will take appropriate action to resolve this matter. Should you require any further information or documentation, I am happy to provide it. Don't hesitate to get in touch with me at XXXX or XXXX. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am formally disputing inaccuracies on my credit report concerning an account reported by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to accurate, complete, and verifiable credit reporting. I have identified the following issues : XXXX. Inconsistent Account Details Across Credit Bureaus : Account Type Detail : XXXX and Experian report Auto Loan. 
XXXX reports Recreational merchandise, which is inconsistent with the other bureaus. 
No. of Months ( Terms ) : XXXX reports 85 months. 
Experian reports 72 months. 
XXXX reports 0 months. These discrepancies may lead to confusion for lenders reviewing the report. 
XXXX. Improper Reporting of Account Status : XXXX shows a last reported date of XX/XX/XXXX, while XXXX and Experian both show XX/XX/XXXXXXXX Such inconsistencies indicate a lack of synchronization and proper updates across bureaus. 
XXXX. Contradictory Payment History : All bureaus list the account as Closed or Paid with a {$0.00} balance, yet the payment history includes several 30-day late marks. If the account is resolved and paid in full, late payments should no longer appear unless they were valid and verified. 
XXXX. XXXX  Misleading Comments : XXXX adds Closed or paid account/XXXX  balance alongside Recreational merchandise, which differs from the comments on XXXX ( Closed ) and Experian ( blank ). This inconsistency could mislead creditors. 
XXXX. Failure to Update or Resolve Disputes : If disputes were filed previously and no corrections were made, this may indicate improper investigation and resolution by the credit reporting agencies.

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must maintain accurate and consistent reporting. The discrepancies in account type, terms, and status violate this requirement. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If disputes were submitted and the inaccuracies remain unresolved, this reflects a failure to investigate properly. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The furnisher ( XXXX  XXXX  ) may be reporting inconsistent or incorrect details, violating the requirement to provide accurate information. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Late payments may be improperly retained, especially if they occurred more than seven years ago or are unverifiable.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I dispute the validity of this debt and have reason to believe that the reported information does not accurately reflect the situation. Under 15 U.S.C. 1692c, I am exercising my rights to ensure that I am not subjected to any unfair practices related to debt collection.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Correction to Previous Experian Dispute Request of Inaccurate and Unauthorized Information. New Request to Include The Removal of Late Payments and Inquiries. 

I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate and unauthorized information appearing on my Experian credit report. These accounts were added due to a data breach and are not authorized or representative of my financial history. I request immediate investigation and removal of the following accounts from my credit report : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX request corrections for the following accounts due to inaccurate reporting of late payments. These accounts should not be closed, but the late payment entries must be removed : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Pursuant to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I assert the following rights and request specific actions to address this issue : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( FCRA 611 ) : I request that the disputed information be investigated and verified as accurate. If the disputed accounts can not be verified, they must be deleted from my credit report.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ( FCRA 607 ) : Experian is obligated to ensure maximum possible accuracy in reporting my credit information. These accounts are inaccurate and result from identity theft or misreporting tied to the referenced data breach. 

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ( FCRA 605A ( b ) ) : I request that these fraudulent items be removed as they stem from a breach of my personal data.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681g ( FCRA 609 ) : I request access to all documentation, records, and communications related to the inclusion of these accounts on my credit report.

Given the widespread data breaches that have affected financial institutions and compromised consumers ' sensitive information, I believe these accounts may have been fraudulently opened or erroneously reported. I demand that these accounts be thoroughly investigated in compliance with FCRA requirements and deleted from my credit report if found unverifiable or inaccurate. 

Additionally, under the Federal Trade Commission Act ( 15 U.S.C. 45 ), it is illegal for businesses to engage in unfair or deceptive practices. Reporting inaccurate or fraudulent accounts on my credit report due to negligence in protecting consumer data constitutes a violation of this statute.

I have attached all relevant documents to support this dispute, including copies of my Experian credit report highlighting the disputed accounts.

Consumer complaint narrative: Subject : Dispute of Unauthorized Inquiries on My Credit Report Dear Sir/Madam : I am writing to dispute certain inquiries on my credit report that I believe to be unauthorized and therefore incorrect. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to have only accurate, verified, and authorized information on my credit report. I am requesting the removal of these inquiries from my report as I did not explicitly authorize any of them. Details of the Disputed Inquiries : Requesting Entities : XXXX Inquiry Dates : XXXX XXXX Requesting Entities XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Inquiry Dates : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXX XXXX Inquiry Dates : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXX Inquiry Dates : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXXXXXX XXXX Inquiry Dates : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXXXXXX XXXX  Inquiry Dates : XXXX XXXX Legal Basis under the FCRA for Removal of Unauthorized Inquiries : 1. Right to Accuracy and Verification of Information ( FCRA 611 ) : Under section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of the FCRA, I have the right to dispute any information that is inaccurate or unverified. I am requesting that you review and verify the legitimacy of these inquiries, and if you can not do so, immediately remove these entries from my credit report. 2. Obligation to Provide Proof of Authorization ( FCRA 609 ) : According to section 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) of the FCRA, I have the right to obtain all information in my file that is relevant to the inquiries conducted, including any evidence that I explicitly consented. I request that you provide this proof of authorization ; in the absence of it, these inquiries should be removed accordingly. 3. Protection Against Identity Theft and Fraud ( FCRA 605B ) : In the event that any of these inquiries are related to identity theft, section 605B of the FCRA requires you to block all information derived from such fraud upon notification. This letter serves as formal notice that none of these inquiries were authorized by me and could potentially be the result of fraud. Furthermore, I want to emphasize that, in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I do not authorize this dispute to be processed using the e-OSCAR automated system. Since this dispute concerns unauthorized information, it requires a complete manual review to ensure compliance with my rights to verification and accuracy of information. Thank you for your attention to this request. I look forward to receiving a written response within 15 days, as stipulated by the FCRA. Please keep me informed of any progress in the investigation process. Sincerely,

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding a violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) by Experian and XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  ). My repeated disputes about the accuracy and verifiability of a charge-off account reported on my Experian credit report have not been resolved, and neither party has provided sufficient evidence or documentation to validate the information. 

Details of the Disputed Account Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Account Number : XXXX Reported Status : Charge-Off Open Date : XX/XX/XXXX Current Status : {$0.00} Balance ( Transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX ) Summary of the Issue Failure to Provide Verification I first disputed this account with Experian and XXXX because the reported information is inaccurate and unverifiable. 

Despite my repeated written requests, XXXX has failed to provide any substantial proof or documentation to verify the accuracy of the account. Instead, I received an email response on XX/XX/XXXX, stating that no investigation was necessary because XXXX was no longer servicing the loan at the time of the dispute. 
Account Transferred to XXXX XXXX, XXXX In XXXX response, they claimed the account had been transferred to XXXX XXXX, XXXX, as of XX/XX/XXXX. 

However, when I contacted XXXX XXXX XXXX, they informed me that they have no record of the account and are not authorized to collect in Virginia, where I reside. 

Violation of the FCRA Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) are required to investigate disputes within 30 days. If the information can not be verified, it must be deleted from the consumers credit report.

As per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), any information that can not be verified must be promptly deleted. XXXX has confirmed it no longer services this loan, and XXXX XXXX, XXXX has stated they have no record. Thus, the charge-off is unverifiable and must be removed. 

Experian has failed to fulfill its obligation to delete the inaccurate information, and both XXXX and XXXX XXXX have failed to provide the necessary documentation to validate the account. 

I have attached the following documents to support my complaint : Copies of my dispute letters to Experian and XXXX. 
The email response from XXXX, dated XX/XX/XXXX. 
Notes from my conversation with XXXX XXXX, XXXX, confirm they have no record of the account and are not allowed to collect in Virginia. 
A copy of my credit report showing the inaccurate charge-off. 

I believe my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681i, have been violated. Experian has failed to fulfill its legal obligations to : Investigate my dispute within the required 30-day period. 

Obtain verification of the disputed charge-off account from the data furnisher ( XXXX ). 
Delete the charge-off account from my credit report when it was determined that the data furnisher could not verify the accuracy of the account. 

As per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), any information that can not be verified must be promptly deleted from my credit report. XXXX has confirmed that it was no longer servicing the loan at the time of my dispute, and XXXX XXXX, XXXX has stated they have no record of the account. This demonstrates the account is unverifiable and must be removed from my credit report immediately. 

In light of the failure of both Experian and XXXX to provide verifiable proof of the disputed account, and given XXXX XXXX  confirmation that they have no record of the account, I respectfully request that the CFPB : Investigate this matter thoroughly and ensure compliance with federal laws governing credit reporting and debt validation. 

Direct Experian to immediately delete the disputed charge-off account from my credit report due to its inaccurate and unverifiable nature. 

Enforce any applicable penalties against XXXX, Experian, and/or XXXX XXXX for failing to comply with the FCRA. 

This situation has caused undue stress and damaged my credit score and financial well-being. I trust the CFPB will take appropriate action to resolve this matter. Should you require any further information or documentation, I am happy to provide it. Don't hesitate to get in touch with me at XXXX or XXXX. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

And according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are supposed to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am disputing inaccuracies on my credit report regarding an account reported by XXXX XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate, complete, and verifiable reporting. Below are the issues I have identified : 1. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : The Date Opened differs : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX Experian : XX/XX/XXXX This discrepancy violates the FCRAs requirement for accuracy and consistency in reporting.

2. Disputed Account Status : XXXX : Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. 
Experian : Customer disputed account - reported by subscriber. 
These comments are inconsistent and may mislead creditors about the resolution status of the dispute.

3. Outdated or Improper Reporting : The Date Last Active for Experian is listed as XX/XX/XXXX, but the Last Reported date is XX/XX/XXXX. If no activity occurred since XXXX, the account may no longer be eligible for reporting under FCRA guidelines, as negative information ( e.g., collections ) must be removed after seven years from the date of first delinquency.

4. No Payment History Provided : There is no clear payment history or supporting data to indicate when the account became delinquent or how it reached Collection/Chargeoff status.

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must maintain accurate and consistent reporting. The discrepancies in the Date Opened and inconsistent dispute comments violate this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting Obsolete Information : Negative information such as collections must not be reported after seven years from the date of first delinquency. If the accounts delinquency began in XXXX, it may be close to or past the allowable reporting period.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If the dispute was filed but the status remains inconsistent or inaccurate, this indicates a failure to properly investigate the dispute.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The furnisher ( XXXX XXXX XXXX may be providing outdated or misleading information to the credit bureaus, especially regarding the accounts disputed and derogatory status.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally notify you of the unlawful reporting of fraudulent accounts on my consumer report, arising from identity theft, which you failed to verify as mandated by law.

15 USC 1681b ( c ) - Furnishing reports in connection with credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer : ( 3 ) Information regarding inquiries : Except as provided in section 1681g ( a ) ( 5 ) of this title, a consumer reporting agency shall not furnish to any person a record of inquiries in connection with a credit or insurance transaction that is not initiated by a consumer. 
The following inquiries, which are a result of identity theft and were not initiated by me, must be deleted immediately : Inquiry : Company Name, Date of Inquiry My identity has been stolen, and I am placing you on formal notice.

Aggravated Identity Theft pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1028A : ( 1 ) In general : Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 2 years.

15 USC 1681b - Permissible purposes of consumer reports : ( a ) IN GENERAL : Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report only under the following circumstances : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates.

15 USC 1681- Fair Credit Reporting Act : ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reports : ( XXXX ) There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Pursuant to 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 - Block of information resulting from identity theft : A consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information resulting from alleged identity theft, not later than 4 business days after the date of receipt by such agency of : ( 1 ) Appropriate proof of the identity of the consumer ; ( 2 ) A copy of an identity theft report ; ( 3 ) The identification of such information by the consumer ; and ( 4 ) A statement by the consumer that the information is not related to any transaction by the consumer. 
Enclosed are all relevant documents pursuant to the above section of the law. I demand that all the aforementioned fraudulent accounts be deleted immediately. Additionally, I demand an updated copy of my consumer file reflecting these changes, as stated by 15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports.

15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports : In any case in which a consumer reporting agency includes a fraud alert in the file of a consumer pursuant to this subsection, the consumer reporting agency shall : ( A ) Disclose to the consumer that they may request a free copy of their file pursuant to section 1681j ( d ) of this title.

Be advised that I will CC : The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection ( CFPB ) The Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) The Attorney General 's Office in your state and mine Thank you, XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Copy of ID Utility bill showing proof of address Copy of Social Security Card FTC Identity Theft Report

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against the Credit Reporting Agencies ( CRAs ) for the following violations : Fraudulent Reporting of Charged-Off Accounts Failure to Honor Opt-Out Rights Under FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802 ) CRAs are illegally reporting charged-off accounts on my credit report. A charged-off account is classified as income when reported to the IRS on a 1099-C form. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), income can not legally be reported as a debt on a credit report.

Violation : Reporting these charged-off accounts as debts is misleading, inaccurate, and against federal law under 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ), which prohibits the reporting of false information on a credit report.

Under 15 U.S.C. 6802, I have the legal right to opt out of the sharing of my non-public personal information ( NPI ) at any time. Despite this, the CRAs have failed to honor my opt-out request and continue to use and share my data without my permission.

Lawful Right to Opt-Out : According to 12 C.F.R. 1016.10, consumers can opt out of the sharing of their information with third parties at any time, regardless of any prior authorizationswritten, verbal, implied, or otherwise.

Under 15 U.S.C. 6801, it is unlawful for any financial institution or Credit Reporting Agency ( CRA ) to report transaction history without my explicit consent. Congress has made it clear that financial institutions have an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of their customers and to safeguard the security and confidentiality of their non-public personal information ( NPI ).

Violation : the CRAs have illegally reported my transaction history without my knowledge or consent. This is a clear breach of their statutory obligations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) and related provisions of the FCRA.

Privacy Obligation : Under 15 U.S.C. 6801 ( b ), financial institutions are required to implement safeguards to ensure the privacy of their customers ' information. Reporting transaction history without proper authorization violates these obligations.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally request the removal of a fraudulent account from my credit report and to exercise my legal right to opt out of your reporting services in relation to this matter.

As outlined in the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681, consumer reporting agencies such as XXXX and Experian are required to handle consumer data with fairness, impartiality, and respect for the consumer 's privacy. This includes ensuring that no consumer information is reported without explicit consent. 

The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. 6801, further protects my personal information, mandating that financial institutions and those who furnish information to credit reporting agencies must respect my privacy and the confidentiality of my nonpublic personal information. I have not provided consent to either XXXX or Experian to share my personal data or information related to any accounts opened in my name, including the disputed XXXX account. 

Furthermore, 15 U.S.C. 1681b and 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) prohibit the reporting of certain adverse information beyond a specified period, and require consumer consent to furnish data to credit agencies. Since I did not authorize the creation of the XXXX account in question, the account is an unlawful and unauthorized entry on my credit report. 

Additionally, 15 U.S.C. 1681s2 ( a ) ( 1 ) clearly states that no person may report inaccurate information to a consumer reporting agency if they know, or have reasonable cause to believe, that the information is incorrect. Since I did not authorize the account and it appears to be fraudulent, the furnisher of information has violated this requirement.

As a consumer, I am also exercising my right to opt out of your reporting services. Under 12 C.F.R. 1016.7, I have the right to opt out of having my information shared with third parties, and I am exercising that right immediately. 

I request that the fraudulent account associated with XXXX XXXX be removed from my credit report, as it was opened without my knowledge or consent. I further request that you confirm in writing that the necessary corrections have been made. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. Please provide written confirmation that this account has been removed and that my privacy rights have been upheld in accordance with federal law.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to declare that I am a victim of identity theft. A fraudulent account was illegally opened in my name without my knowledge or consent. Specifically, I have no recollection of applying for or authorizing the account with XXXX XXXX, and I am unfamiliar with its origin. This unauthorized activity has caused harm to my credit and financial reputation. 

I have taken immediate action by filing a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and I have enclosed my Identity Theft Report as evidence of this crime. Additionally, I have contacted the credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) to request validation of the debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). However, the information I requested has not been provided, which further confirms the lack of legitimacy surrounding this account. 

The fraudulent activity violates my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which ensures the accuracy of information reported to consumer reporting agencies, and the Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act, which makes the unauthorized use of my personal information a federal crime. 

I am requesting the immediate investigation and removal of this account from my records and credit reports to prevent further harm. Identity theft has impacted my ability to secure credit and maintain my financial well-being. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and your cooperation in helping me resolve this issue. Please contact me if you require additional documentation or information. 

Please find attached a copy of my id, a copy of my social security card, a copy of my most recent utility bill, a copy of the FTC complaint, and a copy of the validation of dept letter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the accuracy of an account reported by XXXX XXXX on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate, complete, and verifiable credit reporting. Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I have the right to be free from misleading or unauthorized debt collection practices. Below are the issues I have identified : XXXX. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : The Account Type - Detail is listed differently across bureaus, with XXXX stating Unknown - credit extension, review, or collection, and XXXX reporting Collection. This inconsistency violates 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). 
XXXX. Improper Dispute Status : The comments from Experian and XXXX state that the account is disputed. If this dispute has been resolved or if the reporting is incorrect, this information must be updated or removed. 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Reporting : The Date Last Active is listed as XX/XX/2019. If no activity has occurred since then, the account may exceed the seven-year reporting limit, per 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ). 
4. Lack of Verification and Payment History : The report does not provide any detailed payment history or verification of how the account reached Collection/Chargeoff status. 
XXXX. Unauthorized Transfer of Debt : I did not authorize payments to XXXX XXXX or agree to the transfer of this debt. Reporting this without my consent may violate the FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ). 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and FDCPA : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure that the information they report is accurate and consistent. The discrepancies in account descriptions and comments violate this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Negative information, such as collections, must not be reported more than seven years from the date of first delinquency.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If you disputed the account and it remains unresolved or improperly updated, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate properly.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor or collection agency may have provided inaccurate or unverifiable information.

5. FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : False or Misleading Representations : Reporting this debt without proper verification or authorization from you to collect or transfer the debt may violate the FDCPA.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX dispute dispute This complaint is in regard to the account related to XXXX XXXX XXXX that is being reported to XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX needs prior consent from either the court or the consumer before communication with the collection of any debt to a credit reporting agency. 
Notice, it is a fact, I the consumer did not give prior consent to communication to the debt collector, { XXXX XXXX XXXX } and the consumer alleges there was no prior consent from a court giving permission to contact I, the consumer in collection of any debts owed to XXXX XXXX XXXX and thus this communication by XXXX XXXX XXXX is a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692c ( a ) without a court order brought forth. I did not consent to XXXX XXXX XXXX communicating with me any obligations to pay a debt through any mediums which includes communication with the credit reporting agencies to report the alleged debt. Furthermore 15 U.S.Code 1692a ( 6 ) 1692a ( 6 ) - a debt collector is defined as anyone in the business of collecting a debt. Therefore by definition XXXX XXXX XXXX is debt collector. 

Notice, it is a fact, that, I, agent for principal ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) am aware that XXXX XXXX XXXX is a debt collector by the legal definition. Pursuant to 15 U.S.Code 1692 ( a ) ( 6 ), a debt collector is any person who uses instrumentality of interstate commerce, such as the mails, in any business which the principal purpose is the collection of any debts, or who regularly collects or attempts to collect, directly or indirectly, debts owed or due or asserted to be owed or due another Furthermore this law U.S.Code 1692d states A Debt collector may not engage in any conduct ( no restriction ) which will harass, oppress or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Oppressing a right would be conduct not allowed from 1692d. Credit is the right granted and protected by federal law. If any debt collection caused a denial of credit this allows for damages. I have been denied credit on multiple occasions and denied housing because of this negative account on XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report. This is an actual damage as this tremendously harmed my ability to operate in commerce and purchase household goods and shelter for I the consumer and my family. 

Notice, it is a fact, I the affiant is aware, credit is a right granted to me as a creditor under the Truth in Lending Act and { XXXX XXXX XXXX } does not have the right to oppress or abuse any part of my character which would restrict or prohibit my right to extend credit. XXXX XXXX XXXX has oppressed my right to extend credit which is a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692d.

Furthermore this law 15 U.S.Code 1692e ( 8 ) states the actions performed by XXXX XXXX XXXX was illegal- Communicating with any person false credit information including failure to communicate the debt is being disputed has not been verified. As well as there being no contract that exists bewteen the I the consumer and XXXX XXXX XXXX thats says I the consumer would pay XXXX XXXX XXXX the alleged debt this was false and misleading reporting. 

Notice, it is a fact, affiant is aware and has proof in this complaint of false and inaccurate credit information reported and it is a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692e ( 8 ). XXXX XXXX XXXX reported a debt collections account to XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report. I the affiant have disputed this debt this information can not keep reporting while the dispute is still not resolved as well as failing to communicate with the credit reporting agencies that the debt is being disputed and has not been verified by I, the consumer. This was very misleading and XXXX XXXX XXXX used this as a tactic to swindle the credit reporting agencies into reporting a fake debt while at the same time attempting to force me to pay the alleged debt under the threat of duress and coercion by reporting the negative collections account to my consumer report in doing so severely damaging my credit worthiness and my ability to operate in commerce and obtain household goods and shelter. I have been denied housing on multiple occasions leading to me being in a homeless shelter this is an actual damage to I, the consumer. I demand once again that XXXX XXXX XXXX fix this issue by deleting the account. XXXX XXXX XXXX is also in violation of 15 U.S. code 1681a ( 2 ) ( A ) ( I ) 1681 a ( 2 ) ( A ) ( i ) - Reported information can not be only transactions and experiences between the consumer and a company. 1681 a ( 2 ) ( A ) ( iii ) - The consumer must be given a chance to direct the information whether they want the information about a transaction they had to be reported or not. This is referenced in the Gramm Leach Bliley Act Notice, it is a fact, consumer is aware, a consumer must be given a chance to direct whether they want the information about a transaction to be reported or not. This is referenced in the Gramm-Leach Bliley Act. Affiant was not given the chance to opt-out of having this information reported regarding XXXX XXXX XXXX in doing so is in violation of 15 U.S. Code 1681 a ( 2 ) ( A ) ( ii ) and this information must be removed. 

I the consumer also know that it is a fact that XXXX XXXX the original creditor assigned the debt to XXXX XXXX XXXX. The two debt collectors that reported the alleged debt and are attempting collect are XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX. Both debt collectors are attempting to force the consumer to pay under the threat of duress and coercion by reporting a collections account to XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report. In doing so both companies have severely damaged my ability to operate in commerce and use my right to credit. I the consumer have a right to credit and have had that right taken from me due to the improper use of my consumer report from XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX. 

Furthermore in accordance with 15 U.S.Code 1692e ( 12 ) 1692e ( 12 ) - the assignee clause which makes the 3rd party debt collector and the one who assigns the debt liable. 
XXXX XXXX assigned the debt to XXXX XXXX XXXX This means they are both liable for the alleged debt not I the consumer Notice, it is a fact, consumer has reason to be believe and do so believes, XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX are in violation in accordance to Article XXXX, the assignment of a defaulted note is illegal. Both the assignee and the assigned are both liable for violations under 15 U.S.Code 1692e ( 12 ). So I am actually not liable for this debt according to what the law says about the matter. 

The debt was assigned to XXXX XXXX XXXX they are attempting to collect a debt that they were assigned. XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX do not have any contract which contains my signature nor does a contract exists that states XXXX XXXX XXXX would pay XXXX XXXX XXXX any payment for a debt. 

There is no contract between the consumer and the debt collectors. This violates the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) which prohibits abusive, unfair, or deceptive debt collection practices ; if you are contacted by multiple XXXX for the same debt. Both XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX have both contacted XXXX XXXX XXXX in an attempt to collect a debt. 
XXXX XXXX had no right to sell the account without notice to i the consumer before doing so. XXXX XXXX also had no right to sell the debt because XXXX XXXX already received income from I the consumer. XXXX XXXX already received full payment of the debt. XXXX XXXX withdrew funds from my Social Security trust account. XXXX Treasury XXXX XXXX XXXX Account - [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT NUMBER XXXX XXXXXXXX, with IRS Form 1099-A. The IRS XXXX department can properly account for the transfer of these funds from this account to all debt accounts that I am said to owe or be in default. Due to this fact I, the consumer have no further obligations to XXXX XXXX. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX also violated 15 U.S.Code 1692j 15 USC 1692 ; 1692 - False and deceptive forms. A form which is made to believe the debt has something to do with you or you are obligated and you are not, is false and deceptive.

Fraud found in a form is a false and deceptive form and a violation of this act. For example if you go and get into an agreement as a consumer credit transaction, you went for something and gave credit. Companies are known to make what's called asset accounts. I never went to have an account made, this is a false and deceptive form because they never disclose this account being made. This includes statements which falsely accuses me of owing a debt. The delivery of these forms via mail constitutes mail fraud. I also never created an account with XXXX XXXX XXXX if I the consumer did not open the account then it is fraud. 

Notice, it is a fact, consumer is aware, there has been fraud found in this form shown in EXHIBIT ( - ). This form is therefore false and deceptive, void and a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692j I do not have a contract with XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

Furthermore 15 U.S.Code 1692k ( a ) ( 1 ) 15 USC 16324010 ) 1692k ( a ) ( 1 ) - Allows for any action of damage.

Notice, it is a fact, affiant is aware pursuant to 15 U.S.Code 1692k ( a
) ( 1 ) allows civil liability rewards for any damages, which may include stress, harassment, anxiety, mental anguish, and other damages all caused by violations of FDCPA due to XXXX XXXX XXXX abusive and deceptive business practices. Which caused I the consumer to be denied for housing and certain lines of credit. Which caused I the consumer to be in a homeless shelter and and unable to operate in commerce this is very un equitable. 

Furthermore I am owed monetary value in the amount of XXXX $ for every single violation of the UNITED STATES CODES. 15 U.S.Code 1692k ( a ) ( 2 ) ( A ) 1692k ( a ) ( 2 ) ( A ) - XXXX dollars for each proceeding. 
Notice, it is a fact, 15 U.S.Code 1692k ( a ) ( 2 ) ( A ) states an individual action is a violation worth 1000 dollars for proceeding, however understand 15 U.S.Code 1692k ( a ) ( 1 ) these violations has caused actual damage By XXXX XXXX XXXX violating 15 U.S. Code 1681 a ( 2 ) ( A ) ( ii ) and not giving me a chance to direct whether I want the information about a transaction to be reported or not. Affiant was not given the chance to opt-out of having this information reported regarding XXXX XXXX XXXX in doing so XXXX XXXX XXXX is in violation of 15 U.S. Code 1681 a ( 2 ) ( A ) ( ii ) I was damaged by this violation of the law XXXX XXXX XXXX took it upon themselves to infringe on my right to direct the information I want reported regarding the transaction. Then hindering my ability to credit by reporting without my directions a collections account that negatively impacted my consumer report. 
Every violation of the law by XXXX XXXX XXXX caused a damage to I, the consumer. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX also committed identity theft. They obtained my identifying information such as my social security number to swindle the credit reporting agencies into reporting the fraudulent account. This use of my social security number was not authorized by I the consumer. 15 U.S.Code 1644 ( a ) 15 USC 1644 ( a ) 1644 ( a ) - Fraudulent authorized use of a credit card such as a license plate, social security card, XXXX card etc, can result up to a XXXX fine. 

Notice, it is a fact, affiant is aware, the fraudulent use of a credit card, by XXXX XXXX XXXX is defined as whoever uses, attempts or conspires to use a card to obtain money, goods or services shall be fined for {$10000.00} or imprisoned for 10 years or both. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX used my social security account number the exact number on social security card to report information to my consumer report and to collect on a debt.

This is a direct violation of 1644 ( a ) Also note that this matter could become even more serious if this issues isnt resolved because according to 1692k ( a ) ( 2 ) ( B ) -If i win a civil suit and file a class action, i can obtain up to XXXX XXXX or 1 % of the company.

15 U.S.Code 1602 ( b ) 15 USC 1602 ( b ) 1602 ( b ) Bureau.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute and Request to Update Personal Information Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to dispute and request an update to my personal information in your records. I recently obtained a copy of my credit report and discovered that some of the personal information listed is inaccurate or outdated. I kindly request that you investigate and make the necessary updates to ensure the accuracy and integrity of my credit profile. 

Please find below the specific details of the incorrect or outdated information : 1. Name : My current legal name is [ XXXX XXXX ], but it is listed incorrectly on my credit report as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I request that my name be updated to reflect the correct information. 
2. Address : My current residential address is [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX fl XXXX ], but my credit report shows an outdated address as [ XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, FL XXXX ]. I request that my current address be updated accordingly. 
3. Contact Information : The phone number listed on my credit report, [ XXXX ], is no longer in use. I request that my new phone number, [ XXXX ], be updated as my primary contact number. 
I have enclosed copies of supporting documents to verify the accurate information provided above. The documents include : A copy of my driver 's license or passport displaying my correct name. 
A recent utility bill or bank statement showing my current address. 
A copy of my phone bill or any other official document that displays my correct phone number. 

Additionally, please provide me with a written confirmation once the updates have been made, and send me an updated copy of my credit report reflecting the changes. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter. Should you require any further information or documentation, please do not hesitate to contact me at [ XXXX ] or via email at [ XXXX ]. Thank you for your cooperation. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, AL XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX Experian XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX To Whom it May Concern : I am writing to address concerns regarding the accuracy and compliance of information on my credit report, as mandated by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681I ) and industry-standard reporting guidelines such as the Metro 2 Five Points of Compliance. 
It has come to my attention that certain information reported on my credit file may be inaccurate, inconsistent, or unverifiable. Under the FCRA and Metro 2 standards, creditors are obligated to provide accurate and complete information to credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) in a timely manner. 
I want to emphasize the importance of adhering to the prescribed reporting requisites and standards. Even if the information reported is factually correct, it must be reported precisely according to the mandated format, such as Metro 2 data field formatting. Any deviations from these standards may render the reported information deficient and non-compliant. 
Therefore, I am exercising my rights as a consumer to demand the removal of any inaccuracies and deficiencies from my credit report. I request a thorough investigation into the sources of these accounts to ensure that creditors have fully complied with industry reporting standards, including Metro 2 requirements. 
It is crucial to ascertain that all alleged reporting data furnishers can accurately provide my complete file information to all major credit reporting agencies, including XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. 
Furthermore, I want to highlight the significance of the FCRA 's provision regarding the accuracy of consumer reports ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). Consumer reporting agencies are required to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of information contained in consumer reports.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
To : Credit Reporting Agency Subject : Request for Removal of Unverifiable Account Dear Credit Reporting Department, I am writing to formally request the removal of an account from my credit report as reported by [ XXXX, Experian, or XXXX ]. This request is based on the recent deletion of an account by XXXX, one of the four major credit reporting agencies. I recently disputed a charge-off for {$25000.00} from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX listed on my XXXX report, and following a thorough investigation, XXXX has completely deleted this unverifiable debt from my report as of XX/XX/. 
According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ), all consumer reporting agencies must ensure that information in consumer reports is accurate, fair, and verifiable. Since XXXX has removed this account after its verification process, I request that you do the same and remove this unverifiable account from my credit report. 
Supporting Consumer Laws : FCRA Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires that inaccurate or unverifiable information must be deleted from a consumer 's credit file. I am exercising my right to ensure that my credit report remains fair, accurate, and free of unverifiable information. Since XXXX has deemed this account unverifiable and removed it, you must take similar action. 
Additionally, under FCRA Section 623 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ), information suppliers must report only complete and accurate information. With XXXX having deemed this information unverifiable, I urge you to align its records accordingly. 
Please provide confirmation of this removal within 30 days of receipt of this request. If the account is not removed, I am prepared to pursue further actions, including filing a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and seeking legal action under the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), including Section 616 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681n ), which allows consumers to seek legal recourse for willful noncompliance, and Section 617 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681o ) for negligent non-compliance. 
I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter, as it directly impacts my credit reports integrity. Please notify me in writing once this deletion has been processed. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this request. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the inaccurate and fraudulent information being reported on my credit file. As per FCRA 605B ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ), I am requesting the immediate removal of the following information that has resulted from identity theft : Account : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Relevant Provisions of FCRA 605B Under the FCRA, a consumer reporting agency must block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as resulting from identity theft. Specifically : 1. Timely Action Required : According to FCRA 605B ( a ), Experian must block the disputed information no later than four business days after receiving the following : Proof of my identity.

A copy of my identity theft report.

Identification of the fraudulent information. 

A statement from me asserting that the information is not the result of any transaction I authorized. 



XXXX. Notification Obligation : As required by FCRA 605B ( b ), Experian must promptly notify the furnishers of the information about the identity theft claim, the requested block, and the effective dates of the block. 


XXXX. Limits on Declining or Rescinding the Block : Experian may only decline or rescind a block under very specific circumstances, as outlined in FCRA 605B ( c ). Any decision to decline or rescind a block must be accompanied by prompt notification to me, including an explanation as required by FCRA 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( B ).

Action Requested I demand the following actions : XXXX. Immediate removal of the fraudulent account identified above. 


XXXX. Notification to all furnishers of the fraudulent nature of the account. 


XXXX. Written confirmation within 30 days that the disputed information has been removed or blocked, as required under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ). 



Next Steps Failure to comply with this request will result in formal complaints being filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and other regulatory agencies. Additionally, I reserve the right to seek legal counsel to pursue remedies under federal law, including damages for violations of the FCRA and any other applicable statutes. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

1681i. Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) Reinvestigations of disputed information ( XXXX ) Reinvestigation required ( A ) In general ( B ) Extension of period to reinvestigate ( C ) Limitations on extension of period to reinvestigate ( XXXX ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general If, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( XXXX ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation ; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer. 
15 U.S. Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies. A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Consumer complaint narrative:
To whom it may concern, This letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting inaccurate and incomplete credit information on my Experian Credit Report. 

15 USC 1681e ( b ) Compliance and Procedures ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report, it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual ; about whom the report relates. 

Otherwise, anyone paying for your reporting services could fax, mail or email in a fraudulent account. 

I demand to see verifiable proof ( i.e. : an original consumer contract with my signature on it ) that you have on file for the account listed below. Or a Certification from the creditor that certified the accuracy and completeness of the information/account. 

Your failure to positively verify these accounts has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Under the FCRA, unverifiable accounts must be DELETED and if you are unable to provide me a copy of verifiable proof, you must DELETE the accounts listed below. 

I demand that the following accounts be validated or DELETED immediately : 1. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 2. XXXX XXXX 3. XXXX XXXX In addition, DELETE all non-account holding inquiries over 30 days old. 
Under federal law, you have thirty ( 30 ) days to complete your re-investigtion. Be advised that the description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information is hereby requested as well, to be provided within fifteen ( 15 ) days of the completion of your re-investigation. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
My account with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX was never late! I have had exceptional payment history witH XXXX XXXX and all payments were placed on XXXX. This late payment that is reporting is a result on a systematic error on their end processing my payment. 


This was clearly a billing error made my the company and is not a reflection of my payment experience which violates USC Code 1681eb. This error has caused severe hard to my reputation, my character, my mode of living and to my family! 


I demand the late payment reported in 60 - 90 DAYS to be removed. 


They are not in compliance with the following law. 15 USC 1666b and its requirements set the standards and the guidance for a creditor to treat a payment as late, yet they are reporting a payment as late and they did not comply with the law! 


15 USC 1666b ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 


XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Never Sent the periodic statement along with the disclosures from section 1637 ( b ). 


I have requested proof that this information was mailed or delivered XXXX days before the payment due date and this information was requested in good faith pursuant rule 1002 and It was never provided. 


This is unfair, illegal, fraudulent, and not equitable to me as a consumer! 


Delete the late payments from my consumer reports

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
-- - XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Customer Success Team RE : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Complaint Case # XXXX Dear XXXX XXXX XXXX I am writing in response to your letter dated XX/XX/year>, regarding your investigation of my complaint filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX While I appreciate your response, I respectfully request additional information under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Specifically, I am requesting the deletion and removal of the account from all credit reporting agencies, as I believe that the information reported is inaccurate and unverifiable. 

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), if an item on a credit report can not be verified, it must be deleted. As you are a data furnisher, you are required to ensure that the information provided to the credit reporting agencies is both accurate and verifiable. Therefore, I am formally requesting : 1. A detailed description of the methods of verification used during your investigation, as required by 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 6 ) ( B ) ( iii ).

2. The specific documents and evidence relied upon to verify the accuracy of the information that was reported, including how the late payments were validated and how the account closure was handled in accordance with the requirements of 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which mandates maximum possible accuracy in credit reporting. 



XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX be unable to provide verifiable and accurate evidence, I am requesting that the account in question, including any associated late payments, be immediately deleted from all credit reporting agencies, in accordance with 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), which requires deletion or modification of inaccurate or unverifiable information. 

Additionally, I would like to reference the following case laws that reinforce the importance of accuracy and proper verification under the FCRA : XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Establishes that data furnishers must have a permissible purpose and ensure the accuracy of the reported information. 


XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX, LLC Highlights that furnishers are obligated to refrain from reporting inaccurate or unverifiable information, emphasizing the importance of correcting errors. 


XXXX. XXXX v. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Demonstrates that failure to properly verify or correct inaccurate information can result in legal liability under the FCRA. 


XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Emphasizes that data furnishers have a legal obligation to conduct reasonable investigations when a dispute arises. 



Furthermore, under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ), furnishers of information must promptly investigate disputes regarding the accuracy of reported information, and if they fail to verify the accuracy of the information, they are required to notify the credit bureaus to delete or modify the information.

Given these requirements, I request that the inaccurate information be permanently deleted from my credit reports if it can not be verified in accordance with FCRA regulations.

Please provide a response within the 30-day window as required by the FCRA. If the disputed information is not corrected or deleted, I will explore further legal remedies under 15 U.S.C. 1681n and 1681o for willful and negligent noncompliance, which allows for monetary damages in cases where credit reporting violations occur. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response. Should you need further information, ---

In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. The list of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 U.S.C. 1681. 

XXXX & XXXX : XXXX # XXXX, Dept of ED/XXXX  : XXXX # XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX # XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX # XXXX, XXXX XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, has violated my rights. 

15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602 A. States I have right to privacy.

15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 604 A. Section 2. It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions.

15 U.S.C. 1681 C. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section states. No consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information. Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which ante dates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681 S-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer, to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the accuracy and validity of an account reported on my credit report by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate and verifiable reporting. Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I have the right to be free from misleading or unauthorized debt collection practices. Below are the specific issues : XXXX. XXXX XXXX of XXXX XXXX : The report states, Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. If you did not agree to this dispute resolution or if the dispute was not properly investigated, this statement might be misleading. 
XXXX. Unauthorized Transfer or Assignment of Debt : If you did not agree to any payments or the transfer of this account to a third party ( XXXX Funding ), it could be a violation of consumer protection laws, including the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Information : The accounts Date Opened is listed as XX/XX/XXXX, with the Last Reported date as XX/XX/XXXX. If the original delinquency occurred in XXXX, this account XXXX soon exceed the seven-year reporting limit for negative items under the FCRA. 
XXXX. Lack of Supporting Payment History : The report does not provide a detailed payment history or verification of how the debt reached Collection/Chargeoff status. This lack of transparency raises concerns about the accuracy and verifiability of the report. 
XXXX. Incorrect Reporting of Collection Activity : If XXXX Funding is reporting this account as Collection/Chargeoff without proper documentation or consent, this could constitute a violation of the FCRA and FDCPA. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and FDCPA : XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure the information they report is accurate and verifiable. Inconsistent and unclear reporting violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Negative information, such as collections, must not be reported for more than seven years from the date of the first delinquency.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If you disputed this account and it remains unresolved or improperly updated, this indicates a failure to conduct a proper investigation.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The furnisher ( XXXX XXXX ) XXXX be reporting incorrect or unverifiable information. 
XXXX. FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : False or Misleading Representations : If XXXX XXXX reported this debt without your consent or misrepresented its authority to collect, this could violate FDCPA provisions.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
EXPERIAN XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, TX XXXX To Whom It May Concern, Going over my credit report, I have found it has many errors. It has come to my attention that you are reporting what I believe to be inaccurate data, which I dispute, and this letter is an appeal for your assistance. As a national reporting agency, you are governed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( " FCRA '' ), which protects consumers from inaccurate, outdated, or invalidated information reporting of their credit file. The FCRA states that it's the Credit Bureau 's responsibility to ensure that all information contained within consumer credit files is accurate and free from errors.

According to federal law, you are required to comply with the requirements imposed under the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., including but not limited to : follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information in the consumer report, as required by 15 U.S.C. $ 1681e ( b ) ; XXXX ) comply with the investigation requirements ; XXXX ) should not provide consumer credit file to companies without determining that these companies had a permissible purpose to obtain consumer credit file pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681b ; XXXX ) provide consumer credit file pursuant to 15 U.S.C. $ 1681g ; 5 ) et seq.

Accordingly, I request your company to provide verifiable documentary proof ( e.g., original consumer contract or similar proof bearing my wet ink signature on it ) you have on file of accounts/items listed below. Under the FCRA, if you do not provide documented and verifiable proof, you must remove all unverified, invalid, derogatory information from my consumer disclosure report. For your convenience, I am sending you a list of the items you need to verify them. These listed accounts are neither my debts nor my authorized inquiries. Please correct this by the removal of these items from my credit report. See. Exhibit A. Upon completion of your investigation, please send a detailed description of the procedures used to determine the accuracy of the account ( s ) I am disputing, as well as the name and contact information of the agent conducting the said investigation in case further communication is necessary. I know that your company will need some sort of verification to prove my identity. My information is clearly shown below : Accounts that need to be removed XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  {$1600.00} XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX {$2200.00} - XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions.

15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of Incorrect Address Information on My Credit Report To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute the presence of incorrect addresses listed on my credit report. These addresses are not mine, and I am requesting their immediate investigation and removal to ensure the accuracy of my personal information, as required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 

The following addresses appearing on my credit report are incorrect : XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX My actual and current address is : [ Your Correct Address, e.g., XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX CA XXXX ] Maintaining incorrect address information on my credit report can lead to confusion, misattributed accounts, and potential violations of my rights under FCRA 1681e ( b ), which mandates credit reporting agencies to follow reasonable procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer reports.

I request the following actions : Immediate Investigation : Review the incorrect address information and confirm that these addresses do not belong to me.

Correction or Removal : Remove all inaccurate addresses from my credit report.

Written Confirmation : Provide me with written confirmation of the changes made and an updated copy of my credit report reflecting the accurate information.

Please complete your investigation and respond within the 30 days required by the FCRA. Ensuring the accuracy of my credit report is essential, and I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter. 

Thank you for your cooperation. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
