Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, IL XXXX Report Number : XXXX Date Generated : XX/XX/year> Subject : Request for Validation of Alleged Debt Pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Dear [ Debt Collectors Name or To Whom It May Concern ], I am writing regarding the alleged debt associated with the above-referenced account. As this matter impacts my creditworthiness and personal information, I am disputing the validity of this debt and formally requesting debt validation under 15 U.S.C. 1692g of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 

Specific Issues The information associated with my credit report includes multiple inaccuracies and unverified details. Below is a summary of my correct information and the discrepancies that require immediate attention : Correct Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, IL XXXX Other Address History : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, IL XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, IL XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, IL XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, IL XXXX Employment Information : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX  Name Variations : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Please provide the following documentation to validate the alleged debt : A signed agreement or contract proving my obligation to this debt.

An itemized breakdown of the debt ( principal, interest, fees, etc. ). 
Proof that you are legally authorized to collect this debt on behalf of the original creditor. 
Impact on My Credit Report : If this debt can not be validated, you are instructed to : Cease all collection activity immediately. 
Request the removal of any associated negative information from Experian, XXXX, and XXXX. 
Correct or update any inaccurate address, name, or employer information listed on my credit report. 
Legal Considerations Failure to validate this debt within 30 days of receipt of this certified letter will result in legal action under : FDCPA 807 [ 15 U.S.C. 1692e ], for false or misleading representations. 
Fair Credit Reporting Act [ 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) ], for reporting unverifiable or inaccurate information.

I will pursue damages of up to {$5000.00} in small claims court for : Defamation resulting from inaccurate credit reporting.

Negligent enablement of identity fraud. 
Violations of consumer protection laws. 
Immediate Action Required You are required to : Provide a written response with the requested validation documents. 
Cease all credit reporting and collection activities pending resolution. 
This letter is an effort to resolve the matter amicably and correct inaccuracies. It does not constitute an acknowledgment of the debt or a waiver of any rights. Please direct your response and any questions to my address above. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently had a frustrating experience with a furniture delivery that I'd like to share. The delivery team arrived but quickly assessed that the box wouldnt fit through my doorway, even though another company had successfully delivered furniture to my apartment before. The driver didn't measure anything ; he just assumed it wouldn't fit. I suggested they take the furniture out of the box, as I had paid for delivery to the room of my choice and wasn't concerned about how they managed it. 

While I was on the phone with the furniture company discussing the situation, the driver drove off with my furniture. Several days passed without any updates, and when I finally heard back, they wanted to know if I wanted redelivery. I had taken a day off work for this delivery, and I have a witness who saw everything unfold. 

To make matters worse, my credit card company, Chase, claimed that I had canceled the order and imposed a cancellation fee. Yet, my credit card has been charge the full amount. This didnt make sense to me since the delivery team left with my furniture without even taking it off the truck. The driver had mentioned that the furniture would get dirty if he delivered it, but I was okay with that as I had also purchased a warranty for it. However, I was charged an extra {$100.00} for this warranty, which I found questionable since it wasn't clear on their website. Along with another XXXX dollars for brackets to hold the couch together. I had to change the order and called in and they up charged me XXXX dollars. 

It feels like a scam, as by Illinois law, the company should honor the contract by delivering on the agreed date. Instead, they're claiming I canceled. I attempted to arrange redelivery, but they now want to charge me {$300.00}, which is ridiculous. When I inquired about cancellation fees due to their shadiness, they informed me they had already disposed of the furniture and Id have to reorder it. 

Chase also refused to refund me, insisting I canceled. I only refused to take the furniture after they drove off with it. Even now, in trying to resolve the issue, they are still trying to charge me that additional fee. It's incredibly frustrating, especially since they no longer have the furniture, and I believe a refund is due.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX XXXX XXXX Date : XX/XX/year> Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, IA XXXX Subject : Formal Dispute Regarding Charge-Off Reporting Credit Collection Service Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX I am writing to formally dispute the accuracy and legality of a charge-off reported by Credit Collection Service ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, MA XXXX XXXX on my credit report.

Upon reviewing my credit file, I identified significant inaccuracies in the reporting of this account. I believe the company has violated consumer protection laws under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), specifically regarding the handling and reporting of charge-offs. 

Key Concerns : 1. Incomplete and Inaccurate Reporting : The reported charge-off contains errors that suggest it is not in compliance with FCRA Section 623, which mandates data furnishers to report accurate and complete information.

2. Discrepancies in Key Dates : The Date of Last Reporting ( DLR ) and Date of Last Activity ( DLA ) listed for this account are inconsistent and do not accurately reflect the true history of this account. These inaccuracies violate FCRA provisions requiring precise and truthful reporting of account details.

3. Debt Validation Request Ignored : Under FDCPA Section 809 ( b ), I have the right to request validation of the alleged debt. Credit Collection Service failed to provide sufficient validation despite my written request.

4. Improper Collection Practices : I suspect the charge-off was improperly calculated and misreported to credit bureaus, potentially violating FDCPA and FCRA standards for fair and accurate reporting.

Given these violations and the inaccurate reporting of the DLR and DLA, I respectfully request that this account be permanently removed from my consumer report as it fails to meet the requirements set forth by federal law.

To assist in your investigation, I have attached copies of my credit report, prior correspondence with Credit Collection Service, and relevant documents for your review.

Thank you for your assistance. I look forward to a prompt resolution to this matter. Please feel free to contact me at XXXX or XXXX for further details. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

In accordance with the Fair Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX : # XXXX, Dept of EducationXXXX : # XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : has violated my rights. 

I looked at my Experian credit report on XX/XX/year>, and noticed some things are incomplete and not accurate. And according to the fair credit reporting act Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ).

And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are supposed to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information.

( A ) In general. after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are supposed to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Credit Collection Services XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, MA, XXXX Re : Request for Debt Validation XXXX Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to request validation of the debt that you are attempting to collect from me. Under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I have the right to request that you provide me with verification of the debt and evidence that you have the legal right to collect on it. 
Please provide me with the following information : XXXX. The full name and address of the original creditor associated with the debt. 
XXXX. The amount of the debt, including a breakdown of any interest, fees, or other charges. 
XXXX. Documentation or a copy of the original signed agreement or contract that created this debt, including any amendments or updates. 
XXXX. Proof of your authorization to collect this debt, including any assignment or transfer of the debt to your company. 
XXXX. A detailed payment history, showing any payments or adjustments made to the debt. 
Please consider this letter as a formal request to validate the debt. As required by law, until you provide the requested validation, you must cease all collection efforts on this account, including reporting to credit bureaus. 
I would appreciate a prompt response to this request. If you fail to provide the required documentation, I will consider the debt in dispute, and I expect all collection activities to cease. 
Thank you for your cooperation.

Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative: From XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX fraudulent charges totaling {$900.00} were made on my Bank of America credit card. This card had been inactive for over 1 year, with my last authorized charges occuring in XXXX of XXXX. I noticed these fraudulent charges when my credit monitoring through XXXX XXXX  alerted me to an otherwise inactive account becoming active. On that day, I locked my card and attempted to report the fraudulent charges through the app, however, the app would not allow me to report the charges as fraudulent and notified me that I would need to call the fraud center during business hours. On XX/XX/XXXX, I spoke to the fraud center and reported all of these charges as fraudulent. During that conversation, I noted that I was still in possession of my physical credit card. On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a notice that my claim was denied because the company determined that my physical card was used to make the purchased, and all charges were reinstated on my account. On that same day, I spoke with a banker in person at a Bank of America branch. The fraud department was closed on that day due to it being a holiday weekend, so we were unable to reopen my claim. However, when talking with the banker, we determined that the card I had in my possession had actually expired in XX/XX/XXXX, and I do not have in my possession a new card that was issued at that time. On XX/XX/XXXX I called and spoke with a representative from the fraud department to update them with this information and re-open my claim. I was told at that time that the claim was re-opened. During this process, a new card had been mailed to me ; I never activated this card or unlocked my card through the app. However, on XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX new charged were noted as " pending '' on my account. On XX/XX/XXXX I spoke to the fraud department to report these charges as fraudulent as well and request an update on my original claim for {$900.00}. The new claim was started ( and a temporary credit issued to my account ), but I was told there were no updated on my original claim. All charges made to this account in the year XXXX are fraudulent and in no way authorized by me.

Consumer complaint narrative: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX, XXXX and XXXX do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, XXXX and XXXX ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

Product: Debt or credit management
Consumer complaint narrative:
I received spam mail regarding pre-approved loan for {$35000.00} for debt consolidation. 

I called Lendvia expressing interest in this offer... 

After I agreed for them to do a hard pull on my credit to check if I qualify I got news I didn't qualify, it ended up being a bait and switch... 

3 different agents from Lendvia called me giving me conflicting information ... One agent was telling me everything the other agent said was wrong and got very rude with me ... Every attempt to get clarification resulted in him acting very condescending to me and the other agent... 

I think his name was XXXX or XXXX... 

After this, I told them I was no longer interested and asked them to stop calling me... 

I have received countless calls and XXXX from them literally it started at XXXX per day to now 3 to 6 a day, they eventually sold my PII to XXXX XXXX without my consent or knowledge. 


My PII was then compromised in a cyber security incident... 

I reached out to XXXX telling them they had either obtained my PII illegally or have illegally been provided my information as I never did business with them.nor did I ever sign up for any debt consolidation service. 


I'm still getting calls from Lendvia despite asking them to put me on the do not call list and despite signing up for the FCC no call list multiple times... 

I want Lendvia fined to oblivion for the harassing phone calls, selling my info, and damages suffered as a result... 

I half to keep my phone on silence unknown callers to block the spam calls while I work... This prevents me from receiving call backs from emergency services, management at work, it blocks family emergency calls from school and my families places 's of buinsess, and blocks me from receiving emergency calls from my kid when calling from other lines.. 

Not once was it ever disclosed to me that my PII would be distributed to unsecured third parties.

To Whom It XXXX Concern, I am filing this formal complaint regarding Credence Resource Management, that has violated my rights under federal law. The agency has placed a collection account on my consumer report without providing the legally required validation information as outlined in 12 CFR 1006.34 ( b ) ( 5 ). Furthermore, I have not been given a reasonable opportunity to dispute the account, which violates 12 CFR 1006.34 ( c ) ( 4 ) ( i ).

The actions of Credence Resource Management are in direct violation of my consumer rights. Specifically, they have engaged in false, misleading, and deceptive practices by : 1. Failing to provide the required validation information before furnishing the account to consumer reporting agencies.

2. Furnishing information to consumer reporting agencies without first complying with the disclosure requirements under 12 CFR 1006.34 ( d ).

3. Violating 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 7 ), which governs the responsibilities of furnishers to provide accurate information.

It is both unfair and unlawful for this agency to report this collection account without complying with these regulatory requirements. Their actions undermine my ability to exercise my rights under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ).

I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) investigate this matter promptly. I seek immediate resolution, removal of the inaccurate collection account from my consumer report, and enforcement of compliance with all applicable laws. 

During a recent interaction with a representative, I was informed that this agency was XXXX at first. However, I have since confirmed that they are, in fact, a collection agency, not XXXX  after a phone conversation. This deliberate misrepresentation is both deceptive and unethical. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have a few things on my credit report that are hurting my credit profile. These two accounts are both reporting on my credit profile that were bought out by third party collection agencies, who I did not authorize or consent my personal information to. Because of this error, it is lowering my credit score, and increase derogatory marks on my credit report. I am unable to get any loans at this time and my interest rates are through the roof. National Credit Systems ( Original creditor XXXX XXXX XXXX ) XX/XX/XXXX. 

XX/XX/XXXX National Credit Systems XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Ga XXXX Subject : Notice of Dispute for Improper Communication in Debt Collection Violation of 15 U.S. Code 1692c Dear National Credit Systems, I am writing to formally dispute your recent communications regarding an alleged debt that I am purported to owe. This dispute is in accordance with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), specifically 15 U.S. Code 1692c. 

In your communications dated XX/XX/XXXX of improper communication, you violated my rights as outlined in the FDCPA by : Contacting me at an inconvenient time, specifically XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX. 
Contacting me at my place of employment, despite knowing or having reason to know that my employer prohibits such communications. 
Failing to communicate through my attorney, despite being informed that I am represented by legal counsel. 

These actions are clear violations of the protections provided under 15 U.S. Code 1692c. As a consumer, I am entitled to privacy and fair treatment, and your conduct has been contrary to these legal standards.

I hereby request that you cease all further communication with me, except as legally required, and that you take immediate steps to correct your procedures in compliance with the FDCPA. Any further violations of my rights may result in legal action.

Additionally, I am requesting full validation of the debt, including : 1. Verification of the amount of the debt ; 2. The name of the original creditor ; 3. Any supporting documentation proving that I am liable for this debt.

Please respond in writing to acknowledge receipt of this notice within 30 days. Failure to comply with this request may lead to further actions, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ).

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this formal complaint against XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Capital One for the following violations : Fraudulent Reporting of Charge-Offs as Debt ( IRS Classification of Income ). 
Breach of Fiduciary Duty by Ignoring My Letters and Durable Power of Attorney ( DPOA ). 
Failure to Disclose Securitization of Promissory Notes. 
Non-Compliance with Audit Reporting and GAAP Standards.

Fraudulent Reporting of Charge-Offs as Debt The reporting of charge-offs on my credit report is fraudulent and misleading. According to IRS regulations, charge-offs are classified as income on a 1099-C form when reported to the IRS. Per federal law, income can not be reported as debt on a consumer credit report.

Violation : Reporting charge-offs as debt breaches the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2, which prohibits the reporting of inaccurate information. 

Demand : XXXXXXXX XXXX and Capital One must immediately remove all charge-offs from my credit report as these entries are misleading and harmful to my financial reputation. 
2. Breach of Fiduciary Duty : Ignoring My Letters and Durable Power of Attorney ( DPOA ) I have sent multiple letters asserting my rights, including a Durable Power of Attorney ( DPOA ), which has been ignored by both XXXXXXXX XXXX and Capital One. By failing to respond, these entities have violated their fiduciary obligations and undermined my rights to assert my interest in the credit. 

Legal Precedent : XXXX XXXX XXXX establishes that promissory notes fully fund credit, rendering the consumer the true creditor. As the creditor, I retain rights and interests in the credit and demand acknowledgment of the same. 
Demand : XXXXXXXX XXXX and Capital One must immediately recognize my rights as the creditor and provide a detailed response to all letters and DPOA documents sent. 

XXXX. Failure to Disclose Securitization of Promissory Notes It has come to my attention that the promissory notes I provided to XXXXXXXX XXXX and Capital One were securitized and sold without my knowledge or consent. This failure to disclose constitutes fraud and unjust enrichment. 

Violation : Under 15 U.S.C. 1641 ( Truth in Lending Act - TILA ), lenders are required to disclose the sale, assignment, or transfer of debt instruments to third parties. 

Fraudulent Omission : By securitizing my promissory notes and profiting from the proceeds, without compensating me as the original creditor, XXXXXXXX XXXX and Capital One have committed fraud. 
Demand : Provide full disclosure of the securitization of my promissory notes, including an accounting of proceeds and confirmation that these proceeds have been applied to offset any alleged debt. 

4. Non-Compliance with Audit Reporting and GAAP Standards Under federal law and Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ), financial institutions are required to provide accurate audit reports and account reconciliations.

Legal Obligation : 12 U.S.C. 1831n ( a ) mandates compliance with GAAP standards for all financial institutions.

15 U.S.C. 1637 ( TILA ) requires creditors to provide clear and accurate account information. 
Violation : XXXXXXXX XXXX and Capital One have failed to provide audit reports and reconcile accounts as requested. Their lack of transparency further suggests that the reporting of charge-offs is fraudulent and unsupported by proper accounting practices. 


Formal Opt-Out of Authorization and Illegality of Reporting Transaction History Per the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am formally opting out of any and all authorizations I may have givenwhether written, unwritten, verbal, or non-verbalunder 15 U.S.C. 6802. As a consumer, I have the unequivocal right to opt out of the sharing and use of my non-public personal information ( NPI ) at any time.

By exercising this opt-out right : Unauthorized Reporting is Illegal : Under 15 U.S.C. 6801, it is illegal for financial institutions to report or share my transaction history without my explicit consent. 

The policy of Congress explicitly mandates that every financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to protect the security, confidentiality, and privacy of its customers ' NPI. 
Violation of Privacy Rights : XXXXXXXX XXXX and Capital One and XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX have reported my transaction history and personal information to credit reporting agencies without obtaining my express consent, in direct violation of these statutory obligations.

Product: Checking or savings account
Issue: Problem caused by your funds being low
Consumer complaint narrative:
Back in XXXX I contacted the Department of Finance for NYS attempting to file a claim. I was redirected here, but my letter was sent to Chase ' executive team. I gave them the opportunity to thoroughly address my issue and still there was not a reasonable resolve.

This was the official complaint : I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the consistent overdraft fees that have been assessed to my Chase Performance Business Checking account, despite my adherence to the terms of Chases Overdraft Assist program. 

When I opened this account, I was bringing in $ XXXX to $ XXXX per month through XXXX. The banker who set up my account opened a Chase Performance Business Checking account that required maintaining a daily $ XXXX balance, something I was unaware of at the time. Over the following months, I noticed high charges for service fees, but neither I nor the tellers at my local branch could determine why. Eventually, a telephone banker informed me of the account requirements and explained that I had Overdraft Assist due to the nature of my account, which required me to transfer funds into my account before XXXX XXXX  the next business day to avoid fees. 

Since then, I have been diligently transferring funds before the XXXX XXXX  XXXX  cut-off via instant ACH transfers from XXXX, but I continue to be charged overdraft fees. These transfers reduce my balance to under {$50.00}, which should, according to Chases published terms, exempt me from these fees. 

Here are the specific issues : I have had to call customer service repeatedly over the past few months to request fee reviews. Each time, a supervisor would confirm that I made the transfers on time, and the fees would be reversed, though I was told this was done as a courtesy rather than a correction of a technical issue. 
Recently, I was informed that further fees could not be reversed, and a case was opened. However, I was given no valid explanation for why the fees continue to be applied, despite my compliance with the Overdraft Assist terms.

I have not seen any indication that instant ACH transfers from external sources like XXXX  are exempt from Overdraft Assist, yet I am still incurring fees. This is contradictory to Chases own terms, which state : Chases Published Terms on Overdraft Fees : No Overdraft Fees should be charged if my account is overdrawn by {$50.00} or less at the end of the next business day, or if I transfer funds to bring the balance to {$50.00} or less by XXXX XXXX XXXX 
No Overdraft Fees should apply to transactions under {$5.00} or debit card transactions authorized when sufficient funds were available. 
I have also reviewed the agreement and found nothing excluding instant transfers from external sources. 
This situation has placed an undue financial burden on my business, as I have complied with all terms and have consistently made transfers before the XXXX XXXX  cut-off. Yet, the fees persist, and I am continually told they can not be reversed beyond what has been labeled as courtesy adjustments. 

Given the above, I am respectfully requesting : A full audit of the overdraft fees assessed on my account over the past few months. 
Reimbursement for any fees that were wrongfully applied, despite my adherence to the Overdraft Assist terms.

Clarification on why these fees continue to be assessed despite my timely transfers, as I see no language indicating that external instant transfers are not covered.

This ongoing issue has caused significant financial strain on my business, and I hope for a swift resolution. I trust that Chase will address this matter with the seriousness it deserves. 

Thank you for your attention, and I look forward to your prompt response and resolution. 
-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- I even took a step further to post it on XXXX in case it was me who was mistaken. 
Full Story : I've been a Chase customer for over 20 years, initially for personal banking and now for business. In XXXX, I opened a business checking account at the regular level. By XXXX, a banker upgraded it to Premier Checking, saying it was best for high transaction volume. The account requires a $ XXXX daily balance to avoid monthly fees, which sometimes is a stretch. 

Since the pandemic, Ive noticed substantial monthly fees ( often $ XXXX {$900.00} ) that Chase labels as " service charges. '' I use XXXX for payment processing and only transfer funds into this account to cover rent, vendors, and expenses. 

Heres where it gets confusing : Overdraft Assist Issues : Ive always requested overdraft protection be turned off, so I avoid fees if the balance is low. But I started seeing fees that Chase couldnt explain. Eventually, a rep told me my account has " Overdraft Assist, '' meaning if I transfer funds by XXXX XXXX  the next business day after an overdraft, I should avoid fees. Since then, Ive been meticulous, making transfers well before this cutoff. Still, I see these fees. 

Refunds and Escalations : From XXXX to XXXX, I called Chase each month to review these charges. Theyd usually refund about {$700.00}, as the reps saw Id made my transfers according to policy. In XXXX, the fees hit again, but this time the rep escalated the issue instead of refunding. A Chase executive then called to review the case, but still no resolution. They say Im being charged courtesy fees, but no one can explain why its happening in the first place.

Inconsistent Explanations : Some reps say these fees are due to ACH transfers, others mention high transaction volumes, but nothing in my account terms seems to justify these charges. It doesnt make sense, as my transfers are done before the cutoff, and Im not exceeding any transaction limits. 

Cutoff Confusion : One recent rep claimed theres a XXXX XXXX  cutoff for ACH transfers to avoid fees, but another rep said the cutoff is XXXX XXXX. I make instant transfers from XXXX, which should be nearly immediate, so this shouldnt even apply. 

Ive filed a complaint with the state, and Chases executive team is involved, but they havent given me a clear answer. For now, Im not depositing more money until they reverse the fees and explain why this is happening. 

Question : Am I missing something here, or is this an issue on Chases end? Is anyone else having similar issues with Overdraft Assist or Premier accounts? Im open to any advicethanks in advance for your help! 
-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - Update : After weeks of misinformation, I finally received a vague letter stating the charges were " service fees ''. There was not a breakdown provided for the service fees broken down as requested. I was also recommended to read my service agreement. I have read my agreement back to front and I can not see anywhere where it explains service charges that amount to what I am receiving. I thoroughly believe that Chase has been charging me for overdraft assist because I am transferring from my XXXX account into my Checking account. Even though my available balance and present balance are always in the positive once transferred since it instant, they have been charging me. 

Coincidently, since filing my complaint, all of a sudden the attached messages have shown up on my other Chase business account which is a basic account. My account in the complaint doesn't have the message that conveniently spells out how Overdraft Assist works. It still states that if transferred from an outside account the it may vary, however, again, my present and available balance shows the positive amount from the instant transfer. I have always been transferring in good faith under their rules. I have since stopped transferring funds into the account until a proper resolution happens My account was at a negative {$1400.00}. Majority from fees. This has put me in such a terrible financial position. First, I use my Chase account to pay all of my vendors including my landlord for my business. With the negative balance despite my timely transfers, I had to set up XXXX XXXX with XXXX to make my payments including rent to avoid losing money that I already don't have. I didn't have an extra {$1400.00} to pay in fees.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Escalation of Inquiry Dispute Lack of Verification Provided Dear TransUnion Dispute Department, I appreciate your response regarding the inquiries on my credit report, but the explanation provided does not resolve my dispute. The inquiries listed below remain on my report despite my assertion that they were unauthorized, and you have not provided any evidence to support their validity. 

Disputed Inquiries XXXX. XXXX Reported on XX/XX/year> XXXX. XXXX XXXX Reported on XX/XX/year> XXXX. XXXX XXXX  XXXX Reported on XX/XX/year> XXXX. XXXX XXXX Reported on XX/XX/year> Violations of the FCRA 1. Failure to Verify Authorization ( FCRA 1681i ( a ) ) Under the FCRA, you are required to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation and verify whether these inquiries were authorized or had a permissible purpose. Your response did not include any such verification or documentation. 
2. Burden of Proof on the Furnisher ( FCRA 1681b ) A company must demonstrate a legitimate business need or permissible purpose to access my credit report. Without providing documentation or proof of my authorization, these inquiries should not remain on my credit report.

Requested Actions 1. Provide Verification Documentation : If these inquiries are valid, I request documentation proving my authorization ( e.g., signed applications, account details ).

2. Immediate Deletion of Unauthorized Inquiries : If such proof can not be provided, these inquiries must be removed immediately. 

Supporting Documentation 1. A copy of your original response ( dated XX/XX/year> ) referencing this matter. 
2. My original dispute highlighting the unauthorized inquiries.

Your Responsibility As required under the FCRA, you must resolve this dispute within 30 days and provide a clear resolution, including either verification of the inquiries or confirmation of their deletion. Consumer complaint narrative:
Complainant : XXXX XXXX Subject : Failure by XXXX TransUnion and XXXX to Honor Identification and Power of Attorney Documents -- - Introduction : This complaint is filed to address multiple violations of federal laws by XXXX, which has failed to process my disputes regarding the inaccurate reporting of rescinded accounts. Despite submitting all required documentation, including a valid Power of Attorney ( POA ), identification, and Social Security information, XXXX has falsely claimed that my identification documents were insufficient or illegible. This baseless rejection constitutes a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and undermines the legal validity of my disputes and rescission of signature. 


-- - Background Information : XXXX. Accounts in Dispute : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX : {$12000.00} Opened : XX/XX/year> Past Due Amount : {$350.00} XXXX. Submission of Documentation : In accordance with 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), I submitted disputes to Transunion XXXX XXXX XXXX, asserting that these accounts are inaccurate because they were rescinded under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). As part of my disputes, I provided the following : A certified mail receipt from Transunion A mailing response from XXXX A notarized Power of Attorney document. 

A copy of my valid government-issued identification. 



XXXX. XXXX 's Response : issued a response stating that my identification documents were insufficient or illegible, despite my compliance with their requirements. This is a deliberate misrepresentation of the facts, designed to avoid their obligation to investigate and correct the disputed information under the FCRA. 


Violations : XXXX. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Investigation : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), XXXX TransUnion and XXXX is required to conduct a reasonable investigation when a consumer disputes the accuracy of information. By rejecting my valid documentation, XXXX has failed to meet this obligation. 

Failure to Notify Furnishers : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( XXXX ), XXXX TransUnion and XXXX is required to notify creditors of the dispute. Their baseless rejection of my documentation effectively obstructed this process. 

Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( b ), XXXX XXXX TransUnion must ensure that the information reported is accurate. Reporting rescinded accounts as open is a clear violation of this provision. 



XXXX. Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : Non-Compliance with Rescission Provisions : The accounts in question were rescinded in compliance with 15 U.S.C. 1635, which nullifies any legal obligations tied to the accounts. XXXX refusal to correct this inaccurate reporting violates my rights under XXXX. 



XXXX. Consumer Protection Violations : Obstruction of Legal Process : By rejecting my Power of Attorney and associated documentation, XXXX has obstructed the legal process, preventing me from exercising my rights to dispute and correct inaccurate information. 

Failure to Recognize Legal Authority of Power of Attorney : The Power of Attorney submitted in support of my disputes is a legal instrument granting authority to act on behalf of the principal. XXXX failure to honor this document violates well-established legal principles. 





-- - Conclusion : XXXX  TransUnion and XXXX actions constitute serious violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, Truth in Lending Act, and other federal protections. Their failure to honor valid identification and legal documentation is unacceptable and undermines the integrity of consumer rights. This complaint seeks accountability for these violations and correction of the ongoing issues regarding the disputed accounts. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this formal complaint against American Express and XXXX XXXX  for their egregious violations of federal laws, fraudulent reporting of charged-off accounts, and deceptive practices regarding the handling of my promissory notes. Their actions include, but are not limited to, reporting inaccurate debts, failing to disclose the securitization of my promissory notes, and depriving me of my rightful claims and interests as the creditor. 

XXXX. Fraudulent Reporting of Charged-Off Accounts American Express and XXXX XXXX  have unlawfully reported charged-off accounts to credit reporting agencies. Charged-off accounts, when reported to the IRS via 1099-C forms, are classified as income under federal tax law. However, income is not a permissible category for inclusion on a consumer credit report under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681.

Violation : By continuing to report these accounts as outstanding debt on my credit report, American Express and XXXX XXXX  have breached the FCRA, specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ), which prohibits the inclusion of inaccurate and impermissible information. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) : The court emphasized that debts reported inaccurately or without validation are unlawful. 
XXXX v. XXXX. XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX Cir. XXXX ) : Misleading credit reporting violates the FCRA and FDCPA. 
XXXX. Breach of Contract : Securitization and Non-Disclosure Both American Express and XXXX XXXX  engaged in the securitization of my promissory notes without my knowledge or consent. Securitization involves selling or transferring the promissory note as an asset, generating proceeds that are not disclosed or applied to offset the alleged debt. 

Violation : Non-Disclosure : Failing to disclose the sale and securitization of my promissory note constitutes fraud and a breach of their duty of good faith and fair dealing. 
No Consideration : As the issuer of the promissory note, I am the creditor and provided the initial value through my signature and agreement. Because I was not compensated for the securitization, there is no outstanding debt owed. 
Proceeds from Sale : The proceeds from the sale of the promissory note must be applied to extinguish any alleged debt. By withholding these funds, American Express and XXXX XXXX  are unjustly enriching themselves at my expense. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX : Establishes that a promissory note fully funds the transaction, making the issuer of the note the creditor. Any subsequent sale or securitization of the note is subject to full disclosure and proper accounting to the original issuer. 
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) : Reiterates that the promissory note is the principal obligation, and its assignment must be fully disclosed. 
XXXX. Fraudulent Concealment of Securitization Proceeds American Express and XXXX XXXX  knowingly concealed the securitization of my promissory notes and the proceeds generated from their sale. This fraudulent concealment violates federal and state laws and nullifies any claim that there is a debt owed. 
Legal Basis : UCC 3-305 : Affirmative defenses include failure of consideration and fraud in the inducement.

Restatement ( Second ) of Contracts, 161 : Non-disclosure of material facts constitutes fraud.

4. Claiming My Rights and Interests as the Creditor As the issuer of the promissory notes, I am the creditor and have rights to the proceeds and interests generated from the securitization. By failing to compensate me for these proceeds or properly account for them, American Express and XXXX XXXX  have violated my rights under contract law and federal statutes. 

XXXX. Failure to Provide Audit Reports and XXXX Documentation American Express and XXXX XXXX  have XXXX failed to comply with their legal obligation to provide an accurate audit report and records in compliance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ). These reports are critical to ensuring transparency and validating the legitimacy of any claims regarding an alleged debt. 

Legal Obligations Under Federal Law Requirement for GAAP-Compliant Audit Reports Under 15 U.S.C. 78m ( Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ), financial institutions are required to maintain accurate books and records and provide GAAP-compliant audit reports to substantiate any financial transactions. 
Failure to provide such documentation is a violation of federal law and raises concerns about the legitimacy of the alleged debt and the reporting of such debt.

Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) Violations 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. ( TILA ) : Lenders are required to disclose all terms, conditions, and costs associated with a credit transaction. This includes providing clear and accurate accounting of any amounts owed, offsets applied, and proceeds generated through securitization. 
American Express and XXXX XXXX  have violated TILA by failing to disclose : The securitization of my promissory note. 
The proceeds derived from the sale or transfer of the note. 
The application ( or lack thereof ) of those proceeds to offset the alleged debt. 
Demand for Full Audit and Disclosure Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1639 ( g ) ( TILA ), creditors are required to maintain and disclose accurate records regarding the origination, transfer, and securitization of loans. I hereby demand : A GAAP-Compliant Audit Report Provide a detailed audit of the alleged account, including : The original promissory note. 
Records of any transfers, sales, or securitizations.

Proceeds generated from such transactions and their application.

Validation of Debt Supply documentation that validates the existence of the alleged debt under the provisions of 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( FDCPA ).

Any failure to provide these records will be considered evidence that the debt is not valid and that reporting such a debt constitutes fraud.

Application of Securitization Proceeds Provide a detailed accounting of all proceeds from the securitization of the promissory note and how those proceeds were applied to offset any alleged balance.

Failure to Comply and Consequences The refusal or failure to provide these legally required disclosures and audit reports constitutes a breach of federal law and fiduciary duty. It also undermines the principles of transparency and accountability mandated by GAAP and federal statutes.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the accuracy of an account reported by XXXX XXXX on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate, complete, and verifiable credit reporting. Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I have the right to be free from misleading or unauthorized debt collection practices. Below are the issues I have identified : 1. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : The Account Type - Detail is listed differently across bureaus, with TransUnion stating Unknown - credit extension, review, or collection, and XXXX reporting Collection. This inconsistency violates 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). 
XXXX. Improper Dispute Status : The comments from XXXX and XXXX state that the account is disputed. If this dispute has been resolved or if the reporting is incorrect, this information must be updated or removed. 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Reporting : The Date Last Active is listed as XX/XX/year>. If no activity has occurred since then, the account may exceed the seven-year reporting limit, per 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ). 
4. Lack of Verification and Payment History : The report does not provide any detailed payment history or verification of how the account reached Collection/Chargeoff status. 
XXXX. Unauthorized Transfer of Debt : I did not authorize payments to XXXX XXXX or agree to the transfer of this debt. Reporting this without my consent may violate the FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ). 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and FDCPA : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure that the information they report is accurate and consistent. The discrepancies in account descriptions and comments violate this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Negative information, such as collections, must not be reported more than seven years from the date of first delinquency. 
3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If you disputed the account and it remains unresolved or improperly updated, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate properly.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor or collection agency may have provided inaccurate or unverifiable information.

5. FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : False or Misleading Representations : Reporting this debt without proper verification or authorization from you to collect or transfer the debt may violate the FDCPA.

Enclosed with this letter, please find copies of my credit report highlighting the disputed inquiries, along with any supporting documentation that may aid in your investigation.

I appreciate your attention to this dispute and anticipate confirmation of the removal of these unauthorized inquiries from my credit report within the stipulated timeframe. 

Thank you for your prompt assistance in resolving this matter.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute several unauthorized hard inquiries appearing on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), credit inquiries XXXX only be made with my explicit consent or when otherwise permitted by law. I have reviewed my credit report and found the following inquiries that I did not authorize. picture have been unloaded Under Section 604 of the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), a consumer reporting agency XXXX only provide a credit report for permissible purposes, such as a legitimate credit transaction that the consumer initiated. These inquiries were not authorized by me, and I am requesting their immediate removal as they violate this provision. 

XXXX. Section 607 ( b ) : Maximum Possible Accuracy Credit bureaus must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information included in a consumer report. This applies to all types of data, including inquiries.

2. Section 611 : Dispute Process Consumers have the right to dispute any inaccurate or incomplete information in their credit report, including unauthorized or incorrect credit inquiries. Credit bureaus must investigate disputes within 30 days and delete or correct any unverifiable or inaccurate information.

3. Section 604 : Permissible Purpose Inquiries must have a legitimate purpose and be authorized by the consumer or permissible under the law ( e.g., for a credit application, insurance underwriting, or employment ). If inquiries appear on your credit report without authorization, they violate this section.

4. Section 609 : Disclosure to Consumers Credit bureaus must provide consumers with a list of all entities that accessed their credit file, including inquiries. Consumers can request details on why their credit report was accessed and by whom.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This complaint addresses serious and egregious violations of federal law committed by TransUnion, XXXX, XXXX ( the Credit Reporting Agencies or CRAs ), and XXXXXXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX regarding their mishandling and unlawful reporting of my personal data, privacy breaches, and fraudulent classification of charged-off debts. Their actions not only infringe upon my statutory rights but also cause significant harm to my financial well-being and reputation. 


Failure to Honor Opt-Out Rights Under FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802 ) Under 15 U.S.C. 6802, consumers have the right to opt out of the sharing of non-public personal information ( NPI ). I am formally opting out of any prior or assumed authorizationswritten, verbal, implied, or otherwisegranted to the CRAs or XXXX And XXXX XXXX to use or share my data. Despite this clear directive, these entities have willfully disregarded my right to privacy by continuing to disseminate my XXXX without consent. 


2. Violations of the Privacy Act of 1974 The Privacy Act of 1974 mandates that entities handling personal information must notify individuals of its use and provide them with a meaningful opportunity to restrict or control its dissemination. 

Violation : TransUnion, XXXX, XXXX, along with XXXXXXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX failed to notify me of how my personal information was being shared with third parties and denied me the ability to opt out of these unauthorized disclosures. 
Impact : This lack of transparency infringes upon my fundamental rights to control the use of my personal data. 


XXXX. Illegal Reporting of Charged-Off Debts as Income ( 15 U.S.C. 6801 ) Charged-off debts reported to the IRS via a 1099-C are reclassified as income under federal tax law. Income, however, is not permissible for inclusion on a consumer credit report under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). TransUnion, XXXX, XXXX, and [ Bank Names ] are knowingly violating federal law by falsely reporting charged-off debts as derogatory items instead of removing them as required. 

Violation : The continued reporting of charged-off debts as derogatory trade lines violates 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ), which governs the permissible content of consumer reports. 
Case Law : In XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, the court confirmed that debts reported inaccurately or without proper validation are unlawful under the FCRA. This precedent underscores that creditors and CRAs must remove such items promptly. 
Impact : This misclassification harms my creditworthiness and exposes me to undue financial hardship and damage. 



4.Negligence and Gross Misconduct by Each Bank and CRA Each of the following entities has engaged in illegal reporting and privacy violations : XXXX AND XXXX : Refused to validate a charged-off debt and continued reporting it despite being reclassified as income. 



TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX : Complicit in reporting unvalidated, inaccurate, and impermissible information, including charged-off debts and transaction histories without my authorization. 



The actions of TransUnion, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX and XXXX XXXX violate the following federal statutes and case law precedents : Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 15 U.S.C. 16811681x.

Privacy Act of 1974 : Public Law 93-579. 
Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) : 15 U.S.C. 68016809. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) : Addressing unlawful debt reporting practices. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) : Highlighting the illegality of misleading credit reports.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
To : Credit Reporting Agency Subject : Request for Removal of Unverifiable Account Dear Credit Reporting Department, I am writing to formally request the removal of an account from my credit report as reported by [ XXXX, XXXX, or TransUnion ]. This request is based on the recent deletion of an account by XXXX, one of the four major credit reporting agencies. I recently disputed a charge-off for {$25000.00} from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX , listed on my XXXX report, and following a thorough investigation, XXXX has completely deleted this unverifiable debt from my report as of XX/XX/year>. 
According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ), all consumer reporting agencies must ensure that information in consumer reports is accurate, fair, and verifiable. Since XXXX has removed this account after its verification process, I request that you do the same and remove this unverifiable account from my credit report. 
Supporting Consumer Laws : FCRA Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires that inaccurate or unverifiable information must be deleted from a consumer 's credit file. I am exercising my right to ensure that my credit report remains fair, accurate, and free of unverifiable information. Since XXXX has deemed this account unverifiable and removed it, you must take similar action. 
Additionally, under FCRA Section 623 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ), information suppliers must report only complete and accurate information. With XXXX having deemed this information unverifiable, I urge you to align its records accordingly. 
Please provide confirmation of this removal within 30 days of receipt of this request. If the account is not removed, I am prepared to pursue further actions, including filing a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and seeking legal action under the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), including Section 616 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681n ), which allows consumers to seek legal recourse for willful noncompliance, and Section 617 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681o ) for negligent non-compliance. 
I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter, as it directly impacts my credit reports integrity. Please notify me in writing once this deletion has been processed. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this request. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am disputing the accuracy of an account listed on my credit report under XXXX XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to dispute incomplete or inaccurate information. After reviewing my report, I identified the following issues with this account : XXXX. Inconsistent Account Reporting Across Bureaus : The account is listed under XXXX, but there is no reporting in TransUnion or XXXX. This inconsistency can misrepresent the consumers creditworthiness. 
XXXX. Improper Collection Account Reporting : The payment history under XXXX shows OK for all months, but the account is marked as Collection with a status of Late 120 Days and a balance of {$580.00}. This is contradictory and could indicate an error. 
XXXX. Failure to Update Dispute Status : The comments section states : Consumer disputes this account information, yet the account is still reported as Derogatory without clear resolution or updates. If the dispute was resolved, this status should be updated or removed. 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Reporting : The Date of Last Payment is listed as XX/XX/2018, and the Date Last Active is also XX/XX/2018. Negative information such as collections must generally be removed after seven years from the date of the first delinquency, per FCRA guidelines ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ).

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must maintain accurate and consistent reporting. The contradiction between OK payment history and the account being in Collection with 120 Days Late status violates this requirement.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Conduct a Proper Investigation : If the account has been disputed and the information remains inaccurate, this indicates a failure to investigate and correct errors.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : If the accounts delinquency began in 2018, it may now be obsolete. Such information must be removed after seven years.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor ( XXXX ) may be inaccurately reporting this collection account, particularly if it remains in dispute or contradicts the payment history.

Consumer complaint narrative: Subject : Dispute of Unauthorized Inquiries on My Credit Report Dear Sir/Madam : I am writing to dispute certain inquiries on my credit report that I believe to be unauthorized and therefore incorrect. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to have only accurate, verified, and authorized information on my credit report. I am requesting the removal of these inquiries from my report as I did not explicitly authorize any of them. Details of the Disputed Inquiries : Requesting Entities : XXXX Inquiry Dates : XXXX XXXX XXXX Entities : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXX XXXX XXXX Dates : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXX Inquiry Dates : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXXXXXX XXXX Inquiry Dates : XX/XX/XXXX Requesting Entities : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Dates : XXXX XXXX Legal Basis under the FCRA for Removal of Unauthorized Inquiries : 1. Right to Accuracy and Verification of Information ( FCRA 611 ) : Under section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of the FCRA, I have the right to dispute any information that is inaccurate or unverified. I am requesting that you review and verify the legitimacy of these inquiries, and if you can not do so, immediately remove these entries from my credit report. 2. Obligation to Provide Proof of Authorization ( FCRA 609 ) : According to section 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) of the FCRA, I have the right to obtain all information in my file that is relevant to the inquiries conducted, including any evidence that I explicitly consented. I request that you provide this proof of authorization ; in the absence of it, these inquiries should be removed accordingly. 3. Protection Against Identity Theft and Fraud ( FCRA 605B ) : In the event that any of these inquiries are related to identity theft, section 605B of the FCRA requires you to block all information derived from such fraud upon notification. This letter serves as formal notice that none of these inquiries were authorized by me and could potentially be the result of fraud. Furthermore, I want to emphasize that, in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I do not authorize this dispute to be processed using the e-OSCAR automated system. Since this dispute concerns unauthorized information, it requires a complete manual review to ensure compliance with my rights to verification and accuracy of information. Thank you for your attention to this request. I look forward to receiving a written response within 15 days, as stipulated by the FCRA. Please keep me informed of any progress in the investigation process. Sincerely,

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XX/XX/2023 These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally request the removal of a fraudulent account from my credit report and to exercise my legal right to opt out of your reporting services in relation to this matter. 

As outlined in the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681, consumer reporting agencies such as XXXX and XXXX are required to handle consumer data with fairness, impartiality, and respect for the consumer 's privacy. This includes ensuring that no consumer information is reported without explicit consent. 

The XXXX XXXX, 15 U.S.C. 6801, further protects my personal information, mandating that financial institutions and those who furnish information to credit reporting agencies must respect my privacy and the confidentiality of my nonpublic personal information. I have not provided consent to either XXXX or XXXX to share my personal data or information related to any accounts opened in my name, including the disputed XXXX account. 

Furthermore, 15 U.S.C. 1681b and 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) prohibit the reporting of certain adverse information beyond a specified period, and require consumer consent to furnish data to credit agencies. Since I did not authorize the creation of the XXXX account in question, the account is an unlawful and unauthorized entry on my credit report. 

Additionally, 15 U.S.C. 1681s2 ( a ) ( 1 ) clearly states that no person may report inaccurate information to a consumer reporting agency if they know, or have reasonable cause to believe, that the information is incorrect. Since I did not authorize the account and it appears to be fraudulent, the furnisher of information has violated this requirement. 

As a consumer, I am also exercising my right to opt out of your reporting services. Under 12 C.F.R. 1016.7, I have the right to opt out of having my information shared with third parties, and I am exercising that right immediately. 

I request that the fraudulent account associated with XXXX XXXX be removed from my credit report, as it was opened without my knowledge or consent. I further request that you confirm in writing that the necessary corrections have been made. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. Please provide written confirmation that this account has been removed and that my privacy rights have been upheld in accordance with federal law.

Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing to file a formal complaint against XXXX, TransUnion and XXXX for failing to comply with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically under 15 U.S.C. 1681i and 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). The following account show inaccuracies Account Name : XXXX XXXX ( Account Number : XXXX ) Despite providing evidence that late payment entries on my credit report are inaccurate, the credit bureaus have not corrected or removed these items. On XX/XX/2024, I disputed the inaccuracies with both CRAs, providing supporting documentation, including bank statements and payment receipts. However, the CRAs failed to investigate the dispute properly, did not verify the accuracy of the information, and did not remove the erroneous late payments as required under 15 U.S.C. 1681i. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), the CRAs are required to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information reported on my credit file. By failing to correct the false late payment information, they have violated this obligation, which has harmed my creditworthiness. I request that the CFPB intervene to ensure that the CRAs fulfill their duties under the FCRA, correct the inaccuracies, anc remove the disputed items from my credit report. I trust that the CFPB will take appropriate action to resolve this matter and protect my consumer rights. Thank you for your attention to this issue. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XX/XX/2024

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this formal complaint regarding the unlawful and improper practices of TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX ( collectively referred to as the " Credit Reporting Agencies '' or " CRAs '' ) related to the illegal reporting of my transaction history. Below, I detail the specific issues and violations of federal law : I am formally opting out of any and all authorizations I may have givenwhether written, verbal, unwritten, or impliedfor the XXXX to share reporting of my transaction history Under XXXX XXXX. XXXX, financial institutions and their agents are bound by an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy and confidentiality of consumers ' non-public personal information. Reporting transaction history without explicit consent violates this statute. 

Violation : XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX have engaged in the unauthorized reporting of my transaction history, which is illegal without my consent. 

Impact : This unauthorized action directly undermines the Congressional mandate for safeguarding consumer privacy, as outlined in the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act and its supporting provisions under the FCRA Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 15 U.S.C. 6801 Unlawful Reporting of Charged-Off Debt as Income Under federal law, charged-off debts are considered income for tax purposes when reported to the IRS via a XXXX XXXX. However, income is not a permissible category for reporting on consumer credit reports under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The FCRA and related case law establish that consumer credit reports must only contain accurate and permissible information directly related to creditworthiness, not income classifications. 

Violation : TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX are unlawfully reporting charged-off debts as derogatory trade lines on my credit report despite their reclassification as " income '' under IRS regulations XXXX This constitutes a clear violation of the FCRA because income, especially income derived from forgiven debt, is not authorized for inclusion in consumer credit reporting. 

Supporting Legal Precedents : XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( a ) : Restricts the type of information that can appear on a consumer report. 
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) : Emphasized that misleading information on credit reports can violate the FCRA. 
XXXX XXXX Trans Union XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : Highlighted the importance of accurate classification of debt in credit reporting. 
Impact : The misreporting of charged-off debt as a derogatory item when it should be classified as income causes severe harm to my credit profile and undermines my creditworthiness. Additionally, it subjects me to undue financial and reputational harm by inaccurately portraying my financial behavior.

The company has been notified by this several times. Several disputes has been made to the credit bureau to fix the error. The wrong account being processed as resulted in several NSF fees being charged from the finance company and XXXX XXXX. No funds had been refunded from the finance company side. This issue has caused my XXXX XXXX to drop XXXX points on XX/XX/XXXX. 

I was also told its a 10 day grace period on late payments for NC and payment must be made before XXXX XXXX  to process the same day. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, IL XXXX Report Number : XXXX Date Generated : XX/XX/year> Subject : Request for Validation of Alleged Debt Pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Dear [ Debt Collectors Name or To Whom It May Concern ], I am writing regarding the alleged debt associated with the above-referenced account. As this matter impacts my creditworthiness and personal information, I am disputing the validity of this debt and formally requesting debt validation under 15 U.S.C. 1692g of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 

Specific Issues The information associated with my credit report includes multiple inaccuracies and unverified details. Below is a summary of my correct information and the discrepancies that require immediate attention : Correct Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, IL XXXX Other Address History : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, IL XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, IL XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, IL XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, IL XXXX Employment Information : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, IL Name Variations : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Validation Request : Please provide the following documentation to validate the alleged debt : A signed agreement or contract proving my obligation to this debt. 
An itemized breakdown of the debt ( principal, interest, fees, etc. ). 
Proof that you are legally authorized to collect this debt on behalf of the original creditor. 
Impact on My Credit Report : If this debt can not be validated, you are instructed to : Cease all collection activity immediately. 
Request the removal of any associated negative information from XXXX, XXXX, and TransUnion. 
Correct or update any inaccurate address, name, or employer information listed on my credit report. 
Legal Considerations Failure to validate this debt within 30 days of receipt of this certified letter will result in legal action under : FDCPA 807 [ 15 U.S.C. 1692e ], for false or misleading representations.

Fair Credit Reporting Act [ 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) ], for reporting unverifiable or inaccurate information.

I will pursue damages of up to {$5000.00} in small claims court for : Defamation resulting from inaccurate credit reporting.

Negligent enablement of identity fraud.

Violations of consumer protection laws.

Immediate Action Required You are required to : Provide a written response with the requested validation documents. 
Cease all credit reporting and collection activities pending resolution. 
This letter is an effort to resolve the matter amicably and correct inaccuracies. It does not constitute an acknowledgment of the debt or a waiver of any rights. Please direct your response and any questions to my address above. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

I have received a copy on my consumer reports and I notice you have furnished transactions on my consumer report that is excluded by law as per the FCRA 15 USC 1681a 2Ai.

( 2 ) Exclusions.Except as provided in paragraph ( 3 ), the term consumer report does not include ( i ) report containing information solely as to transactions or experiences between theconsumerand thepersonmaking the report ; A consumers transactions are excluded from the consumer reports. XXXX  and or any other Risk score or algorithm that you use to calculate a consumers credit score is not a factor where the consumer report is concerned! Definition of what the consumer report means. 
consumer report ( 1 ) In general. The term consumer report means any written, oral, or other communication of any information by a consumer reporting agency bearing on a consumers credit worthiness, credit standing, credit capacity, character, general reputation, personal characteristics, or mode of living which is used or expected to be used or collected in whole or in part for the purpose of serving as a factor in establishing the consumers eligibility for ( A ) credit or insurance to be used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes ; ( B ) employment purposes ; or ( C ) any other purpose authorized under section 1681b of this title. 
XXXX or non of its factors are not defined or included in the definition of the consumer report! Therefore the reporting of transactions between the consumer ( XXXX ) and XXXX is a violation of 15 USC 1681a the definition of the consumer report does not include XXXX or XXXX which makes their factors or algorithm not a factor where the consumer report is concerned. 
It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 

You have furnished transaction information on the following accounts. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX late payments dates of XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX My account with XXXX was never late! This was clearly a billing error, and a double dipping scheme. Your truly XXXX XXXX
