Consumer complaint narrative:
I am reaching out to formally lodge a complaint regarding unauthorized hard inquiries listed on my credit report, which violate my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and other applicable laws. The following hard inquiries are present on my credit report without my explicit consent or authorization : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX According to 15 U.S.C. 1602 ( p ), any access to a consumer 's credit report must have a permissible purpose that is clearly established and authorized by the consumer. These inquiries were made without my explicit permission, constituting unauthorized access to my credit information. Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2, I am requesting the immediate removal of these inquiries from my credit report. This provision allows consumers to have unauthorized or fraudulent inquiries removed to uphold the accuracy and integrity of their credit information.

The unauthorized hard inquiries are adversely affecting my credit score and causing unwarranted harm to my financial standing. Despite my attempts to address this issue with the relevant entities, a satisfactory resolution has not been reached. Therefore, I am requesting the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) to take the following actions : 1. Investigate the inclusion of these unauthorized inquiries on my credit report to ascertain their proper authorization.

2. Ensure the swift removal of the unauthorized hard inquiries from my credit report.

3. Hold the responsible parties accountable for breaching my rights under the FCRA. 
I thank you for your prompt attention to this matter and kindly request that you provide updates on the progress of your investigation.

I looked at my TransUnion credit report on XX/XX/year> and noticed some things are incomplete and not accurate. And according to the fair credit reporting act Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ). And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer. and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are suppose to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my extreme dissatisfaction and concern regarding the unresolved status of my previous dispute about unauthorized inquiries on my credit report, which I submitted on XX/XX/year>, followed XXXX and followed up on XX/XX/year>. This is my final attempt to resolve this matter amicably. I demand an immediate resolution in accordance with my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ), and 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ). 
Unauthorized Inquiries in Question XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/scrub>XXXX  Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires an immediate investigation of disputed information. It has been more than 30 days since my initial dispute, and I have yet to receive an adequate resolution, which is unacceptable. 
Section 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ) entitles me to access all information in my file, including the results of your investigation. To date, I have not received the required information, which constitutes a violation of my rights.

Section 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ) defines the permissible purposes for obtaining credit reports. These inquiries were made without my consent and do not meet any permissible purpose under this section, representing a serious infraction. 
Immediate Action Required I demand immediate action to resolve this dispute. Specifically, I request the following : 1. Thorough and Immediate Reinvestigation : Conduct a complete and urgent reinvestigation of the unauthorized inquiries.

2. Immediate Removal of Unauthorized Inquiries : Remove any inquiries found to be unauthorized from my credit report without delay.

3. Updated Credit Report : Provide me with an updated copy of my credit report reflecting these changes immediately.

4. Detailed and Documented Notification : Inform me in detail of the steps taken and the results of your investigation within 15 days of receipt of this letter. Include documentation supporting your actions. 
Warning of Legal Action If I do not receive a satisfactory resolution within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this issue to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and proceed with legal action to protect my rights as a consumer. I will not hesitate to seek compensation for any damages resulting from your failure to adequately resolve this matter. 
I expect your immediate response and resolution to this issue.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am disputing inaccuracies on my credit report concerning an account reported by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to accurate, complete, and verifiable reporting. I have identified the following issues with this account : Identified Issues : XXXX. Inconsistent Comments Across Credit Bureaus : TransUnion : Dispute resolved ; customer disagrees. 
XXXX : Subscriber reports dispute resolved - consumer disagrees. 
XXXX : Consumer disputes after resolution ; closed or paid account/XXXX  balance. 
These inconsistent comments create confusion for lenders and may indicate unresolved disputes, despite the account being paid and closed.

2. Late Payment Reporting on a Closed Account : The payment history shows multiple 30-day late marks for a closed account with a {$0.00} balance. If the account is resolved and paid off, such marks should not appear unless accurate and verified.

3. Failure to Properly Update or Remove Dispute Comments : If the dispute is resolved, the comments section should reflect this. Leaving dispute-related remarks misrepresents the accounts current status. 
XXXX. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : XXXX uses inconsistent terms, reporting Closed or paid account/zero balance, while others simply state Closed or Paid. 
5. Inaccurate Reporting of Payment History : The presence of 30-day late marks on all three bureaus payment history while the account is current, paid, and closed with a {$0.00} balance could be misleading. 
Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure accuracy and consistency in reporting. The discrepancies in dispute comments and payment history violate this requirement.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Conduct a Proper Investigation : If the dispute was resolved and the information remains incorrect, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate and correct the errors properly.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor ( XXXX XXXX ) may be furnishing inaccurate or misleading information regarding payment history and dispute resolution.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Late payments or dispute comments may be obsolete and improperly retained beyond the allowable reporting period.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Correction to Previous TransUnion Dispute Request of Inaccurate and Unauthorized Information. New Request to Include The Removal of Late Payments and Inquiries. 

I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate and unauthorized information appearing on my TransUnion credit report. These accounts were added due to a data breach and are not authorized or representative of my financial history. I request immediate investigation and removal of the following accounts from my credit report : XXXX. XXXX XXXX Account XXXX : XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX Account XXXX : XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX Account XXXX : XXXX XXXX. XXXX Account XXXX : XXXX I request corrections for the following accounts due to inaccurate reporting of late payments. These accounts should not be closed, but the late payment entries must be removed : XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Account XXXX : XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX Account XXXX : XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Account XXXX : XXXX Pursuant to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I assert the following rights and request specific actions to address this issue : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( FCRA 611 ) : I request that the disputed information be investigated and verified as accurate. If the disputed accounts can not be verified, they must be deleted from my credit report.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ( FCRA 607 ) : TransUnion is obligated to ensure maximum possible accuracy in reporting my credit information. These accounts are inaccurate and result from identity theft or misreporting tied to the referenced data breach.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ( FCRA 605A ( b ) ) : I request that these fraudulent items be removed as they stem from a breach of my personal data.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681g ( FCRA 609 ) : I request access to all documentation, records, and communications related to the inclusion of these accounts on my credit report.

Given the widespread data breaches that have affected financial institutions and compromised consumers ' sensitive information, I believe these accounts may have been fraudulently opened or erroneously reported. I demand that these accounts be thoroughly investigated in compliance with FCRA requirements and deleted from my credit report if found unverifiable or inaccurate.

Additionally, under the Federal Trade Commission Act ( 15 U.S.C. 45 ), it is illegal for businesses to engage in unfair or deceptive practices. Reporting inaccurate or fraudulent accounts on my credit report due to negligence in protecting consumer data constitutes a violation of this statute. 

I have attached all relevant documents to support this dispute, including copies of my TransUnion credit report highlighting the disputed accounts.

Subject : Dispute and Request to Update Personal Information Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to dispute and request an update to my personal information in your records. I recently obtained a copy of my credit report and discovered that some of the personal information listed is inaccurate or outdated. I kindly request that you investigate and make the necessary updates to ensure the accuracy and integrity of my credit profile. 

Please find below the specific details of the incorrect or outdated information : 1. Name : My current legal name is [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ], but it is listed incorrectly on my credit report as [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ]. I request that my name be updated to reflect the correct information. 
2. Address : My current residential address is [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX fl XXXX ], but my credit report shows an outdated address as [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX fl XXXX ] I request that my current address be updated accordingly. 
3. Contact Information : The phone number listed on my credit report, [ XXXX ], is no longer in use. I request that my new phone number, [ XXXX ], be updated as my primary contact number. 
I have enclosed copies of supporting documents to verify the accurate information provided above. The documents include : A copy of my driver 's license or passport displaying my correct name. 
A recent utility bill or bank statement showing my current address. 
A copy of my phone bill or any other official document that displays my correct phone number. 

Additionally, please provide me with a written confirmation once the updates have been made, and send me an updated copy of my credit report reflecting the changes. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter. Should you require any further information or documentation, please do not hesitate to contact me at [ XXXX ] or via email at XXXX. Thank you for your cooperation. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: I sent certified mail to the Credit reporting agency to investigate incorrect, invalid, and impermissible information pertaining to my credit report regarding a XXXX  XXXX account with the account number - XXXX. After conducting a full investigation I was told the referred account has not been changed and will remain on my credit report. Earlier this year I made a complaint to the CFPB about this same company furnishing all of this invalidated data without my written consent. Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding an alleged debt from XXXX that is being reported on my credit report and pursued by a collection agency. Despite multiple attempts on my part to obtain proper validation of this debt, as required by federal law, the collection agency has failed to provide the necessary documentation.

Under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ), consumers have the right to request validation of any alleged debt within 30 days of being contacted by a debt collector. Validation must include clear evidence that the debt is valid, including details about the original creditor, the amount owed, and documentation showing that the debt is connected to the consumer. To date, no proper validation has been provided for this alleged XXXX debt. 

Furthermore, the continued reporting of this unvalidated debt by the credit reporting agencies violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), which mandates that consumer reporting agencies ensure the accuracy and integrity of the information they report. Reporting an unvalidated debt constitutes inaccurate and unfair reporting, causing harm to my credit profile.

Requested Action : Immediate Investigation : I request that the CFPB investigate the collection agency and the creditor, XXXX, for their failure to validate the alleged debt. I also request that the CFPB ensure all collection activities cease until proper validation is provided. 

Removal of Debt from Credit Reports : I request the immediate removal of this unvalidated XXXX debt from my credit report across all three major credit bureaus ( XXXX, TransUnion, and XXXX ) to prevent further damage to my creditworthiness. 

Compliance Assurance : I ask the CFPB to ensure that both XXXX and any collection agencies acting on its behalf adhere to the FDCPA and FCRA moving forward, providing proper validation before attempting to collect or report any debt. 

The failure to validate this debt violates federal consumer protection laws and has caused undue stress and harm to my financial standing. I request the CFPBs assistance in resolving this matter promptly and ensuring that my rights as a consumer are upheld. 

Thank you for your attention to this issue.

Sub-issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint to address the presence of unauthorized and unconnected credit inquiries on my credit report. These inquiries are not tied to any account or transaction I initiated or approved, and their continued presence is a violation of my rights under federal credit laws.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), a credit inquiry can only be performed with the consumers consent or in connection with a legitimate credit transaction initiated by the consumer. These inquiries on my credit report lack any associated accounts or transactions, and I have not provided explicit authorization for them.

Additionally, under FCRA Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), I have the right to dispute inaccurate or unauthorized information on my credit report. I have taken steps to dispute these inquiries with the credit reporting agencies, but they have yet to be removed. The failure to act on my dispute constitutes a failure to comply with federal laws requiring accurate
reporting and prompt investigation.

Credit inquiries, even if unauthorized, can negatively affect my credit score and overall creditworthiness. The existence of these unconnected inquiries is causing unnecessary harm to my financial reputation and may impact my ability to secure favorable terms for future financial opportunities.

I request the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) to investigate this matter thoroughly and ensure that the credit reporting agencies promptly : Remove all unauthorized and unconnected inquiries from my credit report. 
Implement stricter verification processes to prevent unauthorized inquiries from being reported in the future. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a resolution that ensures compliance with the FCRA and protects my rights as a consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently received a copy of my Transunion credit report file # XXXX dated XX/XX/XXXX. 

The account XXXX XXXX XXXX # XXXX contains INACCURATE INFORMATION. I am legally entitled to a 100 % accurate credit report. Please thoroughly investigate this account and make appropriate corrections. Please also provide me with the names, phone numbers, and email addresses of the individuals with whom you contact so I can follow up as well. If you are unable to make the corrections compliant with the FCRA and NJFCRA, you are required by law to delete the account. 

Balance {$15000.00} = INACCURATE Terms {$0.00} per month = INACCURATE Payment History = NEVER 30 DAYS LATE XX/XX/XXXX 15 U.S. Code 1681e - Compliance procedures section ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 

If you are unable to make the corrections compliant with the FCRA and NJFCRA, you are required by law to delete the account from my report pursuant to : 15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) Reinvestigations of disputed information ( 1 ) Reinvestigation required ( A ) In general Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumers file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly, or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller. ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general If, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX, Transunion, and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' XXXX XXXX is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' XXXX XXXX the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX, Transunion, and XXXX do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, Transunion, and XXXX, XXXX XXXX whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' XXXX XXXX Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX, Transunion, and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

I did not consent to XXXX XXXX XXXX communicating with me any obligations to pay a debt through any mediums which includes communication with the credit reporting agencies to report the alleged debt. Furthermore 15 U.S.Code 1692a ( 6 ) 1692a ( 6 ) - a debt collector is defined as anyone in the business of collecting a debt. Therefore by definition XXXX XXXX XXXX is debt collector. 

Notice, it is a fact, that, I, agent for principal ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) am aware that XXXX XXXX XXXX is a debt collector by the legal definition. Pursuant to 15 U.S.Code 1692 ( a ) ( 6 ), a debt collector is any person who uses instrumentality of interstate commerce, such as the mails, in any business which the principal purpose is the collection of any debts, or who regularly collects or attempts to collect, directly or indirectly, debts owed or due or asserted to be owed or due another Furthermore this law U.S.Code 1692d states A Debt collector may not engage in any conduct ( no restriction ) which will harass, oppress or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Oppressing a right would be conduct not allowed from 1692d. Credit is the right granted and protected by federal law. If any debt collection caused a denial of credit this allows for damages. I have been denied credit on multiple occasions and denied housing because of this negative account on XXXX XXXX XXXX consumer report. This is an actual damage as this tremendously harmed my ability to operate in commerce and purchase household goods and shelter for I the consumer and my family. 

Notice, it is a fact, I the affiant is aware, credit is a right granted to me as a creditor under the Truth in Lending Act and { XXXX XXXX XXXX } does not have the right to oppress or abuse any part of my character which would restrict or prohibit my right to extend credit. XXXX XXXX XXXX has oppressed my right to extend credit which is a violation of 15 U.S.Code 1692d.

As well as there being no contract that exists bewteen the I the consumer and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX says I the consumer would pay XXXX XXXX XXXX the alleged debt this was false and misleading reporting.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the accuracy and validity of an account reported on my credit report by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate and verifiable reporting. Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I have the right to be free from misleading or unauthorized debt collection practices. Below are the specific issues : XXXX. Improper Reporting of Disputed Status : The report states, Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. If you did not agree to this dispute resolution or if the dispute was not properly investigated, this statement might be misleading. 
XXXX. Unauthorized Transfer or Assignment of Debt : If you did not agree to any payments or the transfer of this account to a third party ( XXXX Funding ), it could be a violation of consumer protection laws, including the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Information : The accounts Date Opened is listed as XX/XX/XXXX, with the Last Reported date as XX/XX/XXXX. If the original delinquency occurred in XXXX, this account XXXX soon exceed the seven-year reporting limit for negative items under the FCRA. 
XXXX. Lack of Supporting Payment History : The report does not provide a detailed payment history or verification of how the debt reached Collection/Chargeoff status. This lack of transparency raises concerns about the accuracy and verifiability of the report. 
XXXX. Incorrect Reporting of Collection Activity : If XXXX Funding is reporting this account as Collection/Chargeoff without proper documentation or consent, this could constitute a violation of the FCRA and FDCPA. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and FDCPA : XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure the information they report is accurate and verifiable. Inconsistent and unclear reporting violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Negative information, such as collections, must not be reported for more than seven years from the date of the first delinquency.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If you disputed this account and it remains unresolved or improperly updated, this indicates a failure to conduct a proper investigation.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The furnisher ( XXXX XXXX ) XXXX be reporting incorrect or unverifiable information. 
XXXX. FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : False or Misleading Representations : If XXXX XXXX reported this debt without your consent or misrepresented its authority to collect, this could violate FDCPA provisions.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Pa XXXX Trans Union LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX RE : XXXX : XXXX To Whom It XXXX Concern, I am writing to formally notify you of the unlawful reporting of fraudulent accounts on my consumer report, arising from identity theft, which you failed to verify as mandated by law. 
15 USC 1681b ( c ) - Furnishing reports in connection with credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer : ( 3 ) Information regarding inquiries : Except as provided in section 1681g ( a ) ( 5 ) of this title, a consumer reporting agency shall not furnish to any person a record of inquiries in connection with a credit or insurance transaction that is not initiated by a consumer. 
The following inquiries, which are a result of identity theft and were not initiated by me, must be deleted immediately : Inquiry : Company Name, Date of Inquiry My identity has been stolen, and I am placing you on formal notice. 
Aggravated Identity Theft pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1028A : ( 1 ) In general : Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 2 years. 
15 USC 1681b - Permissible purposes of consumer reports : ( a ) IN GENERAL : Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report only under the following circumstances : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates.

15 USC 1681- Fair Credit Reporting Act : ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reports : ( 4 ) There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 
List of Fraudulent Accounts : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Pursuant to 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 - Block of information resulting from identity theft : A consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information resulting from alleged identity theft, not later than 4 business days after the date of receipt by such agency of : ( 1 ) Appropriate proof of the identity of the consumer ; ( 2 ) A copy of an identity theft report ; ( 3 ) The identification of such information by the consumer ; and ( 4 ) A statement by the consumer that the information is not related to any transaction by the consumer. 
Enclosed are all relevant documents pursuant to the above section of the law. I demand that all the aforementioned fraudulent accounts be deleted immediately. Additionally, I demand an updated copy of my consumer file reflecting these changes, as stated by 15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports.

15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports : In any case in which a consumer reporting agency includes a fraud alert in the file of a consumer pursuant to this subsection, the consumer reporting agency shall : ( A ) Disclose to the consumer that they may request a free copy of their file pursuant to section 1681j ( d ) of this title. 
Be advised that I will CC : The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( CFPB ) The Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) The Attorney General XXXX XXXX in your state and mine Thank you, XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Copy of ID Utility bill showing proof of address Copy of Social Security Card FTC Identity Theft Report

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to declare that I am a victim of identity theft. A fraudulent account was illegally opened in my name without my knowledge or consent. Specifically, I have no recollection of applying for or authorizing the account with XXXX XXXX, and I am unfamiliar with its origin. This unauthorized activity has caused harm to my credit and financial reputation. 

I have taken immediate action by filing a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and I have enclosed my Identity Theft Report as evidence of this crime. Additionally, I have contacted the credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) to request validation of the debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). However, the information I requested has not been provided, which further confirms the lack of legitimacy surrounding this account. 

The fraudulent activity violates my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which ensures the accuracy of information reported to consumer reporting agencies, and the Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act, which makes the unauthorized use of my personal information a federal crime. 

I am requesting the immediate investigation and removal of this account from my records and credit reports to prevent further harm. Identity theft has impacted my ability to secure credit and maintain my financial well-being. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and your cooperation in helping me resolve this issue. Please contact me if you require additional documentation or information.\ Please find attached a copy of my id, a copy of my SSC, a copy of my most recent utility bill, a copy of the FTC complaint and a copy of the validation of dept letter.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

This lack of compliance is not only troubling but also deeply frustrating, given the critical importance of adhering to legal obligations. 

Therefore, I strongly advocate for the immediate removal of this account in accordance with the specified regulations, unless verifiable evidence is promptly provided to establish its authenticity. Any delay in addressing this issue exacerbates the frustration caused by the apparent disregard for regulatory protocols and the legal standards that ensure fairness and accuracy.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Pa XXXX Trans Union LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX RE : XXXX : XXXX To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally notify you of the unlawful reporting of fraudulent accounts on my consumer report, arising from identity theft, which you failed to verify as mandated by law. 
15 USC 1681b ( c ) - Furnishing reports in connection with credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer : ( 3 ) Information regarding inquiries : Except as provided in section 1681g ( a ) ( 5 ) of this title, a consumer reporting agency shall not furnish to any person a record of inquiries in connection with a credit or insurance transaction that is not initiated by a consumer. 
The following inquiries, which are a result of identity theft and were not initiated by me, must be deleted immediately : XXXX : XXXX XX/XX/XXXX My identity has been stolen, and I am placing you on formal notice. 
Aggravated Identity Theft pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1028A : ( XXXX ) In general : Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of XXXX years. 
15 USC 1681b - Permissible purposes of consumer reports : ( a ) IN GENERAL : Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report only under the following circumstances : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates.

15 USC 1681- Fair Credit Reporting Act : ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reports : ( 4 ) There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 
List of Fraudulent Accounts : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Pursuant to 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 - Block of information resulting from identity theft : A consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information resulting from alleged identity theft, not later than 4 business days after the date of receipt by such agency of : ( 1 ) Appropriate proof of the identity of the consumer ; ( 2 ) A copy of an identity theft report ; ( 3 ) The identification of such information by the consumer ; and ( 4 ) A statement by the consumer that the information is not related to any transaction by the consumer. 
Enclosed are all relevant documents pursuant to the above section of the law. I demand that all the aforementioned fraudulent accounts be deleted immediately. Additionally, I demand an updated copy of my consumer file reflecting these changes, as stated by 15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports.

15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ) - Access to free reports : In any case in which a consumer reporting agency includes a fraud alert in the file of a consumer pursuant to this subsection, the consumer reporting agency shall : ( A ) Disclose to the consumer that they may request a free copy of their file pursuant to section 1681j ( d ) of this title. 
Be advised that I will XXXX XXXX  The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection ( CFPB ) The Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Attorney General 's Office in your state and mine Thank you, XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Copy of ID Utility bill showing proof of address Copy of Social Security Card FTC Identity Theft Report

Consumer complaint narrative:
Name : [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] Address : [ XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, MI ] Phone Number : [ XXXX ] Email Address : [ XXXX ] Company Name ( Transunion, XXXX, XXXX ) : Company Name : [ Transunion ] Account Number XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Date of Incident : [ Different dates not accurate ] Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Credit Reporting and Violation of Consumer Rights Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Details of Complaint : Dear CFPB, I am submitting a complaint against [ Credit Reporting Agency or Creditor Name ] for violating several provisions under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 

Specifically, I believe the following violations have occurred regarding my credit report : Inaccurate Reporting of Account Status - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) The reporting of my account status across different credit reporting agencies is inconsistent and inaccurate. For example, [ Name of XXXX XXXX XXXX ] lists the account as [ describe the status, such as " Voluntary Repossession '' or " Foreclosure '' ], while other agencies, such as [ list other agencies ], report different statuses, including [ list conflicting status reports ]. 
This inconsistency has led to confusion regarding the actual status of my account and has negatively impacted my credit score.

Failure to Report Accurate Payment History - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) The payment history reported on my credit report is inaccurate. [ Name of Credit Reporting Agency ] reports months as " FC '' ( Foreclosure ) when the account was not in foreclosure during those months. This is incorrect, and the payment history is inconsistent with my actual payments.

I request an immediate correction of this reporting, as it violates the FCRA 's requirement for maximum accuracy.

Failure to Update the Balance After Repossession or Voluntary Surrender - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 2 ) ) My credit report continues to show an inaccurate balance of [ {$4700.00} ] after a repossession or voluntary surrender. I believe the balance should reflect the current status after the vehicle was sold, and any remaining deficiency balance should be accurately reported.

Failure to update this information is a violation of the FCRA, which requires creditors to report accurate information regarding the balance of the account.

Failure to Investigate Disputed Information - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ) I have disputed the inaccurate information in my credit report with [ transunion, XXXX, experian ] on [ XX/XX/year> ], but no investigation or resolution has occurred. Under the FCRA, the agency is required to investigate and correct any inaccuracies within a timely manner. This failure to respond is a violation of my rights under the FCRA.

Inadequate Debt Validation Information - Violation of FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) I have not received the proper validation of the debt from the creditor or collection agency. I have requested specific details regarding the balance, payment history, and original contract, but have not received a satisfactory response.

Under the FDCPA, I am entitled to request and receive debt validation within 30 days of receiving a collection notice, which has not occurred.

I expect a response to this complaint within [ 30 days ], in accordance with the regulations under the FCRA and FDCPA. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  MI ] [ XXXX ]

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, AL XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX TransUnion LLC Consumer Disclosure CenteXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX To Whom it May Concern : I am writing to address concerns regarding the accuracy and compliance of information on my credit report, as mandated by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681I ) and industry-standard reporting guidelines such as the XXXX XXXX XXXX Points of Compliance. 
It has come to my attention that certain information reported on my credit file may be inaccurate, inconsistent, or unverifiable. Under the FCRA and XXXX XXXX standards, creditors are obligated to provide accurate and complete information to credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) in a timely manner. 
I want to emphasize the importance of adhering to the prescribed reporting requisites and standards. Even if the information reported is factually correct, it must be reported precisely according to the mandated format, such as XXXX XXXX data field formatting. Any deviations from these standards may render the reported information deficient and non-compliant. 
Therefore, I am exercising my rights as a consumer to demand the removal of any inaccuracies and deficiencies from my credit report. I request a thorough investigation into the sources of these accounts to ensure that creditors have fully complied with industry reporting standards, including XXXX XXXX requirements. 
It is crucial to ascertain that all alleged reporting data furnishers can accurately provide my complete file information to all major credit reporting agencies, including TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX. 
Furthermore, I want to highlight the significance of the FCRA 's provision regarding the accuracy of consumer reports ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). Consumer reporting agencies are required to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of information contained in consumer reports.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am a victim of identity theft, in accordance with the FCRA Sections 605B,615 ( f ) and 623 ( a ) ( 6 ), an identity theft report can be used to permanent block fraudulent information that results from identity theft, such as accounts or addresses from appearing on a victim 's credit report. Identity theft reports can prevent a company from continuing to collect debts that result from identity theft. Pursuant to the FCRA 605B ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ), please BLOCK ALL INFORMATION RESULTING FROM IDENTITY THEFT, except as otherwise provided in this section A, in which a consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer identifies as information resulted from an alleged identity theft, NO LATER THAN 4 BUSINESS DAYS.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute inaccurate information on my credit report regarding an account reported by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate, complete, and verifiable reporting. Below, I have outlined the specific issues with this account : 1. Inconsistent Comments Across Credit Bureaus : TransUnion : Closed. 
XXXX : Subscriber reports dispute resolved - consumer disagrees. 
XXXX : Closed or paid account/XXXX  balance. 
These inconsistencies in comments create confusion and may mislead lenders about the status of the account. 
2. Late Payment Reporting on a Closed, Paid Account : The account has a {$0.00} balance and is marked Closed or Paid across all bureaus. However, the payment history shows multiple 30-day late marks, which is inaccurate if the account is resolved and paid off. 
XXXX. Failure to Update or Resolve Dispute Comments : The comments reflect ongoing disputes despite the account being marked as resolved and closed. This misrepresentation may harm the creditworthiness of the consumer.

4. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : The Last Reported dates differ : TransUnion and XXXX : XX/XX/year>. 
XXXX : XX/XX/year>. 
While minor, this discrepancy shows a lack of synchronization and proper updates across the bureaus. 
XXXX. Contradictory Payment History : Despite the account being marked as Current and having a {$0.00} balance, the payment history contains 30-day late marks. If unverifiable or inaccurate, they violate FCRA requirements. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit bureaus are required to ensure the information they report is accurate and consistent. The discrepancies in dispute comments, payment history, and reporting dates violate this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Conduct a Proper Investigation : If disputes have been filed and the information remains inaccurate or unresolved, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate and correct the errors properly.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor ( XXXX XXXX ) may have provided inaccurate or misleading information regarding the payment history and dispute resolution.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : If the late payments are outdated or unverifiable, they must be removed from the report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the accuracy of an account reported by CB/VICSCredit on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to accurate, complete, and verifiable information. Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I am entitled to protection from misleading debt collection practices. Below are the issues I have identified : XXXX. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : The High Credit amounts differ across bureaus : {$480.00} ( TransUnion ), {$340.00} ( XXXX ), and {$0.00} ( XXXX ). Additionally, the Account Open Date is inconsistent. These discrepancies violate 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). 
XXXX. Discrepancy in Last Reported Dates : The Last Reported dates vary : XX/XX/XXXX ( TransUnion ), XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ), and XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ). These inconsistencies indicate a failure to maintain accurate and updated information. 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Reporting : The Date Last Active is listed as XX/XX/XXXX ( TransUnion and XXXX ). If no activity has occurred since then, this account may be nearing or exceeding the seven-year reporting limit, per 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ).

4. Unauthorized Transfer or Sale of Debt : I did not agree to any payment or authorize the transfer or sale of this account to another party. Reporting this account as Purchased by another lender without consent violates 15 U.S.C. 1692e of the FDCPA.

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and FDCPA : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure that the information they report is accurate and consistent. The discrepancies in account descriptions and comments violate this standard. 
2. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Negative information, such as collections, must not be reported more than seven years from the date of first delinquency.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If you disputed the account and it remains unresolved or improperly updated, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate properly.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor or collection agency may have provided inaccurate or unverifiable information.

5. FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : False or Misleading Representations : Reporting this debt without proper verification or authorization from you to collect or transfer the debt may violate the FDCPA.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my extreme dissatisfaction and concern regarding the unresolved status of my previous dispute about unauthorized inquiries on my credit report, which I submitted on XX/XX/scrub>XXXX followed XXXX and followed up on XX/XX/year>. This is my final attempt to resolve this matter amicably. I demand an immediate resolution in accordance with my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ), and 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ). 
Unauthorized Inquiries in Question XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year> Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires an immediate investigation of disputed information. It has been more than 30 days since my initial dispute, and I have yet to receive an adequate resolution, which is unacceptable.

Section 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ) entitles me to access all information in my file, including the results of your investigation. To date, I have not received the required information, which constitutes a violation of my rights. 
Section 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ) defines the permissible purposes for obtaining credit reports. These inquiries were made without my consent and do not meet any permissible purpose under this section, representing a serious infraction.

Immediate Action Required I demand immediate action to resolve this dispute. Specifically, I request the following : 1. Thorough and Immediate Reinvestigation : Conduct a complete and urgent reinvestigation of the unauthorized inquiries.

2. Immediate Removal of Unauthorized Inquiries : Remove any inquiries found to be unauthorized from my credit report without delay. 
XXXX. Updated Credit Report : Provide me with an updated copy of my credit report reflecting these changes immediately. 
XXXX. Detailed and Documented Notification : Inform me in detail of the steps taken and the results of your investigation within 15 days of receipt of this letter. Include documentation supporting your actions. 
Warning of Legal Action If I do not receive a satisfactory resolution within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this issue to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and proceed with legal action to protect my rights as a consumer. I will not hesitate to seek compensation for any damages resulting from your failure to adequately resolve this matter. 
I expect your immediate response and resolution to this issue.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Name : XXXX XXXX Email : XXXX Phone : XXXX Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/year> Original Balance : {$7200.00} Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX CA XXXX Subject : Request for 1099-C Form for Charged-Off Debt Dear, CFPB This letter serves as my XXXXfifth requestXXXX for the deletion and removal of a charged-off account with XXXX XXXX Despite four prior attempts to obtain a XXXX1099-C formXXXX related to the cancellation of the debt associated with this account, I have yet to receive any response or acknowledgment from your office. This lack of action is a direct violation of both my rights under federal tax law and consumer protection laws related to credit reporting. As stipulated by Internal Revenue Code ( IRC ) XXXX, XXXX XXXX is legally required to issue a 1099-C form when a debt of {$600.00} or more is canceled. The failure to issue this form constitutes a violation of federal law, as you are obligated to report cancelled debts to both the IRS and the consumer. This issue has gone unresolved for far too long. To also add, this account has multiple inaccuracies thats reporting false information across all 3 bureaus. Furthermore, under the XXXX*Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) XXXX, all information reported to credit bureaus must be accurate and complete. The ongoing reporting of this charged-off account is not only incorrect but also misleading. As per the FCRA, if an account is charged off or forgiven, and if the debt is cancelled, the report must reflect this cancellation, and the account should be removed from my credit report or marked as paid or settled with a XXXX balance. The continued reporting of this account as an open, charged-off balance, without issuing the required 1099-C, is an inaccurate representation of my financial obligations and violates my rights under the FCRA. As a consumer, I am entitled to accurate reporting and full transparency regarding any debt that has been forgiven or settled. By failing to issue a XXXXXXXX1099-C formXXXX  and continuing to report a charged-off account, XXXX XXXX is infringing upon my rights under the **Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) **, which protects consumers from misleading and unfair practices by debt collectors and creditors. I request the immediate removal of this charged-off account from my credit report and the deletion of all associated negative entries that do not reflect the true status of the debt. This includes removing any record of the account that reflects it as charged off or in default if the debt has been forgiven or settled. Please delete and remove all this account. 

Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XX/XX/year> Original Balance : {$7200.00} If this matter is not resolved within 15 days, I will be forced to pursue further action, which may include : XXXX. Filing a formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) for failure to comply with **credit reporting laws XXXX. Reporting this noncompliance to the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and the Internal Revenue Service ( IRS ) for failure to issue the required XXXX1099-C form. 
XXXX. Seeking legal recourse for any violations under the Fair Credit Reporting Act and other applicable laws. 

Attached will also be the previous letters send out to this creditor. I expect written confirmation of these actions within 15 days from the date of this letter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to declare that I am a victim of identity theft. A fraudulent account was illegally opened in my name without my knowledge or consent. Specifically, I have no recollection of applying for or authorizing the account with XXXX XXXX, and I am unfamiliar with its origin. This unauthorized activity has caused harm to my credit and financial reputation. 

I have taken immediate action by filing a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and I have enclosed my Identity Theft Report as evidence of this crime. Additionally, I have contacted the credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) to request validation of the debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). However, the information I requested has not been provided, which further confirms the lack of legitimacy surrounding this account. 

The fraudulent activity violates my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which ensures the accuracy of information reported to consumer reporting agencies, and the Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act, which makes the unauthorized use of my personal information a federal crime. 

I am requesting the immediate investigation and removal of this account from my records and credit reports to prevent further harm. Identity theft has impacted my ability to secure credit and maintain my financial well-being. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and your cooperation in helping me resolve this issue. Please contact me if you require additional documentation or information.\ Please find attached a copy of my id, a copy of my SSC, a copy of my most recent utility bill, a copy of the FTC complaint and a copy of the validation of dept letter.

In connection with the XXXX Change in Control Transaction, we entered into a registration rights agreement ( the Registration Rights Agreement ) with certain affiliates of the Sponsors and certain members of management. Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently disputed with Transunion on the following acct becauseof multiple inaccuracies. XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX This XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was investigated on XXXX separate occasions and Transunion failed to take action despite their feedback, letters, and responses ***even on here XXXX consumerfinance.gov***. They responded it was updated but no updates OR corrections were executed. They in willful noncompliance with federal law of the FCRA.

15 U.S. Code 1681e - Compliance procedures ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 

ERRORS XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX : XXXX Account was charged off - the balance remains open {$640.00} XXXX Payment status REPEATEDLY reported as C/O month over month - this is reporting ACTIVE PAYMENT HISTORY on a CLOSED ACCOUNT which is inaccurate and illegal and extends the statue of limitations 3- Past due amount listed as {$640.00} - it was charged off therefore NO PAST DUE 4- Charge off on consumer report is INCOME - income is not reported on any consumer credit report 5- Payment history XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year> BOTH STATE 120 days late - this is WRONG I NOW DEMAND THIS ACCOUNT XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX BE DELETED FROM MY CREDIT REPORT IMMEDIATELY PURSUANT TO US CONGRESS FCRA : 15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general If, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation ; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this formal complaint against XXXX XXXX, Bank Of America, XXXX XXXX for the following violations : Fraudulent Reporting of Charge-Offs as Debt ( IRS Classification of Income ).

Breach of Fiduciary Duty by Ignoring My Letters and Durable Power of Attorney ( DPOA ). 
Failure to Disclose Securitization of Promissory Notes.

Non-Compliance with Audit Reporting and GAAP Standards.

Fraudulent Reporting of Charge-Offs as Debt The reporting of charge-offs on my credit report is fraudulent and misleading. According to IRS regulations, charge-offs are classified as income on a 1099-C form when reported to the IRS. Per federal law, income can not be reported as debt on a consumer credit report.

Violation : Reporting charge-offs as debt breaches the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2, which prohibits the reporting of inaccurate information. 

Demand : XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX must immediately remove all charge-offs from my credit report as these entries are misleading and harmful to my financial reputation. 
XXXX. Breach of Fiduciary Duty : Ignoring My Letters and Durable Power of Attorney ( DPOA ) I have sent multiple letters asserting my rights, including a Durable Power of Attorney ( DPOA ), which has been ignored by both XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX. By failing to respond, these entities have violated their fiduciary obligations and undermined my rights to assert my interest in the credit. 

Legal Precedent : XXXX XXXX XXXX establishes that promissory notes fully fund credit, rendering the consumer the true creditor. As the creditor, I retain rights and interests in the credit and demand acknowledgment of the same. 
Demand : XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX must immediately recognize my rights as the creditor and provide a detailed response to all letters and XXXX documents sent. 

XXXX. Failure to Disclose Securitization of Promissory Notes It has come to my attention that the promissory notes I provided to XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX were securitized and sold without my knowledge or consent. This failure to disclose constitutes fraud and unjust enrichment. 

Violation : XXXXnder 15 U.S.C. 1641 ( Truth in Lending Act - TILA ), lenders are required to disclose the sale, assignment, or transfer of debt instruments to third parties. 

Fraudulent Omission : By securitizing my promissory notes and profiting from the proceeds, without compensating me as the original creditor, XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX have committed fraud. 
Demand : Provide full disclosure of the securitization of my promissory notes, including an accounting of proceeds and confirmation that these proceeds have been applied to offset any alleged debt. 

XXXX. Non-Compliance with Audit Reporting and GAAP Standards Under federal law and Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ), financial institutions are required to provide accurate audit reports and account reconciliations. 

Legal Obligation : 12 U.S.C. 1831n ( a ) mandates compliance with GAAP standards for all financial institutions.

15 U.S.C. 1637 ( TILA ) requires creditors to provide clear and accurate account information. 
Violation : XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX have failed to provide audit reports and reconcile accounts as requested. Their lack of transparency further suggests that the reporting of charge-offs is fraudulent and unsupported by proper accounting practices. 


Formal Opt-Out of Authorization and Illegality of Reporting Transaction History Per the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am formally opting out of any and all authorizations I may have givenwhether written, unwritten, verbal, or non-verbalunder 15 U.S.C. 6802. As a consumer, I have the unequivocal right to opt out of the sharing and use of my non-public personal information ( NPI ) at any time.

By exercising this opt-out right : Unauthorized Reporting is Illegal : Under 15 U.S.C. 6801, it is illegal for financial institutions to report or share my transaction history without my explicit consent.

The policy of Congress explicitly mandates that every financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to protect the security, confidentiality, and privacy of its customers ' NPI. 
Violation of Privacy Rights : XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX and Bank Of America have reported my transaction history and personal information to credit reporting agencies without obtaining my express consent, in direct violation of these statutory obligations.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate and unauthorized information appearing on my TransUnion credit report. These accounts were added due to a data breach and are not authorized or representative of my financial history. I request immediate investigation and removal of the following accounts from my credit report : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Pursuant to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I assert the following rights and request specific actions to address this issue : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( FCRA 611 ) : I request that the disputed information be investigated and verified as accurate. If the disputed accounts can not be verified, they must be deleted from my credit report.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ( FCRA 607 ) : TransUnion is obligated to ensure maximum possible accuracy in reporting my credit information. These accounts are inaccurate and result from identity theft or misreporting tied to the referenced data breach.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ( FCRA 605A ( b ) ) : I request that these fraudulent items be removed as they stem from a breach of my personal data.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681g ( FCRA 609 ) : I request access to all documentation, records, and communications related to the inclusion of these accounts on my credit report.

Given the widespread data breaches that have affected financial institutions and compromised consumers ' sensitive information, I believe these accounts may have been fraudulently opened or erroneously reported. I demand that these accounts be thoroughly investigated in compliance with FCRA requirements and deleted from my credit report if found unverifiable or inaccurate.

Additionally, under the Federal Trade Commission Act ( 15 U.S.C. 45 ), it is illegal for businesses to engage in unfair or deceptive practices. Reporting inaccurate or fraudulent accounts on my credit report due to negligence in protecting consumer data constitutes a violation of this statute. 
I have attached all relevant documents to support this dispute, including copies of my TransUnion credit report highlighting the disputed accounts.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against the Credit Reporting Agencies ( CRAs ) for the following violations : Fraudulent Reporting of Charged-Off Accounts Failure to Honor Opt-Out Rights Under FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802 ) CRAs are illegally reporting charged-off accounts on my credit report. A charged-off account is classified as income when reported to the IRS on a 1099-C form. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), income can not legally be reported as a debt on a credit report. 

Violation : Reporting these charged-off accounts as debts is misleading, inaccurate, and against federal law under 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ), which prohibits the reporting of false information on a credit report. 

Under 15 U.S.C. 6802, I have the legal right to opt out of the sharing of my non-public personal information ( NPI ) at any time. Despite this, the CRAs have failed to honor my opt-out request and continue to use and share my data without my permission.

Lawful Right to Opt-Out : According to 12 C.F.R. 1016.10, consumers can opt out of the sharing of their information with third parties at any time, regardless of any prior authorizationswritten, verbal, implied, or otherwise.

Under 15 U.S.C. 6801, it is unlawful for any financial institution or Credit Reporting Agency ( CRA ) to report transaction history without my explicit consent. Congress has made it clear that financial institutions have an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of their customers and to safeguard the security and confidentiality of their non-public personal information ( NPI ).

Violation : the CRAs have illegally reported my transaction history without my knowledge or consent. This is a clear breach of their statutory obligations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) and related provisions of the FCRA.

Privacy Obligation : Under 15 U.S.C. 6801 ( b ), financial institutions are required to implement safeguards to ensure the privacy of their customers ' information. Reporting transaction history without proper authorization violates these obligations.
