Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX  XXXX bankruptcy : Bankruptcy - Reference Number - XXXX Subject : Dispute of Bankruptcy Reporting Under the FCRA To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to dispute the inaccurate reporting of a bankruptcy on my credit report. Upon confirmation with the bankruptcy court, I have verified that the court does not report credit information to any credit reporting agencies, including Equifax, XXXX, and XXXX. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 USC 1681e ( b ), credit reporting agencies are required to maintain reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information contained in consumer reports. Reporting a bankruptcy as originating from the court without direct verification from the source violates this requirement. 

Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681i, I have the right to dispute any inaccurate or unverifiable information on my credit report. Since the bankruptcy court does not furnish such information to credit reporting agencies, its inclusion on my credit report is unsubstantiated and must be removed. 

Actions Requested : Conduct an Investigation : Investigate the source of the bankruptcy information reported on my credit report. If the reporting can not be verified directly by the source ( the bankruptcy court ), it must be removed. 

Provide Written Confirmation : Notify me in writing of the results of your investigation and provide an updated copy of my credit report reflecting the removal of the inaccurate bankruptcy entry. 

Ensure Compliance : Verify that all procedures are in compliance with the FCRA to prevent similar inaccuracies in the future. 

Enclosed are supporting documents, including confirmation from the bankruptcy court that they do not furnish credit reporting data, and a copy of my credit report highlighting the disputed bankruptcy entry. 

I expect a response within the 30 days required under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ). Failure to comply with these legal obligations will leave me no choice but to report this matter to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and my state Attorney Generals office. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, FL XXXX XXXX Equifax Information Services LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX Re : Disputing Accuracy of Credit Report Dear Equifax, I am writing to dispute the following information in my credit report. The items in question are not accurate. 

Address XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX, FL XXXX Employer Name XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX According to 15 U.S. Code 1681e - Compliance procedures, ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

According to 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies, ( a ) Duty of furnishers of information to provide accurate information ( 1 ) Prohibition ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Regarding the treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information, according to 15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general If, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation ; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

I am requesting these items identified permanently removed from my credit report. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my extreme dissatisfaction and concern regarding the unresolved status of my previous dispute about unauthorized inquiries on my credit report, which I submitted on XX/XX/year>, followed on XX/XX/year> and followed up on XX/XX/year>. This is my final attempt to resolve this matter amicably. I demand an immediate resolution in accordance with my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ), and 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ). 
Unauthorized Inquiries in Question XXXX XXXX - XX/XX/year>XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year> Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires an immediate investigation of disputed information. It has been more than 30 days since my initial dispute, and I have yet to receive an adequate resolution, which is unacceptable.

Section 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ) entitles me to access all information in my file, including the results of your investigation. To date, I have not received the required information, which constitutes a violation of my rights.

Section 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ) defines the permissible purposes for obtaining credit reports. These inquiries were made without my consent and do not meet any permissible purpose under this section, representing a serious infraction. 
Immediate Action Required I demand immediate action to resolve this dispute. Specifically, I request the following : 1. Thorough and Immediate Reinvestigation : Conduct a complete and urgent reinvestigation of the unauthorized inquiries.

2. Immediate Removal of Unauthorized Inquiries : Remove any inquiries found to be unauthorized from my credit report without delay.

3. Updated Credit Report : Provide me with an updated copy of my credit report reflecting these changes immediately.

4. Detailed and Documented Notification : Inform me in detail of the steps taken and the results of your investigation within 15 days of receipt of this letter. Include documentation supporting your actions. 
Warning of Legal Action If I do not receive a satisfactory resolution within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this issue to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and proceed with legal action to protect my rights as a consumer. I will not hesitate to seek compensation for any damages resulting from your failure to adequately resolve this matter. 
I expect your immediate response and resolution to this issue.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am disputing the accuracy of an account listed on my credit report under XXXX XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to dispute incomplete or inaccurate information. After reviewing my report, I identified the following issues with this account : XXXX. Inconsistent Account Reporting Across Bureaus : The account is listed under Equifax, but there is no reporting in XXXX or XXXX. This inconsistency can misrepresent the consumers creditworthiness. 
XXXX. Improper Collection Account Reporting : The payment history under Equifax shows OK for all months, but the account is marked as Collection with a status of Late 120 Days and a balance of {$580.00}. This is contradictory and could indicate an error. 
XXXX. Failure to Update Dispute Status : The comments section states : Consumer disputes this account information, yet the account is still reported as Derogatory without clear resolution or updates. If the dispute was resolved, this status should be updated or removed. 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Reporting : The Date of Last Payment is listed as XX/XX/year>, and the Date Last Active is also XX/XX/year>. Negative information such as collections must generally be removed after seven years from the date of the first delinquency, per FCRA guidelines ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ).

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must maintain accurate and consistent reporting. The contradiction between OK payment history and the account being in Collection with 120 Days Late status violates this requirement.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Conduct a Proper Investigation : If the account has been disputed and the information remains inaccurate, this indicates a failure to investigate and correct errors.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : If the accounts delinquency began in 2018, it may now be obsolete. Such information must be removed after seven years.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor ( Midland ) may be inaccurately reporting this collection account, particularly if it remains in dispute or contradicts the payment history.

I have enclosed a copy my Police Report/FTC identity theft report ( FTC REPORT NUMBERXXXX ) to support my identity theft claim. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 when a consumer submits an identity theft report, credit reporting agencies must block any information identified by the consumer as resulting from identity theft within four business days.

I would like this item immediately re-investigated. 
XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year> In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act, the list of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

The accounts below have violated my rights.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions.

15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C 1681s-2 ( A ) ( a ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative: 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies. There are a lot of inaccuracies on my credit report that needs to be immediately removed until proven the information can be proves that it is valid. I have her attached & highlighted everything in XXXX. XXXX, XXXX XXXX Equifax are listed in the attachment. Accuracy and fairness of credit reporting should be reported & these things are not accurate. There are non mailable address being reported which are also highlighted. I have no way of receiving mail to highlighted address so this would be mail fraud 611. Procedure in case of disputed accuracy [ 15 U.S.C. 1681i ] ( 5 ) Treatment of Inaccurate or Unverifiable Information ( A ) In general. If, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer

Reporting transaction history without explicit consent violates this statute. 

Violation : XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX have engaged in the unauthorized reporting of my transaction history, which is illegal without my consent.

XXXX Unlawful Reporting of Charged-Off Debt as Income Under federal law, charged-off debts are considered income for tax purposes when reported to the IRS via a XXXX XXXX. However, income is not a permissible category for reporting on consumer credit reports under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The FCRA and related case law establish that consumer credit reports must only contain accurate and permissible information directly related to creditworthiness, not income classifications. 

Violation : XXXX, Equifax, and XXXX are unlawfully reporting charged-off debts as derogatory trade lines on my credit report despite their reclassification as " income '' under IRS regulations XXXX This constitutes a clear violation of the FCRA because income, especially income derived from forgiven debt, is not authorized for inclusion in consumer credit reporting.

XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) : Highlighted the importance of accurate classification of debt in credit reporting.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute several unauthorized hard inquiries appearing on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), credit inquiries may only be made with my explicit consent or when otherwise permitted by law. I have reviewed my credit report and found the following inquiries that I did not authorize. picture have been unloaded Under Section 604 of the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), a consumer reporting agency may only provide a credit report for permissible purposes, such as a legitimate credit transaction that the consumer initiated. These inquiries were not authorized by me, and I am requesting their immediate removal as they violate this provision.

1. Section 607 ( b ) : Maximum Possible Accuracy Credit bureaus must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information included in a consumer report. This applies to all types of data, including inquiries.

2. Section 611 : Dispute Process Consumers have the right to dispute any inaccurate or incomplete information in their credit report, including unauthorized or incorrect credit inquiries. Credit bureaus must investigate disputes within 30 days and delete or correct any unverifiable or inaccurate information.

3. Section 604 : Permissible Purpose Inquiries must have a legitimate purpose and be authorized by the cons
umer or permissible under the law ( e.g., for a credit application, insurance underwriting, or employment ). If inquiries appear on your credit report without authorization, they violate this section.

4. Section 609 : Disclosure to Consumers Credit bureaus must provide consumers with a list of all entities that accessed their credit file, including inquiries. Consumers can request details on why their credit report was accessed and by whom.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against the Credit Reporting Agencies ( CRAs ) for the following violations : Fraudulent Reporting of Charged-Off Accounts Failure to Honor Opt-Out Rights Under FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802 ) CRAs are illegally reporting charged-off accounts on my credit report. A charged-off account is classified as income when reported to the IRS on a 1099-C form. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), income can not legally be reported as a debt on a credit report. 

Violation : Reporting these charged-off accounts as debts is misleading, inaccurate, and against federal law under 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ), which prohibits the reporting of false information on a credit report. 

Under 15 U.S.C. 6802, I have the legal right to opt out of the sharing of my non-public personal information ( NPI ) at any time. Despite this, the CRAs have failed to honor my opt-out request and continue to use and share my data without my permission. 

Lawful Right to Opt-Out : According to 12 C.F.R. 1016.10, consumers can opt out of the sharing of their information with third parties at any time, regardless of any prior authorizationswritten, verbal, implied, or otherwise. 


Under 15 U.S.C. 6801, it is unlawful for any financial institution or Credit Reporting Agency ( CRA ) to report transaction history without my explicit consent. Congress has made it clear that financial institutions have an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of their customers and to safeguard the security and confidentiality of their non-public personal information ( NPI ). 

Violation : the CRAs have illegally reported my transaction history without my knowledge or consent. This is a clear breach of their statutory obligations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) and related provisions of the FCRA.

Privacy Obligation : Under 15 U.S.C. 6801 ( b ), financial institutions are required to implement safeguards to ensure the privacy of their customers ' information. Reporting transaction history without proper authorization violates these obligations.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my extreme dissatisfaction and concern regarding the unresolved status of my previous dispute about unauthorized inquiries on my credit report, which I submitted on XX/XX/year>, followed on XX/XX/year> and followed up on XX/XX/year>. This is my final attempt to resolve this matter amicably. I demand an immediate resolution in accordance with my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ), and 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ). 
Unauthorized Inquiries in Question XXXX XXXX - XX/XX/year>XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year> Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires an immediate investigation of disputed information. It has been more than 30 days since my initial dispute, and I have yet to receive an adequate resolution, which is unacceptable.

Section 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ) entitles me to access all information in my file, including the results of your investigation. To date, I have not received the required information, which constitutes a violation of my rights.

Section 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ) defines the permissible purposes for obtaining credit reports. These inquiries were made without my consent and do not meet any permissible purpose under this section, representing a serious infraction.

Immediate Action Required I demand immediate action to resolve this dispute. Specifically, I request the following : 1. Thorough and Immediate Reinvestigation : Conduct a complete and urgent reinvestigation of the unauthorized inquiries.

2. Immediate Removal of Unauthorized Inquiries : Remove any inquiries found to be unauthorized from my credit report without delay.

3. Updated Credit Report : Provide me with an updated copy of my credit report reflecting these changes immediately.

4. Detailed and Documented Notification : Inform me in detail of the steps taken and the results of your investigation within 15 days of receipt of this letter. Include documentation supporting your actions. 
Warning of Legal Action If I do not receive a satisfactory resolution within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this issue to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and proceed with legal action to protect my rights as a consumer. I will not hesitate to seek compensation for any damages resulting from your failure to adequately resolve this matter. 
I expect your immediate response and resolution to this issue.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The list of accounts below have violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. 

MXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Has violated my rights. 

I looked at my Equifax credit report on XX/XX/year> and noticed some things are incomplete and not accurate. And according to the Fair Credit Reporting act whenever a consumer Reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure Maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 168 ( e ) ( b ).

And according to 15 USC 1681i 5 they are supposed to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer Reporting agency shall - ( I ) promptly delete that item of information fromt the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation, and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted fromt the file of the consumer.

And according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are supposed to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to declare that I am a victim of identity theft. A fraudulent account was illegally opened in my name without my knowledge or consent. Specifically, I have no recollection of applying for or authorizing the account with XXXX XXXX, and I am unfamiliar with its origin. This unauthorized activity has caused harm to my credit and financial reputation. 

I have taken immediate action by filing a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and I have enclosed my Identity Theft Report as evidence of this crime. Additionally, I have contacted the credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) to request validation of the debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). However, the information I requested has not been provided, which further confirms the lack of legitimacy surrounding this account. 

The fraudulent activity violates my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which ensures the accuracy of information reported to consumer reporting agencies, and the Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act, which makes the unauthorized use of my personal information a federal crime. 

I am requesting the immediate investigation and removal of this account from my records and credit reports to prevent further harm. Identity theft has impacted my ability to secure credit and maintain my financial well-being. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and your cooperation in helping me resolve this issue. Please contact me if you require additional documentation or information.\ Please find attached a copy of my id, a copy of my SSC, a copy of my most recent utility bill, a copy of the FTC complaint and a copy of the validation of dept letter.

To whom it may concern CAPABLE of making appropriate changes, Please DELETE the illegally reported items below : XXXX XXXX XXXX, Date : XX/XX/XXXX, Account # : XXXX, Amount : {$0.00}, Payment : {$0.00}, Issue : Unverified through FCRA and Metro2 STANDARD.

1681i. Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general If, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall- ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

( B ) Requirements relating to reinsertion of previously deleted material About e-OSCAR ACDVs initiated by a CRA on behalf of a consumer are routed to the appropriate Data Furnisher based on the CRA and subscriber code affiliations indicated by the DF. The ACDV is returned to the initiating CRA with updated information ( if any ) relating to the consumers credit history. If an account is modified or deleted, Carbon Copies are sent to each CRA with whom the DF has a reporting relationship. 

Cushman v. XXXX Credit Bureaus Must Delete Without Proof.

Consumer complaint narrative: Over the past XXXX weeks, I have attempted to access my credit file and score due to a drop in my score from XXXX last XXXX to approximately XXXX now. I've been addressing errors and undertaking general credit repair. TransUnion has denied access to my credit file and score during this period, citing system errors/issues, and most recently, a lock on my credit file with a specific code due to missing files. I've requested corrections since XXXX or XXXX of this year to challenge the accuracy of my file and the legality of some reported items. I've also asked for accurate reporting of my address, phone number, and employment, with the removal of all others, along with other FCRA-related items to rectify the sudden issues with my credit file. Despite resetting my password, I now face difficulties accessing my credit file at will. I suspect TransUnion is deliberately preventing access to my credit report, which I believe is a breach of the FCRA and other laws.

Checking my credit score and noticed it had gone down. I found that the collection company Zion Debt Holding, LLC, XXXX XXXX UT, XXXX had purchased the said debt from XXXX XXXX XXXX amount of {$660.00}. 

I emailed XXXX and received a response from representative XXXX XXXX. I informed her that the debt was not my responsibility and explained the invoice was for XXXX XXXX, a Thai restaurant in XXXX  DC. I worked there about 6 years ago and that restaurant closed about two years ago. I was a contact person on the account, not responsible for billing accounts. I gave them the name of the restaurant owner and his address in XXXX. Zion refused to remove the debt which directly lowers my credit score. 

This information took place place the last week of XX/XX/year> XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
This complaint addresses serious and egregious violations of federal law committed by XXXX, Equifax, XXXX ( the Credit Reporting Agencies or CRAs ), and XXXXXXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX regarding their mishandling and unlawful reporting of my personal data, privacy breaches, and fraudulent classification of charged-off debts. Their actions not only infringe upon my statutory rights but also cause significant harm to my financial well-being and reputation. 


Failure to Honor Opt-Out Rights Under FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802 ) Under 15 U.S.C. 6802, consumers have the right to opt out of the sharing of non-public personal information ( NPI ). I am formally opting out of any prior or assumed authorizationswritten, verbal, implied, or otherwisegranted to the CRAs or XXXX And XXXX XXXX to use or share my data. Despite this clear directive, these entities have willfully disregarded my right to privacy by continuing to disseminate my XXXX without consent. 


2. Violations of the Privacy Act of 1974 The Privacy Act of 1974 mandates that entities handling personal information must notify individuals of its use and provide them with a meaningful opportunity to restrict or control its dissemination. 

Violation : XXXX, Equifax, XXXX, along with XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX failed to notify me of how my personal information was being shared with third parties and denied me the ability to opt out of these unauthorized disclosures. 
Impact : This lack of transparency infringes upon my fundamental rights to control the use of my personal data. 


XXXX. Illegal Reporting of Charged-Off Debts as Income ( 15 U.S.C. 6801 ) Charged-off debts reported to the IRS via a 1099-C are reclassified as income under federal tax law. Income, however, is not permissible for inclusion on a consumer credit report under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). XXXX, Equifax, XXXX, and [ Bank Names ] are knowingly violating federal law by falsely reporting charged-off debts as derogatory items instead of removing them as required. 

Violation : The continued reporting of charged-off debts as derogatory trade lines violates 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ), which governs the permissible content of consumer reports. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, the court confirmed that debts reported inaccurately or without proper validation are unlawful under the FCRA. This precedent underscores that creditors and CRAs must remove such items promptly.

Impact : This misclassification harms my creditworthiness and exposes me to undue financial hardship and damage.

4.Negligence and Gross Misconduct by Each Bank and CRA Each of the following entities has engaged in illegal reporting and privacy violations : XXXX AND XXXX : Refused to validate a charged-off debt and continued reporting it despite being reclassified as income. 



XXXX, Equifax, and XXXX : Complicit in reporting unvalidated, inaccurate, and impermissible information, including charged-off debts and transaction histories without my authorization. 



The actions of XXXX, Equifax, XXXX, and XXXX and XXXX XXXX violate the following federal statutes and case law precedents : Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 15 U.S.C. 16811681x.

Privacy Act of 1974 : Public Law 93-579. 
Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) : 15 U.S.C. 68016809. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) : Addressing unlawful debt reporting practices. 
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) : Highlighting the illegality of misleading credit reports.

Mortgage
Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue related to modification, forbearance, short sale, deed-in-lieu, bankruptcy, or foreclosure
Consumer complaint narrative: In XX/XX/year>, I started having problems with XXXX XXXX  after the third month of me discovering money was being taken out of my account and it would be put back in at a later date but it constantly put my account in the red because I don't get a lot of money as it is and I was unable to pay a lot of my bills and it put me in deeper debt I called flagstar Bank to see if I had any options because it was one of the debts that was being interrupted at the time. I was told because I had never had any lates in my history of 2 years that I qualified for a deferral and that could be from 3 to 6 months. I was told that they could not help me at the time because I had never been late with my mortgage I would have to be late at least 60 290 days before they can even help me. So I asked my single point of sales rep whose name was XXXX XXXX at the time If it would be okay if I was late to repay my debt He said that would be the best thing to do as it looks like you're in great standing with us and that should be no problem So I did not pay for 3 months thinking I would be able to get the deferment Well he was taking off of my case and they put another point of contact in I did not know that my loan had been denied at the time I didn't know until I called asking what was going on because I did not get a notice or anything in the mail nor did I get anything emailed So I was out there in limbo I found out when I called that I was in default and that they denied me This point of contact told me to just reapply I should be able to get it because I qualified for at least a modification or payment plan but because deferral wasn't reached yet I should probably add more debt to my income so that I can look like I was in harder hardship so she gave me the numbers to add on my paper and I did I resubmitted asking for deferment or modification and again for the 4th month I did not get a response I then received a phone call that said that these calls will continue until my debt was caught up Well I'm getting nervous because I'm falling further and further behind but every point of contact that I spoke with told me that I should not pay the bill or should I say my mortgage until the modification is complete If I paid while it was under review it would throw everything off so that's the fourth month of me being told not to pay anything here we go fifth month they tell me oh it's too late You're way over and you need to pay everything back Well now I can't pay everything back at once what happened to my deferment what happened to my modification now nobody wants to talk to me I didn't get any documents to say I was denied I got nothing to say what my chances are what my options are I got nothing nobody talk to me when they called me I answered and they said this is an attempt to collect a debt when I told them what was going on they just suggested that I make a payment and resubmit an application every time I resubmitted an application I waited days weeks now I'm so far behind I do not have all this money to pay back it once I can absolutely pay my monthly mortgage but I'm asking for modification if just for 3 months I can pay the back pay for the additional 2 months if they just work with me but nobody is giving me any accurate information nothing substantial people are literally giving me information that is getting me deeper and deeper in the hole now I'm possibly facing foreclosure and yet all they say is make a payment How you're not accepting payments I don't know what to do right now I need help They keep giving me bad information tell me wait don't make a payment Wait don't make a payment resubmit Don't make a payment and I'm getting deeper in the hole but nobody 's telling me what to do or what options I have The minute I submitted again within a few days from what I was told it goes into denial and nobody tells me I'm running out of time and nobody 's talking I need help I have a daughter and I'm XXXX  I explain that to the last point of sales representative and she told me that they are not going to give me a deferment they're probably not going to give me a modification because I'm not going through a temporary hardship might XXXX is a XXXX  hardship And because of that I don't qualify for any assistance That's discrimination if I never seen it in my life that's full discrimination because I got my mortgage with my XXXX now I can't get a modification with my XXXX. I make more now than I did when I got approved for my mortgage and they're denying me every bit of assistance This is not fair I don't have money to go anywhere I don't have anybody I can depend on me and my baby 's going to be out on the street because they failed me I need help.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, AL XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Equifax Credit Information Services , XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX To Whom it May Concern : I am writing to address concerns regarding the accuracy and compliance of information on my credit report, as mandated by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681I ) and industry-standard reporting guidelines such as the Metro 2 Five Points of Compliance. 
It has come to my attention that certain information reported on my credit file may be inaccurate, inconsistent, or unverifiable. Under the FCRA and Metro 2 standards, creditors are obligated to provide accurate and complete information to credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) in a timely manner. 
I want to emphasize the importance of adhering to the prescribed reporting requisites and standards. Even if the information reported is factually correct, it must be reported precisely according to the mandated format, such as Metro 2 data field formatting. Any deviations from these standards may render the reported information deficient and non-compliant. 
Therefore, I am exercising my rights as a consumer to demand the removal of any inaccuracies and deficiencies from my credit report. I request a thorough investigation into the sources of these accounts to ensure that creditors have fully complied with industry reporting standards, including Metro 2 requirements. 
It is crucial to ascertain that all alleged reporting data furnishers can accurately provide my complete file information to all major credit reporting agencies, including XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax. 
Furthermore, I want to highlight the significance of the FCRA 's provision regarding the accuracy of consumer reports ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). Consumer reporting agencies are required to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of information contained in consumer reports.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to declare that I am a victim of identity theft. A fraudulent account was illegally opened in my name without my knowledge or consent. Specifically, I have no recollection of applying for or authorizing the account with XXXX XXXX, and I am unfamiliar with its origin. This unauthorized activity has caused harm to my credit and financial reputation. 

I have taken immediate action by filing a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and I have enclosed my Identity Theft Report as evidence of this crime. Additionally, I have contacted the credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ) to request validation of the debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). However, the information I requested has not been provided, which further confirms the lack of legitimacy surrounding this account. 

The fraudulent activity violates my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which ensures the accuracy of information reported to consumer reporting agencies, and the Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act, which makes the unauthorized use of my personal information a federal crime. 

I am requesting the immediate investigation and removal of this account from my records and credit reports to prevent further harm. Identity theft has impacted my ability to secure credit and maintain my financial well-being. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and your cooperation in helping me resolve this issue. Please contact me if you require additional documentation or information.\ Please find attached a copy of my id, a copy of my SSC, a copy of my most recent utility bill, a copy of the FTC complaint and a copy of the validation of dept letter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the accuracy of an account reported by XXXX  on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to accurate, complete, and verifiable information. Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I am entitled to protection from misleading debt collection practices. Below are the issues I have identified : XXXX. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : The High Credit amounts differ across bureaus : {$480.00} ( XXXX ), {$340.00} ( Equifax ), and {$0.00} ( XXXX ). Additionally, the Account XXXX Date is inconsistent. These discrepancies violate 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). 
XXXX. Discrepancy in Last Reported Dates : The Last Reported dates vary : XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ), XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ), and XX/XX/XXXX ( Equifax ). These inconsistencies indicate a failure to maintain accurate and updated information. 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Reporting : The Date Last Active is listed as XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX and XXXX ). If no activity has occurred since then, this account may be nearing or exceeding the seven-year reporting limit, per 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ). 
XXXX. Unauthorized Transfer or Sale of Debt : I did not agree to any payment or authorize the transfer or sale of this account to another party. Reporting this account as Purchased by another lender without consent violates 15 U.S.C. 1692e of the FDCPA. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and FDCPA : XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure that the information they report is accurate and consistent. The discrepancies in account descriptions and comments violate this standard. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Negative information, such as collections, must not be reported more than XXXX years from the date of first delinquency. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If you disputed the account and it remains unresolved or improperly updated, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate properly. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor or collection agency may have provided inaccurate or unverifiable information. 
XXXX. FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : False or Misleading Representations : Reporting this debt without proper verification or authorization from you to collect or transfer the debt may violate the FDCPA.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Name : [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] Address : [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, MI ] Phone Number : [ XXXX ] Email Address : [ XXXX ] Company Name ( XXXX, Equifax, XXXX ) : Company Name : [ XXXX ] Account Number : [ Credit Acceptance ] Date of Incident : [ Different dates not accurate ] Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Credit Reporting and Violation of Consumer Rights Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Details of Complaint : Dear CFPB, I am submitting a complaint against [ Credit Reporting Agency or Creditor Name ] for violating several provisions under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ).

Specifically, I believe the following violations have occurred regarding my credit report : Inaccurate Reporting of Account Status - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) The reporting of my account status across different credit reporting agencies is inconsistent and inaccurate. For example, [ Name of Credit Reporting Agency ] lists the account as [ describe the status, such as " Voluntary Repossession '' or " Foreclosure '' ], while other agencies, such as [ list other agencies ], report different statuses, including [ list conflicting status reports ].

This inconsistency has led to confusion regarding the actual status of my account and has negatively impacted my credit score.

Failure to Report Accurate Payment History - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) The payment history reported on my credit report is inaccurate. [ Name of Credit Reporting Agency ] reports months as " FC '' ( Foreclosure ) when the account was not in foreclosure during those months. This is incorrect, and the payment history is inconsistent with my actual payments.

I request an immediate correction of this reporting, as it violates the FCRA 's requirement for maximum accuracy.

Failure to Update the Balance After Repossession or Voluntary Surrender - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 2 ) ) My credit report continues to show an inaccurate balance of [ {$4700.00} ] after a repossession or voluntary surrender. I believe the balance should reflect the current status after the vehicle was sold, and any remaining deficiency balance should be accurately reported.

Failure to update this information is a violation of the FCRA, which requires creditors to report accurate information regarding the balance of the account.

Failure to Investigate Disputed Information - Violation of FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ) I have disputed the inaccurate information in my credit report with [ transunion, equifax, experian ] on [ XX/XX/year> ], but no investigation or resolution has occurred. Under the FCRA, the agency is required to investigate and correct any inaccuracies within a timely manner. This failure to respond is a violation of my rights under the FCRA. 
Inadequate Debt Validation Information - Violation of FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) I have not received the proper validation of the debt from the creditor or collection agency. I have requested specific details regarding the balance, payment history, and original contract, but have not received a satisfactory response. 
Under the FDCPA, I am entitled to request and receive debt validation within 30 days of receiving a collection notice, which has not occurred. 
I expect a response to this complaint within [ 30 days ], in accordance with the regulations under the FCRA and FDCPA. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] [ XXXX XXXX way XXXX, XXXX, MI ] [ XXXX ]

Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear CFPB, I am writing to express my deep disappointment with Truist Banks handling of my account. Despite being a loyal BB & T customer for over 30 years, I have faced numerous issues that have caused significant distress to me and my family.

Interest Rate Increase : Truist has raised the interest rate on my credit card without my approval. This change has caused severe financial strain. I am unsure if this occurred during the merger with BB & T and SunTrust into Truist. I urgently request a copy of the original fixed-rate contract I signed. Despite contacting Truist multiple times and speaking with executives, specialists, supervisors, and managers, I have only received the current contract, not the original one. 

Credit Bureau Reporting Error : Truist mistakenly reported incorrect information to the credit bureau, negatively impacting my credit score. Although Truist acknowledged the error and contacted the credit bureau to correct it, this is just XXXX of many issues I have faced. 

Lack of Support and Financial Assistance : Over the years, I have repeatedly reached out for assistance, only to be met with inadequate responses. I have never received any financial benefit or meaningful support from Truist. For instance, when I applied for a mortgage loan, Truist made a significant error. Despite being approved and completing all necessary steps, including the appraisal, the process was halted due to a mistake on Truists part. It took intervention from two executives to acknowledge the error and refund the appraisal fee. This is just one example of the many issues I have encountered. I have asked Truist constantly to help me pay off the card or to negotiate a reasonable interest rate and then lock my card until it is paid off, but they have done absolutely nothing to help.

Financial Contributions : Over the years, Truist has made significant profits from my accounts. Specifically, they have earned over {$15000.00} from my credit card alone. Additionally, we have an international account and frequently transfer large sums of money, generating further revenue for Truist. Despite this, they have never offered any assistance to help reduce my credit card payments or balance. This is the only credit card I have ever had in 30 years where I have not been able to pay off the balance on time, despite having a good credit score and a strong financial history.

Personal Circumstances XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  I have applied for Social Security XXXX, and my wife, who is also an XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX We have never missed a payment in 30 years, and we need your help to resolve these issues and get our credit card paid off. 

I am extremely disappointed with the lack of action and support from Truist. It feels like being punched in the stomach every time I have to recount these issues. I request that a regional XXXX or an XXXX contact me immediately to resolve these matters. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent request. 

Please not the general contract the send is illegible. 

Sincerely, XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute inaccurate information on my credit report regarding an account reported by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate, complete, and verifiable reporting. Below, I have outlined the specific issues with this account : XXXX. Inconsistent Comments Across Credit Bureaus : XXXX : Closed. 
XXXX : Subscriber reports dispute resolved - consumer disagrees. 
Equifax : Closed or paid account/zero balance. 
These inconsistencies in comments create confusion and may mislead lenders about the status of the account. 
XXXX. Late Payment Reporting on a Closed, Paid Account : The account has a {$0.00} balance and is marked Closed or Paid across all bureaus. However, the payment history shows multiple 30-day late marks, which is inaccurate if the account is resolved and paid off.

3. Failure to Update or Resolve Dispute Comments : The comments reflect ongoing disputes despite the account being marked as resolved and closed. This misrepresentation may harm the creditworthiness of the consumer. 
XXXX. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : The Last Reported dates differ : XXXX and XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX 
Equifax : XX/XX/scrub>XXXX 
While minor, this discrepancy shows a lack of synchronization and proper updates across the bureaus. 
XXXX. Contradictory Payment History : Despite the account being marked as Current and having a {$0.00} balance, the payment history contains 30-day late marks. If unverifiable or inaccurate, they violate FCRA requirements. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit bureaus are required to ensure the information they report is accurate and consistent. The discrepancies in dispute comments, payment history, and reporting dates violate this standard. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Conduct a Proper Investigation : If disputes have been filed and the information remains inaccurate or unresolved, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate and correct the errors properly. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor ( XXXX XXXX ) may have provided inaccurate or misleading information regarding the payment history and dispute resolution. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : If the late payments are outdated or unverifiable, they must be removed from the report.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am formally disputing inaccuracies on my credit report concerning an account reported by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to accurate, complete, and verifiable credit reporting. I have identified the following issues : XXXX. Inconsistent Account Details Across Credit Bureaus : Account Type Detail : XXXX and XXXX report Auto Loan. 
Equifax reports Recreational merchandise, which is inconsistent with the other bureaus. 
No. of Months ( Terms ) : XXXX reports 85 months. 
XXXX reports 72 months. 
Equifax reports 0 months. These discrepancies may lead to confusion for lenders reviewing the report.

2. Improper Reporting of Account Status : Equifax shows a last reported date of XX/XX/XXXX, while XXXX and XXXX both show XX/XX/XXXX. Such inconsistencies indicate a lack of synchronization and proper updates across bureaus. 
XXXX. Contradictory Payment History : All bureaus list the account as Closed or Paid with a {$0.00} balance, yet the payment history includes several XXXX late marks. If the account is resolved and paid in full, late payments should no longer appear unless they were valid and verified. 
XXXX. Equifaxs Misleading Comments : Equifax adds Closed or paid account/zero balance alongside Recreational merchandise, which differs from the comments on XXXX ( Closed ) and XXXX ( blank ). This inconsistency could mislead creditors. 
XXXX. Failure to Update or XXXX Disputes : If disputes were filed previously and no corrections were made, this XXXX indicate improper investigation and resolution by the credit reporting agencies. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must maintain accurate and consistent reporting. The discrepancies in account type, terms, and status violate this requirement.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If disputes were submitted and the inaccuracies remain unresolved, this reflects a failure to investigate properly.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The furnisher ( XXXX XXXX ) may be reporting inconsistent or incorrect details, violating the requirement to provide accurate information.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Late payments may be improperly retained, especially if they occurred more than seven years ago or are unverifiable.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports

XXXX The payment history for XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year> is inaccurate and reflects a charge-off payment history, which does not represent accurate or truthful information. I request that you update the payment history to reflect correct information or delete the account entirely from all consumer reporting agencies. In XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX, the court emphasized that repeated reporting of inaccurate charge-off information is misleading and distorts a consumers credit profile. Failure to address this matter promptly will leave me no choice but to escalate the issue through all available legal and administrative channels, including filing complaints with the CFPB, FTC, and state attorney general 's office.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the accuracy and validity of an account reported on my credit report by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to accurate and verifiable reporting. Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I have the right to be free from misleading or unauthorized debt collection practices. Below are the specific issues : XXXX. Improper Reporting of Disputed Status : The report states, Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. If you did not agree to this dispute resolution or if the dispute was not properly investigated, this statement might be misleading. 
XXXX. Unauthorized Transfer or Assignment of Debt : If you did not agree to any payments or the transfer of this account to a third party ( XXXXXXXX XXXX ), it could be a violation of consumer protection laws, including the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 
XXXX. Potential Obsolete Information : The accounts Date Opened is listed as XX/XX/XXXX, with the Last Reported date as XX/XX/XXXX. If the original delinquency occurred in XXXX, this account may soon exceed the seven-year reporting limit for negative items under the FCRA. 
XXXX. Lack of Supporting Payment History : The report does not provide a detailed payment history or verification of how the debt reached Collection/Chargeoff status. This lack of transparency raises concerns about the accuracy and verifiability of the report. 
XXXX. Incorrect Reporting of Collection Activity : If XXXXXXXX XXXX is reporting this account as Collection/Chargeoff without proper documentation or consent, this could constitute a violation of the FCRA and FDCPA. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and FDCPA : XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure the information they report is accurate and verifiable. Inconsistent and unclear reporting violates this standard. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Negative information, such as collections, must not be reported for more than seven years from the date of the first delinquency. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Investigate Disputed Information : If you disputed this account and it remains unresolved or improperly updated, this indicates a failure to conduct a proper investigation. 
XXXX. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The furnisher ( XXXX XXXX ) may be reporting incorrect or unverifiable information. 
XXXX. FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : False or Misleading Representations : If XXXX XXXX reported this debt without your consent or misrepresented its authority to collect, this could violate FDCPA provisions.

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding an alleged debt from XXXX that is being reported on my credit report and pursued by a collection agency. Despite multiple attempts on my part to obtain proper validation of this debt, as required by federal law, the collection agency has failed to provide the necessary documentation. 

Under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ), consumers have the right to request validation of any alleged debt within 30 days of being contacted by a debt collector. Validation must include clear evidence that the debt is valid, including details about the original creditor, the amount owed, and documentation showing that the debt is connected to the consumer. To date, no proper validation has been provided for this alleged XXXX debt. 

Furthermore, the continued reporting of this unvalidated debt by the credit reporting agencies violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), which mandates that consumer reporting agencies ensure the accuracy and integrity of the information they report. Reporting an unvalidated debt constitutes inaccurate and unfair reporting, causing harm to my credit profile.

Requested Action : Immediate Investigation : I request that the CFPB investigate the collection agency and the creditor, XXXX, for their failure to validate the alleged debt. I also request that the CFPB ensure all collection activities cease until proper validation is provided. 

Removal of Debt from Credit Reports : I request the immediate removal of this unvalidated XXXX debt from my credit report across all three major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax ) to prevent further damage to my creditworthiness. 

Compliance Assurance : I ask the CFPB to ensure that both XXXX and any collection agencies acting on its behalf adhere to the FDCPA and FCRA moving forward, providing proper validation before attempting to collect or report any debt. 

The failure to validate this debt violates federal consumer protection laws and has caused undue stress and harm to my financial standing. I request the CFPBs assistance in resolving this matter promptly and ensuring that my rights as a consumer are upheld. 

Thank you for your attention to this issue.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I hope this letter finds you well. My information was exposed in Equifax data breach. I am writing to formally dispute several hard inquiries listed on my credit report. Upon reviewing my credit profile, I discovered multiple inquiries and accounts that I did not authorize nor recognize. These inquiries and accounts are adversely impacting my ability to secure new credit and are unjustifiably affecting my creditworthiness. 

As per the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I am entitled to dispute any inaccurate or unauthorized information present on my credit report. Therefore, I kindly request that the unauthorized hard inquiries be promptly investigated and removed from my credit report. 

I emphasize the urgency of this matter and request that these inquiries be expunged from my credit report within 30 days. Such timely action is essential to restoring the accuracy and integrity of my credit profile and ensuring fair access to credit opportunities. 

Enclosed with this letter, please find copies of my credit report highlighting the disputed inquiries, along with any supporting documentation that may aid in your investigation. 

I appreciate your attention to this dispute and anticipate confirmation of the removal of these unauthorized inquiries from my credit report within the stipulated timeframe. 

Thank you for your prompt assistance in resolving this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am disputing inaccuracies on my credit report concerning an account reported by XXXX XXXX. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to accurate, complete, and verifiable reporting. I have identified the following issues with this account : Identified Issues : XXXX. Inconsistent Comments Across Credit Bureaus : XXXX : Dispute resolved ; customer disagrees. 
XXXX : Subscriber reports dispute resolved - consumer disagrees. 
Equifax : Consumer disputes after resolution ; closed or paid account/zero balance. 
These inconsistent comments create confusion for lenders and may indicate unresolved disputes, despite the account being paid and closed. 
2. Late Payment Reporting on a Closed Account : The payment history shows multiple 30-day late marks for a closed account with a {$0.00} balance. If the account is resolved and paid off, such marks should not appear unless accurate and verified.

3. Failure to Properly Update or Remove Dispute Comments : If the dispute is resolved, the comments section should reflect this. Leaving dispute-related remarks misrepresents the accounts current status. 
4. Inconsistent Reporting Across Bureaus : Equifax uses inconsistent terms, reporting Closed or paid account/zero balance, while others simply state Closed or Paid.

5. Inaccurate Reporting of Payment History : The presence of 30-day late marks on all three bureaus payment history while the account is current, paid, and closed with a {$0.00} balance could be misleading.

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must ensure accuracy and consistency in reporting. The discrepancies in dispute comments and payment history violate this requirement.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to Conduct a Proper Investigation : If the dispute was resolved and the information remains incorrect, the credit bureaus may have failed to investigate and correct the errors properly.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : Furnishing Inaccurate Information : The creditor ( XXXX XXXX ) may be furnishing inaccurate or misleading information regarding payment history and dispute resolution.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) : Reporting of Obsolete Information : Late payments or dispute comments may be obsolete and improperly retained beyond the allowable reporting period.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Credit Reporting and Request for 1099-C Documentation To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to dispute the accuracy of an account listed on my credit report. This letter is being sent under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 USC 1681s-2, which requires that furnishers of credit information report only accurate and verifiable information.

The account in question is as follows : 1. Account Name : XXXX XXXX  Date Listed : XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX. Account Name : XXXX XXXX  Date Listed : XXXX XXXX, XXXX This account is reporting a balance despite the fact that such reporting may violate consumer law and IRS regulations concerning the discharge of indebtedness. According to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, the issuance of a 1099-C form is evidence of an identifiable event of debt cancellation under IRS regulations . Specifically, Identifiable Event Code 7 states that a discharge of indebtedness occurs due to a decision by the creditor to discontinue collection activity and cancel the debt as part of a defined policy.

If a 1099-C form has been issued for this account, it signifies that the debt has been canceled. Reporting a balance for a canceled debt is not only inaccurate but also misleading under the FCRA. This inaccurate reporting is damaging my credit and must be addressed immediately.

Demands : Verification of the Account Balance : Provide evidence showing that the balance being reported is accurate and collectible.

Provision of the 1099-C Form : If a 1099-C form has been issued for this debt, provide a copy of the document as proof of the identifiable event.

Immediate Deletion of the Account : If the debt has been discharged under Identifiable Event Code 7 or can not be verified, this negative information must be promptly deleted from my credit report to comply with the FCRA.

Under the FCRA, I expect your investigation to be conducted within 30 days of receipt of this letter. If you are unable to verify the accuracy of the information or provide the requested documentation, you are required to remove this account from my credit report.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your resolution and a written confirmation of the results. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Complainant : XXXX XXXX Subject : Failure by XXXX XXXX and Equifax to Honor Identification and Power of Attorney Documents -- - Introduction : This complaint is filed to address multiple violations of federal laws by XXXX, which has failed to process my disputes regarding the inaccurate reporting of rescinded accounts. Despite submitting all required documentation, including a valid Power of Attorney ( POA ), identification, and Social Security information, XXXX has falsely claimed that my identification documents were insufficient or illegible. This baseless rejection constitutes a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and undermines the legal validity of my disputes and rescission of signature. 


-- - Background Information : XXXX. Accounts in Dispute : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year> Past Due Amount : {$1300.00} XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : {$12000.00} Opened : XX/XX/year> Past Due Amount : {$350.00} XXXX. Submission of Documentation : In accordance with 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), I submitted disputes to XXXX Equifax XXXX XXXX, asserting that these accounts are inaccurate because they were rescinded under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). As part of my disputes, I provided the following : A certified mail receipt from XXXX A mailing response from XXXX A notarized Power of Attorney document. 

A copy of my valid government-issued identification. 



XXXX. XXXX 's Response : issued a response stating that my identification documents were insufficient or illegible, despite my compliance with their requirements. This is a deliberate misrepresentation of the facts, designed to avoid their obligation to investigate and correct the disputed information under the FCRA. 


Violations : 1. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Investigation : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), XXXX XXXX and Equifax is required to conduct a reasonable investigation when a consumer disputes the accuracy of information. By rejecting my valid documentation, XXXX has failed to meet this obligation. 

Failure to Notify Furnishers : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 2 ), XXXX XXXX and Equifax is required to notify creditors of the dispute. Their baseless rejection of my documentation effectively obstructed this process. 

Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), XXXX Equifax XXXX must ensure that the information reported is accurate. Reporting rescinded accounts as open is a clear violation of this provision. 



2. Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : Non-Compliance with Rescission Provisions : The accounts in question were rescinded in compliance with 15 U.S.C. 1635, which nullifies any legal obligations tied to the accounts. XXXX refusal to correct this inaccurate reporting violates my rights under TILA.

3. Consumer Protection Violations : Obstruction of Legal Process : By rejecting my Power of Attorney and associated documentation, XXXX has obstructed the legal process, preventing me from exercising my rights to dispute and correct inaccurate information. 

Failure to Recognize Legal Authority of Power of Attorney : The Power of Attorney submitted in support of my disputes is a legal instrument granting authority to act on behalf of the principal. XXXX failure to honor this document violates well-established legal principles. 





-- - Conclusion : XXXX  XXXX and Equifax actions constitute serious violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, Truth in Lending Act, and other federal protections. Their failure to honor valid identification and legal documentation is unacceptable and undermines the integrity of consumer rights. This complaint seeks accountability for these violations and correction of the ongoing issues regarding the disputed accounts. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint to address the presence of unauthorized and unconnected credit inquiries on my credit report. These inquiries are not tied to any account or transaction I initiated or approved, and their continued presence is a violation of my rights under federal credit laws.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), a credit inquiry can only be performed with the consumers consent or in connection with a legitimate credit transaction initiated by the consumer. These inquiries on my credit report lack any associated accounts or transactions, and I have not provided explicit authorization for them.

Additionally, under FCRA Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), I have the right to dispute inaccurate or unauthorized information on my credit report. I have taken steps to dispute these inquiries with the credit reporting agencies, but they have yet to be removed. The failure to act on my dispute constitutes a failure to comply with federal laws requiring accurate reporting and prompt investigation.

Credit inquiries, even if unauthorized, can negatively affect my credit score and overall creditworthiness. The existence of these unconnected inquiries is causing unnecessary harm to my financial reputation and may impact my ability to secure favorable terms for future financial opportunities. 

I request the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) to investigate this matter thoroughly and ensure that the credit reporting agencies promptly : Remove all unauthorized and unconnected inquiries from my credit report. 
Implement stricter verification processes to prevent unauthorized inquiries from being reported in the future. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a resolution that ensures compliance with the FCRA and protects my rights as a consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting a formal complaint regarding an ongoing issue I have experienced with Equifax. Despite submitting all necessary documentation to verify my current address, including photos of my drivers license and bank statement, Equifax has continuously claimed that they can not verify my address change. 

Here are the details of my situation : 1. Address Information : I have been living at my current address for over 10 years. However, the address listed on my Equifax credit report is incorrect, and I have never been associated with the address that appears. 
2. Documentation Provided : I have submitted clear evidence to Equifax, including a photo of my drivers license and my bank statement, both of which confirm my current and correct address. 
3. Equifax Response : Despite submitting this documentation multiple times, Equifax has informed me that they are unable to verify my address change. This has caused confusion and frustration as I have no idea why they are unable to validate my address, even though Ive lived here for a decade. 
4. Impact on My Credit Report : The incorrect address on my credit report is causing unnecessary complications, and I am concerned it could negatively affect my credit score or my ability to apply for credit in the future.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
To whom it may concern, This letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting inaccurate and incomplete credit information on my Equifax Credit Report. 

15 USC 1681e ( b ) Compliance and Procedures ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report, it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 

Otherwise, anyone paying for yiyr reporting services could fax, mail or email in a fraudulent account. 

I demand to see verifiable proof ( i.e. : an original consumer contract with my signature on it ) that you have on file for the account listed below. Or a Certification from the creditor that certified the accuracy and completeness of the information/accouunt. 

Your failure to positively verify these accounts has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Under the FCRA, unverifiable accounts must be DELETED and if you are unable to provide me a copy of verifiable proof, you must DELETE the account listed below. 

I demand that the following account be validated or DELETED immediately : XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX  In addition, DELETE all non-account holding inquiries over 30 days old. 
Under federal law, you have thirty ( 30 ) days to complete your re-investigation. Be advised that the description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information is hereby requested as well, to be provided within fifteen ( 15 ) days of the completion of your re-investigation. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX
